We got the Dolmeh special, which ended up being a baked potato with a filling of braised goat, surrounded by wilted kale, sour grapes, raisins, all in a yummy yogurt-harissa sauce.  This was a very good dish.  Then, we got the eggplant, which was spectacular - two small, peeled eggplants, served whole on some grilled bread with an amazing sauce.  I could have ordered a second portion.  I should have ordered a second portion.  Because...

We were there on Meatball Monday, so we opted for the meatball special.  The waiter never mentioned that this meatball special was twice the cost of the meatballs on the menu (interesting definition of the term "special" in my opinion), but oh well.  Overall it was pretty tasty, but the texture was a bit mushy, and the bits of goat meat in the middle were a little on the dry side.  The meatball came on a plate with some broth/sauce that was pretty heavy on the cinnamon - not a bad thing, necessarily, but the sauce itself was too thin to cling to the meat at all, so it was sort of wasted.  

No dessert for us (the meatball was huge!), so we asked for our check.  Upon looking it over, I noticed that they hadn't taking the first drink I ordered off of the bill.  So we summoned our waiter and brought this to his attention.  At which point he informed me that it was not their policy to remove things like this from the bill.  Since I had ordered the drink and taken a couple of sips, I should expect to pay for it.  This totally blew me away - I am not the type to send things back everywhere I go, but I have never, ever been to a restaurant where this is the "policy."  Honestly, I would have been happy to finish my drink if they had been able to remix it with some more soda, gin, the elusive cardamom, ???  to make it more to my palate.    

The service for our entire meal was very good.  They did ultimately remove the drink from the bill without much fuss, but this episode, at the end of the meal, sort of wrecked it for me.  I don't think we'll be going back.
author: Cyrille K.

description: Great service and hospitality. Great modern takes of classic Persian dishes. The owner is very friendly and treats guests like his own family. A great spot to eat.
author: C Z.

description:
Located in the San Francisco financial district, Zaré at Fly Trap  is one of my favorite new finds. And, I'm not the only one raving about it. This Mediterranean and Persian-inspired restaurant has built a very loyal following. Much of the restaurant's success has to do with its owner, chef Hoss Zaré, an extremely social and gregarious guy with loads of celebrity chef potential. Seriously, mark my words: Hoss will become the first Persian celebrity chef.

The restaurant itself is a cozy and romantic spot with a rich 110-year history. Purchased in 2008 by Hoss, its new incarnation maintains its original quirky charm. Besides a few minor renovations and improvements, Hoss has cleverly maintained its original ambiance. Check out the funky antique wallpaper and sconces.

After moving to the states from Iran in 1986, Hoss ditched his medical school aspirations when he discovered his talent and love for cooking. Interestingly, he worked at the original Flytrap from 1989 to 1992, starting as a line cook and moving up to chef. It's nice to see him come back and transform the place into one of the hottest spots in SF. You might want to check out some of Flytrap's special events and lively dance parties frequented by the chic SF Persian set. 

Here are some of my personal favorites from several recent visits:

-Pisco sour made with barsol pisco, angostura, egg white, and lime
-Pistacho meatballs with harissa-honey-pomegranate sauce
-Roasted beets with laural goat cheese, grape molasses, and mint
-Ash Reshteh (traditional Persian noodle soup)
-Smoked trout with cucumber linguine, trout roe, and dill créme fraîche
-Ghormeh Sabzi with short ribs served over basmati rice (classic Persian fresh herb stew)
-Faloudeh with a tequila shot (a delicious tart sorbet with cream chips)

Next time I'd like to try the Lamb Burger and a few more of the drinks designed by mixologist Reza Esmaili. The absinthe concoction sounds delightful. ZUNG!  Not to mention an extensive wine list.

There are also several adventurous items on the menu that Hoss highly recommends, including the Spice Roasted Bone Marrow and the Oxtail Tagliatelle.

Finally, I was really impressed with the service. Not overly drippy sweet and not too aloof either. It was juuuusssst right.

Make a reservation. This place gets packed.
author: Elle J.

description:
Oh Hoss, just marry me already! I have been in love with this man and his food since his old outlet, Zare, in the fidi was my favorite. Having mourned the closing of Zare, I am delighted to live within a block of Fly Trap, and thus be able to delight in his menu any old time I please.

The service is familial, the atmosphere is lively and intimate all at the same time, and the food is outstanding. Arancini, lamb burger, oxtail, and beet salad are all on my list of favorites and there is a Sicilian wine that will kick your ass harder than my mafia-rooted brethren. The whole arrangement is wrapped up in a perfect rose-colored package and is just too sweet for words. Love may not be the right word for the way I feel about Zare, but it's pretty close. Great food, great people, great location.
author: Autumn K.

description: Wow.  I've walked by this place several times and thought it was just a bar, but no!  It is a Persian restaurant with fantastic food.  Recommended are any lamb dish and the Pistachio meatballs.  Also, I have to say that Brussels Sprouts are one of my least favorite vegetables but this is one of only two restaurants in which I have ever eaten that made me reconsider my position, the crispy sprouts are TDF!   How do they make them taste like almonds?
author: Kevin T.

description: Great food, great decor, good service, vegetarian menu  ahh my kinda place.  We went there around 5:30 or 6 so it wasn't super busy, which was nice because I does get loud.  Keep that in mind if you go there for a date.  A little pricey, but you get what you pay for--fresh, local and some organic ingredients.  I would definitely go back!
author: Megan M.

description:
In truth - I would probably give this place 3.5 starts.  

We had stuffed eggplant (w/ lamb) - which was excellent - and I dont normally eat lamb or like eggplant much - but it was really tender meat and made and presented uniquely.  Also had the grilled moroccan-style wild salmon (served with french lentils ~ ratatouille ~ charmoula ~ raita) - this was excellent - its meant to be eaten mixing up all the stuff that comes with the salmon.  
For dessert - we shared, not your grandma's pie (with lemon curd ~ coconut meringue ~ coconut sorbet saffron-mint syrup) all the accompaniments are served in separate areas of the plate - and its meant to be eaten by dragging the spoon through the entire plate, getting a bit of everything.  Its ok - for me the presentation was interesting but the taste did not really deliver.  

Overall I would knock this place only for not being better at advertising their entrees as really big serving sizes that 2 normal people could share.  Its really way too much food for 1 person, IMO.  Parking is a complete pain - but thats very SF! :) 

Worth a try - but would highly recommend trying and ordering family style!
author: Bhavin M.

description:
Last night was girls' night out. I love to organize and plan fun adventures for my friends so I picked Zare @Fly Trap to start the evening right. I've known Hoss, the owner/chef, for many years through mutual friends. I was a fan of his restaurant in Napa and I've dined at Fly Trap one other time before last night, so I knew that the girls would not be a disappointment. ;) 

Since we were a decent sized group we ordered a bunch of different plates to share. Pardon me for not recalling all the names, but I will do my best to describe the yummy delectables we enjoyed. I will post photos too.

Some of the dishes we tried were the roasted beets salad with goat cheese & grape molasses - never tasted beets so fresh and flavorful before, the braised italian eggplant - melts in your mouth, the famous pistachio meatballs with harissa-honey-pomegranate glaze - yum! we were fighting over the sauce, lol, a tasty sumac couscous salad, and a special olivia salad made just for us. Thanks Hoss!

We had four desserts. Yes we are lushes indeed.  We had the homemade sorbets, the goat cheese cheesecake - sooooo delicious, a fried dish, and a very special one with noodles & tequila poured on at the table - it tasted like a margarita, ridiculously good. :)

The cocktails were no disappointment either. I'm a huge mojitio and caipirinha fan so I enjoyed the Minted Memory yesterday evening. 

I really like what Hoss has done with the place. It has a nice warm, unstuffy vibe to it. Great for groups, but also romantic. The entrance is like a secret garden. Lots of beautiful details inside and outside of the property. Parking isn't too difficult in this neighborhood either. We parked a block away. Decent price as well for such an awesome experience.
author: S A.

description:
My first Thanksgiving in a restaurant.  A week before our trip to SF for Thanksgiving I realized that I hadn't made any reservations for Thanksgiving dinner. I perused yelp and tried reservations for all of the places that came up.  In literally hundreds of results, Zare was the only one with an open reservation, so I took it.  I called after booking to make sure it wasn't going to be like $100/each meal and that they had vegetarian options for me.  nly $59 for 4 courses and veg options for each dish.  Sold.

I really really liked it, for me it was not a traditional thanksgiving, but I am anything but traditional, so that was fine with me.  There was turkey, stuffing, and mashed potatoes for the main course for my husband, so that was fine for him.

I especially loved the eggplant dish and the veggie main course was vegetarian kufteh tabrizi, which is basically a veggie take on a meatball.  There were two huge ones and I could only eat one of them.  Mmmm, so good and clever, I will have to try it at home sometime.

Check out more at my blog: http://eclecticallymodern.blogspot.com/2010/12/thanksgiving-almost-month-later.html
author: Taryn B.

description: I stopped by their station at the SF Street Food Fest. I ordered their lamb tacos. Man. $8 for two 2 bit tacos. I haven't seen tacos so expensive. The tacos had decent flavors but it was like a spoonful of mushy meat.
author: Kien M.

description: Pistachio meatball is good but the lamb shank is just ok, too fatty.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Hoss Zaré is bringing an awesome middleastern twist to an "american food" landscape i find in my neighborhood. 

You walk in to a beautifully dim lit room, elegant walls and an awesome ceiling.. nice and romantic without being overbearing.  Hoss reminds me of a bear, and his jovial attitude put me at ease and ready to eat!

And goddamn did we eat...We started with a celery soup; creamy tasting, but somehow vegan.  Then we got a plate of babaganoush and a salsa-y potatoey kafuteh thing.  The baba was tasty, without the bite I usually expect, but the kafuteh and salsa took the cake.  Avocadoey, potatoey, pretty hard to describe but goddamn delicious.

For dinner I had the Lamb Shank, and my gf had the toretllini off the veggie menu.  The lamb was HUGE! savory, and melted in my mouth.  The pasta was good, but I was way too preoccupied with the hunk of meat bigger than my head!!

I wanted dessert, but my belly couldn't handle it.  All of that, a couple drinks and less than $100!!!  God blessya Hoss, I'll be back!
author: Joseph F.

description:
I would actually give it 3.5 stars. Cute ambience. GREAT cocktails (especially the "Cardamom My Dearest"). Love the fact that they have a separate vegetarian menu. I wanted to try everything! Here's what we got (amongst 3 of us):
- Arancini: Really tasty and good! Spicy too!
- Vegetarian Kufteh Tabrizi (the larger portion): Alright; kind of bland
- Marinated Chickpeas: Very tasty!
- French Fries with Saffron Aioli: Good fries, but we ordered them for the aioli which didn't have any saffron flavor in it

We were too stuffed to get any desserts, and we still had some Kufteh Tabrizi and Fries left over that we took to-go. I'd love to come back here to try the other items on the menu.
author: Chinmayi B.

description:
Love this place.

Excellent service.

Excellent food.

Great Atmosphere.

Every time I go, the food gets better and better.  The Persian inspired cuisine is excellent, and has moved way beyond the typical kabob and rice fare associated with Persian food.  Try the fesenjoon.
author: Bob R.

description: Ok the pistachio meatballs were quite good, as seen in almost all the pictures and reviews of this place... but everything else was a little bit disappointing.  The fesenjoon dish was interesting but was really missing the sweet or sour flavor you would normally expect.  In fact the sauce was almost completely missing -- just a dash on the bottom.  The chicken was well cooked with crispy skin, but hardly any flavor.  Same story with the noodles/confit on the other side of the dish; they tasted like plain noodles.  The lamb burger was spiced well, tasted good, but had no other toppings or anything to really go with it.  Service here was good except our waiter disappeared for a while right about the time we wanted to order something.  Overall a good meal, but expected more.
author: Alan M.

description:
I always wanted to check out this place but from the look of it from outside, it always looked to me very expensive. But it's actually not as expensive as you would think. It's pretty average. Food is $21-27 for main course. Appetizers are around $10-12. Wine bottles $38- and more. 

The place is beautiful. The walls are beautifully decorated. The waitresses are very nice and they check on you often. Honestly the service is much better than most other restaurants with this pricing. The chef/owner is very nice and he greets you if he is available at the end. The service is comparable to what you would see at a Micheal Minna restaurant or a very good fine dining place. Except they don't overwhelm you with extra unnecessary information about what you are eating in a weird formal language that most fine dinning waitressed do. Instead they make sure you have your clean napkin and your wine and water levels are good. Your Knife and fork are in the right place and are relevant to what you have ordered. They do all these in such seamless ways that it makes you not remember them but you remember that you were treated nicely and that you felt comfortable. Isn't that what good service should be always?

Food, was great. It was Persian Fusion. Torshi, Lavash, Kashke Bademjoon and other persian basics were reinvented to give you a new experience. 

I find this place a perfect spot for first dates, for valentines, for anniversaries, for meeting old friends (not large parties), for inviting your parents to a nice dinner, for meeting a professor and so on.

Definitely a classy spot. Go nicely dressed on an empty stomach and enjoy. 

Not recommended for large groups as this place has a nice quiet environment that should be disrupted by large loud parties.
author: T I.

description:
Your review helps others learn about great local businesses.

Please don't review this business if you received a freebie for writing this review, or if you're connected in any way to the owner or employees.
author: Martin S.

description:
Zaré is criminally overlooked in a city packed with great restaurants. Only I'd prefer that people continue to overlook it, because I'd like it to stay a quiet little place.

Their drinks are outstanding, their meals perfectly seasoned and prepared with fresh and delicious ingredients, and their deserts are out of control good without feeling bad for you. I'll second that the entire menu was so great sounding that it made it very hard to decide, but that's far from a fault.

Our server was spot-on, but my only complaint is that the host/house manager was a little brusque with us. Whatever, I'll be back.
author: Jess F.

description:
We came here for Valentine's Day and they were nice enough to accomodate my request for a window seat.  I was aiming for romantic but the place is as funky as the name implies and felt like we were in some kind of burlesque meets 80's music video set...Hard to describe.  Nonetheless, the atmosphere was entertaining and there was a spanish guitarist playing solo most of the night.  When I heard Jason Mraz during his breaks, I should have caught on... 

We had a prix fixe menu ($69 pp) with a unique wine pairing that really didn't complement very well, I thought.  They were mostly middle eastern wines which I'm not terribly convinced of just yet.  The pistachio meatballs were really the only memorable dish of the night and our main entrees (filet mignon & pan roasted bass) were average at best.  The chocolate mousse cake was embedded with some sort of rice crispy crust and was actually decent, but the port pairing was just not good...For the price, this was definitely a lop sided meal and as with all special occasion prix fixe menu's, it's a crap shoot.  Thankfully the service was decent, but I'll have to build up enough zare manifesto to come back on a regular night to compare...
author: Darren B.

description:
I am SOOO happy Zare is open for lunch now. There really isn't an option for REALLY good healthy food around this corner. (There is Lee's for salad but I'm not really much of a salad person)

I first had their Ash Anar Pomegranate Soup. I've never had any savory dish made with pomegranate before and it was so yummy. With all the grains, swiss chard, duck meat balls in the yummy light pomegranate broth. It wasn't overly sweet which I was scared of. All the ingredients complimented each other in the dish.

Another day my co-worker let me take a nibble of their Baklava. WOW I never knew roses could taste like that. YUMMY but REALLY sweet. I had about a half teaspoon serving of it and the tastes sweetness lingered on my pallet for a while.

I'm bummed to see that the Ash Morgh "Chicken Soup" isn't on their menu right now. My co-worker said it was really good too.

Today I'm having the sardine wrap with a side salad. I mostly choose this meal cause it is made with Monterey sardines. This DEFINITELY is not sardines from a can. The grilled sardines in the lavash bread wrapped with perfectly cooked veggies is such a great way to compliment the grilled sardines. 

I can't wait to try the rest of the dishes on this menu.

One other thing I forgot to mention the staff there is probably the most friendliest staff I've ever encountered in SF. Even the chef was walking around, knew exactly what I ordered and commented on why he likes the dish.
author: She R. A.

description: Was here for a birthday. Had the bone marrow appetizer and $27 braised beef cheeks, but still wasn't completely full. Felt kind of ripped of so ordered a squid appetizer. Maybe if they serve bread would be nice! Then came dessert decided to order baklava. Told the waiter my wife has a peanut allergy. He said NO peanuts in there only pistachios, which was fine. Baklava came she takes a few bites, plus it's dark inside and next thing you know my wife starts to have an allergic reaction. Turned on my flash on phone and here I see and can taste minced peanut in the baklava. WTF ! Still tipped 18% because we had a big party, but will never return.
author: Julie L.

description: I like that Zare serves mediterranean style food for lunch that's not based on gyro/falafel/hummus or pasta.  It's different but in a way that I like.  I tried the sardine wrap and pistachio meatballs.  It's a little pricey for lunch.  The food was good but not the easiest to eat for lunch.  The sardine "wrap" deserves the double quotes because it was so loosely wrapped that there was no way to eat it without a knife and fork.  The price point may make it difficult to convince colleagues to come here - especially since you don't get a lot of food for the price.
author: Jean K.

description:
Pros:
It is hard to find good Persian food in San Francisco, and at least this is Persian influenced.

Cons:
Some of the dishes didn't deliver--I went once and haven't been in a rush to get back.

Fun:
Try eating everything they have with eggplant in it in one sitting--makes for an interesting meal.
author: Mike G.

description:
[Probably more like 3.5 stars]

The food is pretty good, but probably not worth the price. They have a pretty interesting selection of beers and wines, though.

The goat cheese cheesecake is highly recommended. In fact, I'd almost recommend coming here solely as a dessert and drinks place.
author: Ryan C.

description:
One of the BEST dining experiences I've ever had last night! We went here to check out the food and private room for an important business dinner next week and we were completely blown away with the entire experience! 

5 STARS for every part of the experience: Price, Service, Food, Atmosphere, and Drinks!

Started off with the fly trap martini which is made w/hangar 1 vodka~ feta cheese-stuffed olive, toybox tomato & persian pickle. A perfect strong cocktail to begin our night! 

For Appetizers we ordered:
the vegetarian Kufteh Tabrizi which comes w/mediterranean avocado salsa, mushrooms and seven spices - AMAZING! 
Braised Italian eggplant - the flavors mixed w/sundried yogurt, walnuts and onions - Best eggplant dish ever! 
Pistachio meatballs - the flavors of harissa, honey and pomegranate glaze had a wonderful spicy kick. 
Sumac couscous salad w/dungeness crab was very fresh 

For the entree I ordered the lamb shank which came w/black eyed beans, and potatoes. OMG! it was cooked to perfection with the meat just falling off the bone. I tried some of the black cod and filet mignon as well but it was nothing compared to my lamb shank. 

Seriously no room left for dessert but we had to try the fried milk torrijas w/powdered sugar & rose water hot chocolate. WOW!! 

i don't remember the last time I've experienced such an amazing waitstaff who was completely passionate about their food and knew every piece of the menu. 

To finish off a perfect night, as we were about to leave the restaurant Chef Zare came and personally thanked us! 
I'm so excited about having our business dinner here next week!!
author: Deb C.

description:
As my SO and I walked towards our destination, we were bombarded with scents of curry goodness.  We jokingly told each other if Fly Trap didn't work out, we'd still have a good fallback next door.  That's as far as that idea went.

The manager gave us greeting and a light ribbing for being 1/2hr late -hey, we're out of towners and had no idea where to park- and proceeded to take us to our table.  Points for being nice enough to hold our table even though we were late on a capacity night knowing it was our anniversary dinner.  We couldn't help but share each other's plates since everything from the crab cakes and escargot to the rack of lamb and sweetbreads were nothing short of plate-licking good.  The staff did an excellent job of staying on top of things.

Our dinner finished on a high note with some berries with sabayon.  We even  enjoyed some tasty port courtesy of the manager while listening to happy anniversary sung to the tune of happy birthday.  They offered to play us our jazz song... but we both had deer in the headlights looks on our faces as we completely blanked out.  Oh sure the names of various songs poured in after the fact... maybe next time we'll keep a list at hand.  My date got to take home the rose sitting on our table.

All in all, we had a great dinner in a cozy laid back setting with friendly non-pretentious staff.  I'll be sure to make Fly Trap a regular destination whenever I'm back in town.
author: Edward H.

description:
Rating: 4.5 stars

Yummy!! Loved this place! My gfs and I shared a bunch of small plates here.  It's a super cute, warm and cozy restaurant.  Great for a date or just having a small intimate dinner with friends.

We tried the famous pistachio meatballs.  I am not a beef eater and ate this.  They were great.  But I have to say that I loved the lamb sausage!  It was not gamy at all and had a nice kick to it.  It was accompanied by a few pieces of squash and some other veggie.  We also tried the smoked trout salad, which came with cucumbers cut up like spaghetti.  This was good, but not one of my favorites.  We also tried the brussel sprouts that came with some sort of yogurt sauce.  Wonderful!!  Our last small plate was an eggplant dish.  Can't remember exactly how it was prepared, but it was another hit.  When you look at the menu, many of the dishes just sound so interesting b/c they are flavors that you wouldn't normally think would go together.  But they know how to make it work.  

One of the best courses of course is dessert.  We ordered the trijolla (not sure if that's how it's spelled).  But it was off the hook. I trijolla is a cross b/w a churro and a beignet.  It came with a side of chocolate sauce with rose flavor.  

I would def come back as it seems like the menu changes with what's in season.
author: Michelle H.

description:
I had been here twice before for dinner.  I remember the food being very good and liking the atmosphere.  I brought my co-workers over here for lunch.  The format was a bit different - ordering at the bar and seating yourself.  It made the event casual, but enjoyable nevertheless.

We ordered two steak salads, a lamb and salmon wrap, and fires and eggplant/garbanzo salad to share.  We also had the cheesecake.  I can honestly say that everyone was thoroughly pleased with their dishes (there was some crossing of forks as well).  The salads were very flavorful, and the meats were cooked just right.  The fries were really perfectly done!  We were impressed.

The cheese cake was the "bomb".  We will definitely be back.

The only criticisms are that they left us with a cheese cake to share with no desert plates.  And, there was at least 5 mins of waiting between the first two dishes and the second two dishes.  When you are hungry, it is hard to stare at your lunch, knowing you shouldn't start because you have to wait for the other half of the table to get theirs!
author: N F.

description: Tip: Sit at the bar - Fernando is awesome!
author: Jonathan H.

description:
I've been here 3 times now, and am always completely satisfied.  I've had the following dishes and loved them all. 

Vegetarian Kufteh - my favorite dish, so many flavors! Although, it is quite small so I recommend a salad to go with it!
Braised eggplant - also amazing with the yogurt sauce (order as Appetizer or with a side salad)
Roasted beet salad- great with the goat cheese
The fires - probably some of the most flavorful fries ever!
The vegetarian risotto balls with marinara sauce, also yummy!
Dessert: I haven't tried the goat cheese cheesecake but I heard its amazing as well (from my sister)!

Ambience is also nice, you can dress up or dress down (jeans  but with dressy T) and not feel out of place!
author: Harvinder K.

description:
I have been doling out 5-star reviews quite liberally recently (I'm nice, what can I say), but Zare without a doubt earns and deserves all 5 of those twinkly, pretty little stars.

The food was fantastic - the meatballs really stole the show for me - their pomegranate sauce was unreal. Tangy enough to make the back of your mouth pucker, but not to overpower the actual meat. My salmon entree was very good and the yogurt sauce was heavenly. The bread app was good and the sauces were insane... notice a trend here? The sauces here are ridiculously good... Not sure if Chef Hoss does the sauces himself or not but they were definitely the icing on top of a truly great meal. Overall, the food is a delicious melange of French cuisine peppered with dashes of Persian influence. 

The cocktail list sounded amazing but I am a sucker for a txakolina so I had to order it (it was good).

Desserts - the faloudeh with the shot of tequila was a hit at our table and I loved the deconstructed pie. I love being able to control my meringue:citrus ratio. :)

But the best part about dining at Zare is the overall experience. I felt like I was coming into somebody's home for dinner. Chef Hoss is amazingly friendly and genuinely cares that each patron (or rather, dinner guest) has a great time. Of course food takes center stage, but at Zare they really appreciate that it is not only the food which wholly creates 'The Dinner' experience. There are many restaurants that serve great food, and Zare is among them - but what puts it over the top is the warmth of the experience. 

5 stars, well-earned and well-deserved. Can't wait to come back on a Monday for the Kufte Tabrizi next time I am in town.
author: Ahu S.

description:
In a cute homey building in Soma you'll find comforting food done well.

Well thought out and good quality cocktails, apps, and entrees

What made me the happiest: goat cheese cheesecake!  

As a girl who is lactose intolerant (I try to stay away from dairy but sometimes it's just too much self control..), I was happy to see a dessert  that was a little more friendly to us asian stomachs... and it was better than I expected, and the lavender syrup helped take away that goat flavor I'm not much keen on!  =)

I wouldn't go out of my way, but if I'm driving around I will definitely grab a bite!
author: Hannah W.

description: Outstanding dinner and wine! The man is an artist in the kitchen and seasonings are his pallet. Unique and wonderfully creative dishes. Great drinks and wines. Not to be missed if you consider yourself a foodie.
author: Bill V.

description:
woo, first review! When do I get my elite status? :-P

Right, so I went here for my one year anniversary lunch at my current job. Good thing I told you that. It sets context. So no romantic encounters and no piano playing.

I ordered the Ahi Tuna Nicoise. I didn't even know how to pronounce it, but it included all my favorite things: tuna, artichoke hearts, olives, tomatoes, green beans, hard-boiled eggs(!) all tossed in olive oil. Lo and behold, a nicoise is a type of salad you can find at lots of places. Neat! It's my new fav.

So yeah, that's all I had there, and it was good. I didn't pay for it, but it wasn't horribly priced since it had HUGE steaks of ahi. I'll upload a picture of it.

knocked a bit for our table being near this curtain so the lighting was a little low. I like to see my food. But the other tables seemed well lit and people were happy. I'd go here again.

that is all.

PS, just realized this is probably the only French food I like.
author: Jesse K.

description:
3 to 3.5 stars.  I went here for dinner last month with a friend in which we always pick a new restaurant to try every month while we catch up over dinner.  The ambiance was great, in that it was full of people but quiet enough to easily hear your dinner partner's conversation.  Our waiter was extremely friendly with the right amount of attention, giving us the space to enjoy our food and conversation.  I would say the food was hit or miss.  We tried both the scallop carpaccio and pistachio meatballs.  The scallop dish was very bland and underseasoned, so the texture was not the most appetizing because that's all you were left with in terms of tasting the dish.  The pistachio meatballs in comparison were hearty, rich and flavorful.

I forget exactly what my friend had for dinner, but it was the special or the day chicken dish, a roasted chicken I believe, and the bite I had was quite tasty.  I had the cinnamon braised beef cheek dish which was incredibly tasty and fork tender, by far the highlight of my dinner.  I could have eaten several servings of that!

We finished with trying both the goat cheesecake and chocolate torte.  The torte was rather dry and again underwhelming in its flavor.  The goat cheesecake was much better, and the goat cheese does give it an interesting twist, but again, it was not an outstanding dessert.

I walked away feeling slightly disappointed, given some of the other highly rated reviews, but would consider coming back to give it another shot sometime given the atmosphere, service and the fact that our entrees were excellent... but not necessarily soon.  After all, there are so many more restaurants for me and my friend to try!
author: E F.

description:
Came here recently for a work dinner and I have to say i was surprised at how much i like this place. Passed by a bunch of times but never ate here, thinking it was too upscale for me. Since we were a larger group, there were hors d'ourves being passed around when we arrived. They were amazing. veal/beef meatballs and grilled shrimp both were well cooked and seasoned. Not overdone at all. Many times, places overcook shrimp.  As for the entree, I ordered the wild salmon. It was good but I found myself eying everyone else's fillet mignon with potato gratin. I'll have to order that next time. 

The space is a good size and has that french bistro feel. I like the seating and the bar area, especially. My one complaint would be mix drinks. I ordered multiple vodka tonics and they were all weak. 

I think this place would be great for a business lunch/dinner in Soma or to grab some beer/wine after work. It's right by 2nd and folsom; very convenient location.
author: Ka C.

description: Came here on a Friday night. The service is super friendly and attentive. We ordered the pistachio meatballs, the dolmeh of the day, brussels sprouts and the kashk bademjan, which is an eggplant dish. Let me say the pistachio meatballs do live up to the hype. The pomegranate flavors definitely came across more than the harissa but nonetheless, the meat was so juicy and tender. My next favorite was the kashk bademjan. It was AMAZING. I've never knew eggplant could taste so good. It was just the perfect balance of flavors and I loved the crispy eggplant chips served on top. I want to come back to try the entrees!
author: Amy N.

description: My goto place for taking friends that visit me here in SF. Always reliable and impressive.
author: Aish F.

description: Loved this spot! Great Happy Hour menu. I had the flat iron steak kabobs (though they really weren't kabobs on a stick like I expected) which was delicious. It was served with some fresh herbs, a creamy white sauce and some lavash. I'm not even a big steak person, but it was really good. I also had the fries which were delicious...served with a saffron aoli. My husband had the lamb burger (which was huge) and we both had a couple of glasses of wine. Wil also had a beer. We thoroughly enjoyed being served by Jessica, who was sweet, attentive and in-obtrusive. We'll definitely be back!
author: Sydni C.

description:
We had dinner there last night! It's a beautiful place. Food was very interesting, and tasted good. 
So, 4* !
author: cyril l.

description:
To be fair, I think I had the wrong dish and my experience would have been a lot different had I chosen something else. 
First of all, I loved the actual restaurant. It has an artsy modern vibe but still feels very welcoming. The decor and ambiance get 5 stars. 

The appetizer was good. No fuss, but good. Desert as well. Service is really good as well. Our waitress was nice, funny and knowledgeable. 

I had the filet mignon and here is why it did not dazzle me much : It had way to many flavors, to a point where it was almost not enjoyable to eat. 

The filet mignon had a balsamic/wine sauce on it. It almost could have stopped there. But then on top of that there were dates, Gorgonzola cheese ( these are not bland in flavor). Then it was served with a potato gratin, but I believe there was cumin in the gratin ( another strong flavor), and it had a side salad with fennel and watercress. There a point when a lot becomes too much. Well that dish reached that point. 

Zaré I wanted to like you more, but my dish was a little too odd. Next time, I will choose wiser !
author: Clara T.

description: Ten stars!!! Atmosphere is great, service is amazing and the food is unreal.  Persian fusion at it's best.  I would eat here everyday if I could.  Chef Hoss is the man and Nina is one the best servers!
author: Nima G.

description: Place did not live up to its rating. Everything was fresh and decent, but nothing really even approached "good."
author: candace j.

description:
Yummy yummy cocktails and appetizers! 

My favorite was the Expressotini- woke me up and was so smooth! 

Nice decor- ended up spending hours here on a weekday. 

Had risotto, mushroom truffle, fries, lamb. 

Very noisy with some really loud group that was distracting since they sat so close but we ignored them- or tried to anyway.
author: Anya R.

description:
I came here for happy hour with some girlfriends to celebrate my belated birthday and it was pretty busy at the bar. Let's start with cocktails! I ordered their pisco sour, which not many places carry pisco, perfectly delicious like it's suppose to. So my first round was from Peru, my next round was Spain! I had their anar daiquiri which was a tangy party in my mouth! Since I was already traveling through liquids, the fabulous bartender, Valen, took me to the deep Mediterranean for a Persian cocktail! I don't know what it's called but it was refreshing and perfect to end with my delicious birthday cheesecake! 
Let's start talking about food! We started off with an olive medley which was yummy salty! We then ordered the french fries with saffron aioli and sourdough bread & lavash. I had these with my first 2 cocktails and was paired beautifully. We then had the crispy risotto! It is a must order! Our last dish was the Persian tacos. Now these were not the typical tacos that were on the menu, the Persian New year just started this past Tuesday (March 20th) and some of their items on the menu was altered for the new year. They had fried baby shrimp (shell and all) and was a crispy light appetizer. To end our evening, Valen brought me the piece de resistance, the goat cheese cheesecake! You can taste the goat cheese and it was mild and the back end of your taste buds can taste the sweetness of the cheesecake.
The staff was incredible! And I'm in love with the bartender! Compliments to Chef Hoss! I don't do this often but they will be getting thank you cards from me!
author: Linda L.

description: It was the best Americanized Persian food I've ever had! The lamb abgoosht was very delicious, and pistachio meatball was really great!
author: Hesam S.

description: Great service but not my preference for Mediterranean food. I really prefer more traditional Mediterranean foods like from Maykedeh. Good service though!
author: crystle w.

description:
This place was just A-OK for happy hour for me. I just don't like having drinks at 5 pm unless they're discounted. Though cocktails like Pisco Sour and Mai Tai were tasty, they were $10. Some of the bar bites were a good deal though. 

I quickly glanced at the menu and saw Menage a Foie on the menu-- I knew I had to have it. I assumed it would be 3 types of foie gras, but there was one tiny piece of foie, chicken liver, and sheep liver. I pride myself on being able to eat the insides of most animals, but sheep liver is FOUL. Blech.
author: Mimi L.

description:
hmm... PRETTY GOOD. sadly I can't say i was blown away by it. I expected a lot more after hearing good reviews, but it was just alright. We ordered the lamb pistachio meatballs since that seems to be the popular kid in school. These were pretty good, but drenched pretty heavily in sauce. My waistline and I respectfully decline. The mushroom cake was REALLY good though, and I could have easily eaten another one.

For my entree, I got the grilled moroccan-style wild salmon after debating between another seasonal fish dish. I think I should have gone with the other one. Salmon is already delicious if you just pop it in the microwave, add some seasoning, and have the right veg/wine pairings, so I expect a lot from a restaurant that's serving it.  I'm not the greatest cook in the world (far from it), but I felt like I would have been equally pleased with my microwaved 15 minute salmon. 

There were plenty more items on the menu I'd like to have sampled and might have liked more, but since this rating is based solely on what I did order - meh. So yes, I'd come back again but only if I happened to stumble upon this when I was super hungry.
author: Natalie W.

description:
Loved this place and want to come back.  Came here for drinks with friends and it was great, apart from some really obnoxious people but that's not the restaurant's fault.

The bartender immediately came to our table and was fantastic.  The dirty Martini I had was sooo good.   We shared the saffron rice balls, which was amazing.  The sauce had a nice bite.  Yum.  The whole menu looked so good but I had dinner plans so had to contain myself or I would have sampled many of the dishes.

We were sitting at one of the shared tables and these really annoying people came by.  There were obviously pissed off that we were there.  The guy just tried to take over our comfortable space by pushing his chair and crowding my friend.  There was enough space.  It was pure arrogance and it made this guy seem so unattractive to us, despite the fact that he was so full of himself that he probably didn't care.   -sigh- Why can't we all just get along, especially on a Friday night after a long work week.?

The service was excellent and I am looking forward to coming back to our own table or with people who can share and know how to play with others :-)
author: Ayelet B.

description:
I was in town for the weekend and didn't really have any expectations since my friend made the reservation and I had never heard of the restaurant prior to that evening.   I thought the food was decent but was VERY PLEASED with the service.

The Sumac Couscous Salad was very good.  The entire dish was very flavorful; the dungeness crab was sweet and the couscous added great texture.

My friend LOVED the Pistachio Meatballs ( a house special apparently), but I found the sauce too overwhelming.  It was like a sweet reduced balsamic vinaigrette, which was about all I could taste from the dish.

I was looking forward to the Moroccan-style Salmon, but sadly it was overcooked.  The charmoula and fergola were delicious though.

For dessert, we ordered the  Banana Torte.  It had a layer of toasted marshmallow, banana custard, and a biscuit-like crust  that was way too sweet!!!!  We only ate half of it and it was pretty small to begin with.

The food was good, not great, but I'd come back again.

The reason why I'm giving this restaurant 4 stars is because of the service.  We were always greeted with a smile.  Everyone was polite  and very attentive.  My glass was never half empty and I drink A LOT of water, so they had to have refilled my glass at least 6 times.  Yay for friendly and pleasant people!!!
author: Julie L.

description:
Things I did not like about Zare:

1. Service/greeting. We stood at the host stand for several minutes, waiting for someone to help us. Since we were a few minutes early for the reservation we decided to wait at the bar, and showed ourselves over. We made a point of telling the bartender that we had a reservation for x time, assuming that the bartender would alert the host to our presence or flag down someone who could help us. This did not happen. She gave us a drink and never came back. Finally some other couples arrived, and the host appeared, so we got in the back of the line and were eventually shown to our table. Being ignored and worrying about losing our table because they didn't know we were at the bar was not a good way to start the night.

2. Lamb dish. I ordered a lamb dish that was beautifully described on the menu, but had the grey and cylindrical appearance of tinned cat food. The taste was not much better, sort of like the worst pulled pork of your life. Except it was lamb at a fancy restaurant.

3. Fillet mignon. Bland. 

Things I liked about Zare:

1. Minty cocktail. It was very delicious, and the right strength.
author: Laura M.

description: Excellent meatballs!! Pear and fig salad was excellent!! We had lamb that was tiny but good!!
author: Isidro L.

description:
Hung out at the bar and had first courses.  It was all really good. What made it for me was the bartender. i wish I had asked her name because she deserves props.  Probably one of the friendliest and funniest bartenders we have ever met in SF in a long time.

I overheard her actually ask for the phone number of an elderly patron. She wanted to call him later to make sure he got home okay.  I thought that was so kind.  You don't see kind of humanity too often.

Food-wise...the cucumber linguini with smoked trout in a dill creme-fraiche was the bomb. Loved it. Carb-free too.

Nice vibe at happy hour too. Good mix of people.

I'll be back.
author: Luis O.

description:
Outstanding and healthy food!  Took my vegetarian mother here for lunch, a picky eater, and she was very happy!   We shared the mushroom wrap, a special menu (Blackboard Eats) bulgur taco, and the roasted brussel sprouts.  Delish.

We especially loved the harissa sauce.  Hoss Zare, the chef and owner, came out to tell us that he will be marketing this sauce soon at www.hosszare.com.  

This place would be great for groups, too!
author: Ravi C.

description:
What a wonderful experience. Had my 40th B-day dinner there with the family. The atmosphere was a perfect blend of city-chic but quiet enough that we could all hear each other. The food was off the hook. I think we pretty much covered the menu, sumac couscous salad with Dungeness crab, mushroom cake, wild salmon, short ribs, fillet Mignon and deserts...yes one of each.

The table service was impeccable, from the darling foreign waitress to a personal visit from the chef. Both took such good care of us with special desserts and aperitifs. 

Thanks much to all at Zare's who made my birthday so special! This is a must visit...and don't wait for a special occasion, we will be heading back soon!
author: Paulette N.

description:
Popular watering hole for SOMA folks given HH specials, we came and stayed for dinner. Expecting it to be more casual, Fly Trap was pleasantly polished, soft warm lighting with red and dark wood accents throughout the bar and restaurant. Really a soft beautiful appearance.

With the long wait for tables, we opted to dine at the high bar tables instead which turned out to be quite cozy and made for a more intimate meal.

Our group shared some appetizers to start:  
- Pistachio Meatballs ($12) w/ pomegranate glaze. This was delicious. They brought the Mediterranean use of pistachios to classic meatballs for a twist of flavor that really paid off.
- Beet Salad ($9) w/ goat cheese. Thin sliced beets line a large plate like petals with accents of yellow beets and goat cheese with a center of watercress sprouts (or something like it). I didn't think it was particularly outstanding but it did live up to "beet salad".
- French Fries ($5) w/ saffron aioli. I didn't really taste the saffron but the fries were thin cut w/ skin which is how I like my fries.

For my main, I had the Black Cod ($22), with sauteed greens and a tomato gratin. My cod was cooked perfectly. Golden and just crisp on the outside; tender fish that breaks off gently inside. Mmm. Was really impressed. The tomato gratin was a nice touch. Something different. And I enjoyed my plentiful greens as well.

Our waitress/bar tender was very pleasant and attentive despite doubling as the bar tender. She was kind enough to pour me a half glass of Chardonnay upon request too.

Had a great time.
author: Cindy W.

description:
a modern twist on traditional dishes. pomegranates, pistachio, hashk o bademjoon, fesenjoon, i could go on....

each sip of my drink and each bite of food was literally a piece of heaven.  i was here with a few friends and we each ordered something different so we could try as much as we could.  we started out with some squash and the kashk o bedemjoon - both were so good a full of flavor that it made you want to literally lick the plate clean.  for main dishes we had the ghormeh sabzi, fesenjoon, and salmon.  having grown up with traditional persian food at home i usually don't like to order khoresht (stews) when i'm eating out but this was simply delectable.  my friends and i enjoyed every bite.  

the desert was the only disappointment.  it was an apple on a few cookies and ice cream.  it was tasty but hard to eat. 

i'll definitely be back to try everything else!
author: Sarah A.

description: Excellent service. It's a bit pricey but definitely worth it. I ordered the vegetarian spaghetti squash and absolutely loved it. The chef here is extremely talented. We had a group of 8 and everyone's meal was beautifully presented and looked like a work of art. I highly recommend the hummus Plate which provides a couple different types of hummus complimented with pita chips and lavash bread. A great place for a date as well!
author: Laila W.

description: Ended up here for a friend's birthday dinner and had some pretty killer food in a laid-back-but-classy setting.  Bone marrow to start, followed by lamb shank, which was incredibly tasty and tender.  The accompanying pickles were a nice contrast and the bread was handy to make a mini wrap or soak up the sauce.   Great service, too.   Will definitely be back for more.
author: Chung Y.

description:
Went recently on a Friday night, 7.30 reservation went straight to our table even tho place was busy.  We had six appetizer dishes, including the meatballs (good), fois gras combo (a bit too rich and two of three pieces texture and taste of plain liver), sardines (really good), a crab couscous salad (very good), curry beef tips also good.
Plan to go there again with friends - food was good to very good, reasonably priced, good wines by the glass list and bar drinks, ambiance very nice with just right level of noise - vibrant but not loud, service excellent.
author: Diane K.

description:
This is not a conclusive review since we went here for the first time on 8/24/2010, in the middle of a 90 deg + heat wave. So, maybe some of my dissatisfaction can be attributed to all of us being hot, although one of my complaints is that they had no ventilation in the dining room. No AC, no fans, no air vents. Just open windows which resulted in several mosquito bites....

Anyway, the service was spotty. It was not crowded and it took more than 10 minutes to get service at the bar (the bartender was MIA, probably icing herself down in the cooler). Our waitress was great at the beginning, but after our entrees were served, she must have joined the bartender in the cooler. 

And the food was okay, but I expected more care in execution. Three of us got the pulled lamb pasta and it was too hot when it arrived at the table. As in, we could not put it in our mouths, kind of hot. And of course, it was overcooked. BF got the special meatball with duck leg and although the meatball was really good, the duck inside didn't cook properly - it was tough. The bone marrow app, however, was the stand-out. Thoughtful and delicious. 

All in all, I'm not going to recommend against this place, but I'm also not in a rush to get back. Will update my review if I do.
author: Kate M.

description:
How on god's green earth could I walk in here at 8pm on a Thursday night and get a table? Could this be SOMA's best kept secret? There's no other explanation.

Every morsel was beyond satisfying. Of course we got those balls that everyone is raving about -- and rightly so, those mother truckers are bad ass -- followed by the mushroom cakes, oxtail and some delish dessert that's pretty similar to a churro, complete with hot chocolate for the dunk. My saliva glands just kicked in. 

But what I really adore about this place is the environment. Christ! Dimly lit, red accents, the wallpaper looks like pieces of vintage newspaper, the entrance is tucked away between two buildings and lined with hanging plants, and there is a fabulous persian rug as you enter the restaurant. Our server was beyond charming and beautiful. The whole experience put me in a trance and had me chanting Zaré's praises. 

Go. You won't be disappointed. And order up a glass of the Lebanese wine, CA wines can suck its grapenuts.
author: Alexis M.

description:
I was invited to a private party, and despite being slightly put off by the website's flies "buzzing" around the page, I figured why turn down a free meal?  

The food was outstanding.  Because we were a private catered event, we were each given a specially printed menu with three different choices for both appetizer/salad/soup, entree and dessert.  I was not displeased a bit with my choice of the pistaccio crusted meatball appetizer, the filet mignon with gratin and watercress, and the "not your grandmother's pie" for dessert.

The highlight was the dessert.  Not your grandmother's is actually three different dollops of heaven served on a long plattered dish.  You have to get a little scoop of each of the "crust" the "filling" and the "topping" to get the full pie effect.  Beautiful.
author: Cindy Q.

description:
This review probably isn't completely fair, since I wasn't really hungry when I came here and ended up getting something I wouldn't have normally ordered.  l was here late in the evening (9ish?) with some friends who hadn't had dinner yet, while I had already eaten (albeit several hours before).

I didn't want just a salad, and figured if I got the pasta, at least it would be good reheated later.  It was good, but nothing special. It was served with a very light cream sauce and lots of veggies. The pasta was a little over-cooked for my taste.  The portion was good, but it definitely wasn't worth $22, especially when all of my friends ordered entrees that were much bigger and better looking for only a few dollars more. One friend had the wild rice stuffed quail, which came piled high on the plate, looked absolutely amazing, and was only $6 more than my pasta. (My friend loved it.)
author: D E.

description:
I went here last night with 4 girlfriends, and we all really enjoyed the evening:  great food, great setting, and it wasn't as expensive as I would have expected.  

We shared multiple appetizers (and I even ventured to try the spicy lamb sausage which I don't usually enjoy, but it was quite tasty).  The staff was all super friendly and nice, and were accomodating to us sharing plates and food.

The chef/owner came out to check on us as well (hopefully not because we were being too loud), which I always find is a thoughtful touch.

Overall, great place that should be frequented by San Franciscans periodically, as a reminder of a great "old school" venue with great food, tasty drinks, and excellent service.
author: Jane N.

description: Loved pretty much everything here! Wish they had given us more hummus, though. Drink menu was solid and the food was adventurous and tasty. Will go back!
author: Michael M.

description:
An amazing restaurant.

I had lunch here over the past weekend.  My wife and I along with 4 of our friends each had an appetizer course, entree and desserts along with a series of cocktails.  I'll reserve my comments for what I think was the best of what we had (although quite frankly, everything on their menu looked amazing).  

First, as for appetizers the chef is well known for his kufteh (a meatball but without the meat).  While the kufteh was incredibly good, I would recommend the "Ménage a Foie", a series of three very good servings of liver.  Although listed as a side dish, we also ordered the couscous.  Very, very good.

Second, for entrees my wife had the black cod while I ordered the fulton valley spring chicken.  I have to admit, the chicken was the winner.  The chicken was perfectly cooked and rested on a sauce made of pomegranate, walnuts, onion, and some sugar.  The mixture was perfect.  A friend of mine also had a notable dish, "ghormeh sabzi", which was a very good lamb with rice, and a number of herbs. 

Lastly, for dessert I highly recommend the faloodeh.  It's a homemade Persian cuisine.  Flytrap tops it with fruits and a shot of tequila.  Very innovative, but also very good.

Overall, the best thing about flytrap is that it does something that no restaurant has every done - and it does it well.  It takes traditional Persian cuisine and adds new flavors to it while still retaining the core ingredients.  In that sense, the restaurant is as much the creative innovation of its chef as it is the quality of the food.  Had Flytrap simply been the first "new-Persian/Iranian" restaurant in the country, it would certainly be worth visiting and would have likely garnered 3 stars.  However, because it succeeds in blending new tastes with old ones, I would easily give it 5 stars and place it as one of the top 10 restaurants (easily) in San Francisco.
author: Nima M.

description:
It's starts with the bartending. Valen (sp?) does a spectacular job of making you feel like you've been a regular for years. After only a few visits, when I returned a few months later, she still remembered what I was drinking. Amazing bartending service. 

And then there's the food. It took me more than just a few visits before I had a full meal. And what a meal it was. Before you order, check with the wait staff to see what pairings are available. Hoss has a wonderful wine list, including some spectacular reds from the Middle East. He's got a couple of dishes that he's paired with those wines which provides a taste experience a foody will love.  Not to be missed is the "Ménage a Foie"... fois gras, sheep, and chicken liver, each prepared as a unique taste sensation. Sorry for the commercial. This is one of my favorite restaurants.
author: Harry M.

description: You just can't go wrong here... Beautiful bar and seating, intimate dining area and a little private cozy area for a small group.  The service is always friendly and kind but I don't think anything other would pass when you have a Chef/Owner like Hoss.  I've been here several times and if he is working that evening (which he normally does) he will come out and great everyone and see how everything is going as if we are at his home.  To some he is a rockstar! I've had drinks here, dinners here and it's never disappointed me.  The specialty house drinks are dreamy and some out of the box.  If you order something with the egg, don't freak yourself out too much, you'll like it, like I did.  And the food people, everything is incredibly creative.  It's a collage of tastes, textures, and mixed in with family traditions.  Glad I stopped by last weekend for a drink but sad I couldn't stay long enough for the bone marrow!  Next time.
author: Zin M.

description: Hoss is a boss, I love this place! The food is a great new take on some classic persian and non-persian dishes. I always try to take my friends and family from out of town here, so they can get a chance to enjoy the atmosphere and food here, as this is truly a one of a kind restaurant and experience.
author: Arman A.

description:
Persian fusion at its best (or at least in the Bay area) 

My Fav of Zare's Hybrid Concunctions: 
 -- The popular 7x7 listed Pistachio Meatballs: perfect interplay of sweet+tart+savory flavors with a plump meatball smothered in pomegranate reduction (an Iranian specialty) rolled in bright green speckles of pistachio 
 -- Duck Fesenjoon: why didn't I think of this myself? Fesenjoon is a dish that had often (yet not often enough due to the difficulty that goes into perfectly executing the dish) been on rotation in my Persian household. It's a stew consisting of pomegranate reduction, pureed walnuts, often served with chicken. Pairing it with duck I thought was brilliant, given how well this meat pairs with sweet/tart flavors. Although it lacked the oomph I expected from it, still a solid entree choice. 
 -- Lamb Shank Abgoosht: I love that they took a traditional working man's food in Iran (think the appetite/taste of truck driver) and put a refined twist on it....meat was tender, as it should be given abgoosht is meant to be slowly cooked for hours on in!
 -- Goat Cheesecake- I love goat-cheese, I love cheesecake, this dessert obviously went over well with me....
 -- Drinks: Anar/Pomegranate Daiquiri (as you can tell that love of pomegranate was definitely passed down from my Persian side) and Cardamom My Dearest (gin, cardamom, lime)

Looking at the current menu it seems to have shifted from having more of a Persian influence, to mostly western flavors with just a bit of Mediterranean flare. The lover of Persian food in me is disappointed by this shift, but the foodie in me has me anxious to go back in and give Fly Trap yet another try!
author: Mahsa K.

description:
Wavering between 3 and 4 stars on this one, but they offer a separate vegetarian menu, so I'll bump them up.

We started with the baba ghanoush.  I typically have it Turkish-style with garlic and yoghurt, but this is Persian-style with whole grain mustard and tahini. Outstanding and unusual!

G had the audacity to sit next to me and order short ribs that looked and smelled phenomenal. No further comment since I'm off meat for a few more weeks...

The vegetarian kufteh tabrizi is a Bulgar wheat ball stuffed with mushrooms, a whole garlic clove, and beans. Not really a fan of whole beans in my food, but overall the flavors meshed well and the avocado salsa took it over the top. I was happily sated. It's offered in two sizes, meze and main. One or two "meatballs". One is plenty. But the second reheated well in the toaster oven for lunch.

Wines by the glass, $8+. And I'm dying to go back for desert one day. Baklava!

Lent certified, Carnley approved.
author: Carnley P.

description:
I can only review the cocktails as we stopped in for a quick drink before dinner but I was duly impressed with this bar - well stocked with a wide assortment of artisan liquors, it seemed they could make anything.

My friend had a drink that was fantastic - gin and cardamom.  I was eyeballing the same but I'm allergic to juniper (and thus, no gin for me).  The bartender shrugged her shoulders and suggested another drink and then said "oh wait, that has gin too".  

No other suggestions from her - with such a widely stocked bar, that disappointed me that she wouldn't maybe suggest something off menu that was similar to my friend's cocktail but without gin (1 star off for that).  So I ordered something with bourbon.  It wasn't bad but wasn't great either (0.5 star off for that since i ordered it and it DID taste like bourbon... but that's all it tasted like - not what I want in a "specialty cocktail" with specialty prices).  Service was efficient though and I'd like to return again the next time I am staying in the neighborhood to give it another try and maybe try the food (since everything we smelled around us seemed divine!)

Ironically, we went down to Zero Zero for dinner and then DID have a vodka/cardamom drink on the menu... so it can be done.

Overall 3.5 stars.... could easily be improved on my next return.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Zare is a magnificent find in the heart of SOMA.

Modern, with a taste of historical class, this restaurant/bar has a wonderful vibe for after work drinks.

I came here recently for a Birthday Party for none other than Mr. Steve Ngo, and we had a blast. 

After work drink specials are on par, and will leave you more than happy without leaving a major dent in your pocket. The long narrow bar is a comfortable spot for free flowing conversations and post dinner one on ones.

There was a special area in the back where our party was hosted, and the highlight of the event was having the Chef and Owner, Hoss Zare, dishing out some wonderful mini bites for us to dine on.

He was gracious, warm, and full of good humor to make every one of his guests feel at home. 

The chick pea salad was my favorite. Served on thick silver spoons, these mini salads livened up the taste buds and went well with the down to earth cocktails being served.

Zare is a beautiful venue, and I'm looking forward to coming back for a full meal.
author: Mike K.

description: I came here on a Saturday evening, and found the overall experience to be quite nice! Our waiter was very much attentive to our needs, and had great suggestions and answers to our questions. The food itself was delicious-- for appetizers we tried their smoked salmon-wrapped fois gras and risotto cakes, and for our mains we had the braised lamb and quail/duck fesenjan. The duck was wrapped and baked in phyllo pastry dough and was my personal favorite with the sweet pomegranate sauce :). We loved the way they incorporated traditionally Persian and Mediterranean flavors for a nice, unique twist in the dishes. The ambiance reminded us of dining in an old library, dressed up with warm light from lamps and candles.
author: Consumer Z.

description:
Dance like a butterfly, sting like a bee.  Sting like a bee?  Yeah, actually, my friend got stung by a bee while sitting inside way away from the door at this restaurant.  Super-weird.  The wait staff was nice and brought us some ice for her finger.

Oh, and the food was pretty much delicious.  I really enjoyed the black cod seafood dish and found it tasty and very well-spiced.  A portion of it was a little undercooked for my taste, which is fine for sushi, but didn't give the right flavor or texture for this dish.  The saffron fries were good.  The bone marrow appetizer was tasty, but with a shockingly tiny quantity of bone marrow.  Come on you're going to throw the bones away anyway, don't be so stingy ;)

I did find a cocktail I very much want to try at home.  Cardamom my dearest...a cardamom & gin cocktail.  Little sweet but a lovely flavor!

Overall, a very nice place to eat.  Not a value restaurant, but the food is all well-spiced and the service is good.
author: Ian P.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco.
Great ambiance... delicious food and drinks... friendly service.

Here are my favorites:
Drinks: Cardamom my dearest and Minted memory
Appetizer: Pistachio meatballs and Kashk bademjan (eggplant dish)
Entree: Lamb shank soup (Abgoosht) and Monday nights special- Koofteh tabrizi
Dessert: Faloodeh
author: Farnaz D.

description: Wonderful dinner from arrival to departure. Eggplant & all salads we had = amazing. Wait staff all excellent & knowledgeable. Entrees included salmon, polenta, chicken & scallops were perfection. Can't wait to go back.
author: Kristi L.

description:
It was my turn to sponsor a romantic dinner, after receiving my annual bonus. I picked Fly Trap because of the yelp reviews as well as the Daily Candy recommendation. In a lovely mood I was, donning a new dress and requesting a button down shirt on BF, we came out to this cute little spot in the busier end of SOMA. 

Service: We waited quite some time before getting some acknowledgment from the server. But once our waiter stopped by the table, he explained everything on the menu proficiently and all of our food came out timely. The chef also greeted each table with a friendly hello, which I thought was very nice. 

Food: The description of the butternut squash soup was delicious--- curried with a drizzle of basil oil--- I was sold. Unfortunately, the texture of the soup was way too thick. BF called it: It was like drinking spoonfuls of gravy. It was also on the salty side, and as small as the portion, I simply could not finish it. The trio of foie got us excited, but also fell short. The original foie, supposedly the most delicate one, was rather gamey. The sheep liver to my surprise, was actually not bad at all, being a non-lamb eater. Then the chicken liver just underwhelmed. Calling that robust in flavors would be an understatement.  Now the bone marrow, one of my favorite things to eat in the world--- were my taste buds simply numbed by the gravy soup?  It was bland and not hot enough, and the rock hard toast was impossible to chew down.  Simply not the bone marrow I had looked forward to.  

My main course, the black cod, was very bland.  BF's lamb shank was good--- once again, for someone like me who does not eat lamb, actually found the meat so tender and with very little gaminess.  It was the only good dish that night.

Cocktails were delicious, as we each had 2.  I always bypass the wine anyway, so cannot comment on the wine list.  Oh, and there were mosquitoes.  I got bitten at the table.  And when I went to the bathroom, there were two big ones resting on the mirror.  Yuck.

Overall, not crazy about their food.  I almost feel bad saying it, but that's my honest opinion.  Maybe the butternut squash soup just ruined my palate for the night...  I don't know.
author: Jiajia C.

description: this is a great place to get dinner and drinks with friends. i came here on a saturday night. even without a reservation, we got a table right away. i had the stuffed tomato, pistachio meatballs, and the cod. everything was amazing. me and my friends ordered another stuffed tomato, and we would have ordered more if we weren't already full. the drinks were also very good. i will definitely keep coming back to this place.
author: Rebecca D.

description: Nice  place, came with friends, food was good service likewise, will return.
author: sweetie p.

description:
I've been here a few times since Zare took it over. Each time has been a delight. Four-star food at Three-star prices, and cozy, personable service that takes the whole thing up to a Five-star experience for me. 

The bartending is stellar. I've found alumns of the city's finer craft cocktail houses on each visit and enjoyed whatever the revival du jour is among cocktail geeks. I've been ordering small food from the bar menu, all lovely and tasty and harmonious with the vibe of the place (perhaps the food *is* the vibe of the place). I have been eyeing the larger fare being sent to the tables; next time, for sure. Oh, and that big guy in the white jacket wandering around the dining room and chatting everyone up? That's Zare dispensing general charm and hospitality.
author: bobo n.

description: The cocktails are unique, the food is delicious and artistically prepared!  The ambiance is perfect.  One of the best I've been to in SF.
author: Laleh J.

description:
Yumm.  Picked it up to go.  Stuffed squash was not actually stuffed but it did have lots of delicious toppings  -  just needed a little more of the sauce to go with it.  Brussel sprouts were sauted and tasty - loved that sauce too as it had feta in it.  They seemed a little greasy as they sat in the togo container.  Would still get them again.
Goat cheese cheesecake - I love goat cheese so it was fantastic but I could imagine that it might be overpowering for some.
The restaurant was packed including the bar.  Reservations are a must.
author: Carolina R.

description: The smoked trout appetizer was the best part of the meal.  Our entrees--lamb burger and albacore, were reeeally bland.  The drinks were nothing special.  The ambiance is warm and cozy while also being a little fancy.  The service was really good--very attentive and friendly.  They should either lower their prices or liven up the fare.
author: Dagmar H.

description: This place is a lot of fun! I've been here for dinner once about a year ago - and I still remember how good their meatballs are! Highly recommend. The entrees were excellent as well. We came here most recently for cocktails right as happy hour was ending (doh!) but the place was packed. We managed to snag a few barstools, but it was definitely crowded. We'll have to come back again to experience the happy hour in full. However the drink I had was really delicious..although the other choices sounded good as well!
author: Christy M.

description:
I love this place! It's really easy to get carried away while choosing from their diverse and inventive main and drink menus. 

This ain't the most useful review, I know. But -- if you are an adventurous eater, isn't picky, got a group of friends to go with and just got paid, check it out. Cuz I said so!
author: Faffy L.

description:
Excellent food. Hats off to chef Zare.

I went to this restaurant a couple of years ago and found it overrated. However, I tried it once again this year and it was GREAT. Hats off to chef Zare for listening to his customers and respecting their opinions. He is a very smart and talented chef. I would definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Narg R.

description: Fantastic food! Try "Koofteh Tabrizi". It is the best :)
author: Azi Y.

description:
I was really excited to try this place.  I saw an article about the restaurant in SF Gate and made a reservation through Open Table.

The restaurant was nice and the service was great.  We just thought the food was just alright.  The appetizers were great.  We had some sort of ball with avocados and the baba gnoush.  They were great.  The main dish was a disappointment.  I ordered the herb stew with cod and expected a flavorful dish but it was really bland.  We ended with the goat cheese cheesecake - which I'd come back for.
author: Johannah P.

description:
A friend invited me to dinner here. Last time I came it was "just" the Fly Trap, which I remember as an old time restaurant in San Francisco and unremarkable. Now a Persian fellow named Hoss Zaré has taken it over (hence, Zare at Fly Trap; the bartender, a very knowledgeable lady named Valen, told me that Mr. Zaré has a big following in San Francisco (http://cookeatshare.com/chefs/hoss-zare-10507), so the idea was to attract his cult as his customer base for this restaurant. 

Drinks: At the recommendation of Mario, the host, Valen made a cocktail with no name for me, which was equal parts of yellow & green chartreuse and Black Bottle, a blend of single malts from Islay with a splash of Luxardo, a cherry liqueur. We agreed that the best way to describe the concoction was something like licking the rubber of a street, from a car that had laid it there earlier. Surprisingly good! :-) My friend had the "Cardamom My Dearest", which she said hit the spot. (I did try a pisco sour, but didn't like it and had another Street Rubber.)

Food: I had pistachio meatballs with harissa, honey, and pomegranate glaze as the appetizer. And then something called "ghormeh sabzi", described as a herb stew with basmati rice, preserved lime, which I had with the short ribs. Both dishes were delicious, tasty with complex flavors that complemented each other. My friend had a boring salad(!) and the spring chicken with wild rice, walnuts and fessenjoon, which was very good, particularly that sauce. The food was well cooked and presented and came promptly, when we wanted it. 

Our waitress, Meg (short for Margaret), was totally professional. We went last night, Thanksgiving eve so there were only two other tables seated. I had a blast with Meg, Valen, and Mario (not to mention my friend!), so great drinks, great food, and wonderful staff. What's to complain about? I'll be back (and Meg promised to remember me and get me in when it was crowded!)
author: Stewart A.

description:
After much debate, I am actually going to write my first Yelp review.  It is unfortunate this needs to be categorically negative, but I feel strongly that others should not be subject to the treatment that my friends and I experienced last weekend.

Our party consisted of 17 people for a 2-way joint birthday dinner.  I had no strong first impression - ambiance is like a smaller Cafe Des Amis.  

The lady bartender was actually fantastic - very helpful in guiding us to a special scotch as a birthday toast.  She gets a star.

The first sign of weirdness was a bread service that contained fewer pieces of bread than people at the table.  And how we'd be charged for more.  Fine, it's a recession - I understand you need to charge $5 for 8 pieces of bread.  We'll wait.

Next up:  lamb sausage appetizer.  This was probably the highlight of the meal (though possibly due to being hungry from lack of bread).  Very flavorful - a little salty, but this was balanced out nicely by the accompanying squash.  Ideally, we could isolate this dish and serve it at a high quality restaurant.

Main course:  filet mignon.  I say filet mignon only because that's what they call it on the menu - a more appropriate description would be "gravy drenched meatloaf".  Curiously, the waiter never asked how I'd like the filet to be cooked (to be fair, some of my other friends said they were asked).  It appears he assumed I wanted "cooked until the filet tastes equivalent to meatloaf".  Fine, I guess I should have proactively asked for "medium rare".  I asked an employee named Ryan (who later turned out to be the General Manager) if there was anything he could do, and acknowledged the waiter and I never had a discussion about how to cook the steak.  Ryan responded with, "Okay, we'll bring you another piece".  Awesome.  Oh wait, the 2nd piece tastes just like the first piece.  Ugh.  

Dessert:  "Not Your Grandma's Pie".  This one was actually very aptly named because my grandma, who has no idea how to make a pie, could make a better pie than this!  Since when do people enjoy slimy, tasteless meringue amorphously smeared around a plate next to a pile of bread crumbs... such that it looks like the product of someone puking and shitting at the same time?  This is not a pie.  If they were going for a "deconstructed" presentation, a pile of sugar, flour, and eggs would have been preferable.

Okay, time to go!  Oh wait.  The bill appears to be $100 per person.  That's strange, because we were told $82 per person for the fixed menu.  Excuse me, General Manager Ryan, we don't understand?

Oh, it turns out that our contract was for 18 people instead of 17.  Despite how [birthday boy's gf] had called two days earlier to say we'd only be 17, and how she was told that'd be fine... I guess the number stands at 18.  Okay, so can we have the extra meal?  No??  Why not?!  Because:  They had voluntarily replaced my overcooked steak with an equally overcooked steak.  Really?  In what universe is it okay to tell a customer you'll replace a steak, and then charge for two of them??

Further justification for not giving us the 18th meal:  we're lucky to have even gotten to eat in the side dining room.  Despite [birthday boy's gf] having been told in advance that we could sit at a single table, we were placed in a side room and split into two tables.... we should be advised that we were done a favor here.  It seems we owe Ryan a meal for splitting our group in two.

Final justification for not giving us the 18th meal that we're paying for:  we've been drinking.  Huh?  We're being accused of being drunk?  I had two drinks over an hour ago!  What is this guy in his day job - a high school prom chaperone?  And how does this have anything to do with us being refused a meal that we're paying for??

The only silver lining here is that we were all amongst friends, so it was easier to enjoy the rest of the night.  Imagine bringing a group of business clients here... Good God!!
author: Joseph S.

description: Had a great meal with friends. Shared appetizers and entrees and everything was delicious!  Flavors are different and fresh... everything tasted fantastic.  Gabriel rocked it and took great care of us. Thanks!
author: Beth N.

description:
