It has been nearly a year since we were there but my memories of the place are good. 

There were 3 of - we started with the spice-roasted bone marrow &  grilled sardines, not terrible.  Seriously not enough bone marrow at all.  The plate was dominated by other things...would not order either again.

For the main course, we got grilled moroccan-style wild salmon & grilled pork chop and some thing else which I cant recall. Overall, we thought the food was ok but what really threw us off was the fact that there was a big party sitting next to us.  All the servers and the chef were falling all over themselves helping this big party so we felt like the poor outsiders and an afterthought by the servers, who had been super nice all evening before that.

I know that there is nothing you can do about who you sit next too, but feeling like the poor relations never makes any one feel like they are appreciated.  The chef must have come out to that table a hand-full of times checking on everything, we were sitting right next to that table yet he never asked us if we were good!

Ha-ha, no big deal they could be family or anything.  Food was decent (we are picky, we love to cook and eat out), would recommend just wont go back.

The
author: ORLA L.

description: Great service, great food, warm staff and super clean place. I will difinitely come back.
author: Nick M.

description:
Disclaimer: This is my very first Yelp review. I simply haven't cared enough until now - I haven't felt this strongly about an establishment (for better or worse) in the past 5 years. This is saying a lot, as I am a minority owner in a restaurant myself (and have never tried to push it up with reviews) and have friends that run numerous restaurants.

Summary: Food started out at 4 stars, rapidly decreased to a 2-3 stars. Service started out average and plummeted to -2 stars. Weighting food quality and food service equally, the net rating is at 1 star. BOTTOM LINE - DO NOT COME TO THIS RESTAURANT UNLESS YOU WANT TO BE TREATED LIKE A MENTALLY CHALLENGED INDIVIDUAL OR [INSERT DEGRADING RACIAL SLUR]. And the food was mediocre to boot! Diner be warned, especially if you have to deal with the condescending, hostile, and untrustworthy general manager Ryan.

Details: Zare went from good to bad to worse in the span of 2 hours. To be objective, I'll point out the positives first. I only had one complete drink at the bar (a Pisco Sour) and a couple sips of another one of their cocktails. Both were spectacular - well mixed and a great start at dinner. After making my selections off the set menu, we waited for a very long (but still tolerable) amount of time for our appetizers. I got the Pistachio meatballs (a signature appetizer), and was immediately a fan. Given how hungry I was, they immediately hit the spot. Current rating - 4 stars.

Unfortunately, the entree I chose was a major step down. I consider myself a steak fan, so when my Filet came out tasteless and dry, I was disappointed. To compound matters, I had originally asked for Medium Rare, but the waitress made it a point to ensure me that it was easier for them to leave the temperature at Medium, and that it would be pink, moist and tender on the inside. To me, this sounds like a bit of laziness on the chef's part as the waitress specifically asked me if I could go with Medium and it tasted like a piece of cardboard. Several of my friends left their Filets barely touched. Current rating - 2-3 stars.

The evening progressed. We were with good company for a friend's birthday, so everyone was in a good mood despite the subpar food. We did not object to the $2+ PER PERSON cake cutting fee, although it seemed unreasonably high. Nor did we complain when the restaurant-supplied desserts came out highly original and inventive (in the worst possible way imaginable). Backstory - after asking the waitress for her recommendation, I ordered the 'Not Your Grandma's Pie", which was a jumbled mess of ingredients presented in a way that resembled something akin to lemon-flavored puke (or perhaps bile or phlegm). The flavors of the "pie" were not completely inedible (the sorbet was actually good), but the texture and lack of an actual pie (cake or bread or cookie dough would have been fine substitutes) really killed it. Globs of random ingredients that a toddler would fling around in a baby food fighting contest really don't satiate the palate, especially when one expects a pie. Current rating - 2 stars.

At this point, we were ready to leave. Had service not gone from mediocre to downright condescending, you wouldn't be reading this. I wouldn't have been motivated to break my Yelp virginity with this review (and further spreading it on all social media channels - can I get a retweet people?). But alas, the general manager decided to act elitist, present his best "the customer is always wrong" smirk, and insult no fewer than 6 of my friends. I felt like I had received a figurative boot up my ass, and now I'm punching back.

Having fallen one person short of the minimum for our group party, we politely asked if we could get the extra plate of food since we were paying for it. All the general manager had to say was "No", and that would have been an acceptable answer. Ryan said "No", but he followed with ridiculous excuses that only a 3 year old child would buy. Choice quotes below:

Ryan: You guys sent back a steak. We were going to charge you for that one. But I didn't because I knew the last person didn't come - so it all works out.

Friend: But wait...if the steak was done poorly, shouldn't Zare comp it?

Ryan: No it was your fault.

Friend 2: That's not how it is at other restaurants.

Ryan: This is how all restaurants do it.

Friend 3: Can we get the extra steak to go?

Ryan: No, you guys look like you want to have a good time tonight. We don't do food to go.

(Really??? Because your waitress just dropped a place card at our table for Food To Go for another entree. Are you lying to our faces?)

Me: Ok, we can eat it now.

Ryan: Look, clearly you have had a lot to drink tonight. Why don't you guys just leave.

(WTFx10. Only had 1 drink 3 hours ago buddy.)

Me: "I am not drunk"

Conclusion: The GM is condescending, arrogant, and will call you drunk if you disagree with him. The food is a sorry excuse for fine Mediterranean given the numerous other options in SF. 1 STAR.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Fine dining Persian restaurants are pretty much absent from the San Francisco food scene. If you know of another place with food, service, and an atmosphere this fantastic, then you better share your secret!!  But it's no secret why Zare, along with it's owner Hoss, is so impressive.

My roommate is a friend of Hoss', and so she sent him a little note about the dinner reservations she made for 4 gals to celebrate our dear friend's birthday. I showed up first, and was surprised to find the restaurant's executive chef and owner playing hosting duties. He walked up to me, I told him what party I was with, and he opened his arms big to give me a hug (assuming I was the birthday girl). I told him she was on her way, but that looking like I could be Persian myself I took it as a compliment that he would mistake me for Sahar (the beautiful birthday babe). No matter, I was a friend of Lauren's (my roommate) which meant I got greeted like a guest of honor. He sat me at our table and we had a wonderful conversation about the industry, about traveling, and about what wonderful weekends we both just had. What a character and a charmer! I knew, right away, I was about to have an impressive meal....

Did we EVER!!! We started with flat bread that came with the most amazing tapenads and spreads, pistachio meat balls, eggplant, wild mushroom pie, and THE  BONE MARROW with bergamot preserve. I'll order bone marrow anywhere that has it...which means I've had it at every possible French restaurant in this city. It was by far the best bone marrow I've ever had outside of Paris. The preserve paired with black sea salt makes for a taste experience you've probably never had. Get it!!

Our entrees were superb as well. The succulent duck I ordered came with a very sweet, and yummy, pomegranate sauce; the "Monday Meatball" my roommate ordered was stuffed with amazingly marinated short rib; the squash that our other friend got was perfectly cooked; and the chef was nice enough to replace the salmon in the Moroccan-style salmon dish with lots of veggies for our vegetarian birthday gal! Both bottles of wine recommended by their staff were perfect pairings with the food, and to top ALL that off....Hoss sent us 3 desserts on the house! 

The hospitality and the food were some of the best I've ever experienced in any restaurant anywhere.

Thank god my birthday is coming up soon ;-)
author: Raquel C.

description: Love the food and the staff. Great place for happy hour. The meatballs and lamb burger are two of my favorites, but can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Sandy M.

description: A few friends and I dropped by here for an impromptu Happy Hour and had a good time. The decor in here was pretty upscale but not uninviting. We sat in the bar seating area which wasn't too packed at 5PM on a Friday. The price was definitely right for happy hour--well drinks only $3! Had a margarita that was very tasty and also had the fries with the aioli sauce.  I would love to come back for dinner. A good time with good people and a nice spot for happy hour.
author: Mymy N.

description:
Another restaurant where I'm conflicted with ratings - 3.5 or 4? Came here for the dinner portion of a bachelorette party. Service was great, waiters came by often enough to make sure we had our cocktails on hand, and water refilled.

The pistachio meatball things were delicious. The sauce, oh the sauce!! Probably the best part of the dish. The tri-tip appetizer was also quite delicious. Cocktails here are on the sweet side, but pretty unique. Nothing too awesome...the brussel sprouts side was just ok I thought. I had imagined something more robust and flavorful, but it just wasn't. 

The winner of the night, in my opinion, was the lamb burger. I don't usually love lamb, but as part of my hamburger quest, I figured I was obliged to order and try this rendition of a hamburger. I'm glad I did. The burger was freaking delicious and satisfying, even though there wasn't really anything in it aside from some chopped up veggies of some sort. The fries were pretty awesome too.
author: Carol L.

description:
I went with a group, we tried everything and it was all delicious! The whole menu was great, from the appetizers to the desserts! 

I didn't have any experience at the bar but the restaurant and service were very good. The food was fast to the table, but they were not in a hurry to get us out of the seats and turn the table over which allowed us plenty of time to enjoy our meal. I'd go back
author: Andrew W.

description: Great food as always!!  I especially enjoyed the duck dish tonight (with the pomegranate reduction and citrus hints): Excellent dish (although I might have liked a duck a little rarer?).  I was not as wowed by the meatball special for Mondays (what can I say, the duck dish probably set the bar high), but the Lamb Entré was pretty darn good as well.  Service was superb as always.  You cant go wrong with dinner at Chef Zaré's restaurant and I'll be back again soon enough!!
author: Leroy R.

description: When my boyfriend picked out a "surprise" restaurant for us to go to before Cirque Du Soleil Totem, I realized I'm a bit of a control freak and got a little nervous about where we were going.  Control-freak-no-more after this experience -- I am a bit of a closet food snob -- That said, I've NEVER had such an amazing tasting ANYTHING than this evening.  We started with the meatballs, which our server told us are on the SF Food Bucket List.  Wow!  Every bite was a little taste of heaven.  Zare's meatballs are more-than-tender, and cooked to perfection.  Then I had the salmon, which came with a couple of very different types of sauces and reductions.  The oregano-thyme tasting mixture on the plate was the most interesting taste my taste buds have ever come across - in the best way I can't even describe.  This was by far the best meal I've ever had, and I can't wait to go back!
author: Jamie G.

description: We have been fans of owner Hoss Zare through many different restaurants, his Financial District Zare, then his place in Napa and now Flytrap.  At my husband's request I took him here for his birthday and was not disappointed.  The food was excellent --dolmas, lamb stew, tuna, and the goat cheese cheesecake was outstanding.  Service was solicitous without being overbearing.  Our waiter Brian was very accommodating to my request for tweaking a dish to remove a dietary issue for me.  The maître'd Fernando was lovely and arranged to play "When I'm 64" for hubby's birthday.  Altogether a really nice dining experience and the prices are very reasonable.
author: Frances W.

description:
We had our appointment at 7:30 pm, and called to see if they had anything available earlier .  The receptionist told us that they should have a table ready close to 7pm, so we went there early . . . but then we ended up waiting until 7:45 pm.  

The carpaccio appetizer was very good, but the other dishes were just ordinary.  The lamb shank especially was bland, and the presentation was very plain.
author: Elena L.

description: My wife and I went to Zare for her birthday. We had an amazing time. Like many others, we'd recommend the meatballs. The halibut we had was amazing as well. It is a great atmosphere and we loved Hoss. What a wonderful guy?!?!?!?!? Go now.
author: Tim B.

description: Was slightly disappointed when coming here on a Wednesday. The meatballs and apps were amazing, great menu, but the entrees were fine but not outstanding. Maybe it was an offnight, but 4 of us shared entrees and our pan roasted salmon wasn't cooked perfectly, the chicken was ok and the polenta was kinda salty. I was expecting a lot better from the reviews and the fact that it's one of 7X7's top restaurants but like I said, maybe an off night.
author: Melissa C.

description:
BEST LAMB BURGER!

Not going anywhere else for burgers anymore. I love Lamb, I love burgers, and $10 for a heavenly juicy tasty lamb burger. This is it.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I went in really wanting to love this place.
It was a friends birthday party.  The decor was posh and dim, very nice, upscale, romantic ambiance.
However, the food was very bland. There were 8 people at the table and no one Loved their food.  The saffron cod stew was very plain, the salmon the same and the steak mediocre.  The "mediterranean" spices did NOT work.  The goat cheesecake was just plain weird.
THe bill was $450.
All I can say is for that amount of money, I should be able to Love the food.
author: Laura S.

description:
What a wonderful place!  This is a smaller restaurant, and it also has a banquet room which can accommodate large groups.  I dined there last night in a group of twelve.  The service was excellent, even when two of us were very late.  

The food was excellent - just the right flavor combinations, wonderful dishes, and healthful preparations.  Our party had a variety of different food needs.  There were vegetarians, people who didn't eat fish, folks who could or couldn't handle spicy hot food, and individuals who would not have felt as though they'd had a meal if it hadn't had meat.  The reason this restaurant was selected was because these all could be accommodated.

I had the vegetarian stuffed squash entree (which can be vegan by having them hold the tablespoon of sauce displayed artfully on the plate, but not directly on the food).  It was very tasty, and filling.  I tasted a friend's salmon plate which was also flavorful and rich.  For dessert, the goat cheese cheesecake was more than marvelous, and the panna cotta with fresh fruit melted in our mouths.  I look forward to going back to this restaurant, and to sharing it with others.  

This restaurant is reasonably priced.  It's great for foodies, and good for foodies who also want to watch their wallet.  (If this is you, be prepared to skip the appetizer but go back several times to try their different items!  Or have the appetizers in one visit, and entree another time, maybe stop in for dessert and a drink...  the possibilities just go on.)

I get the impression this would not be a good place for children - I did not see any there.  The restaurant is right off the Bay Bridge (we found street parking within a block) and accessible by BART.
author: Sara F.

description:
Interesting food pairings, seasonal ingredients, lovely presentation, calm, unhurried pace and prompt service.  Plus we had a great Lebanese wine, Chateau Mesaur Hochar, which brought back memories of a trip five years ago.  

There are plenty of choices regardless of your food preferences, e.g., vegetarian, low-fat, etc. and price point.  The starters and sides can be easily shared.

We had the lentil soup, watermelon with ricotta salatta, tomatoes shirazi, sea bass with orchiette & tomatoes, salmon with an Israeli-like couscous (can't remember the Persian equivalent), roasted chicken topped off with "not your grandma's pie" which was a deconstructed lemon meringue pie topped with toasted coconut.  Excellent.

Oh yeah, the absinthe frappe was a nice started to the meal.

Enjoy!
author: Cathy N.

description: First off, I don't give five stars very lightly but this restaurant absolutely deserves it and I am writing this review as I returned to my hotel room. I came with my newborn baby in a stroller and they were very accommodating despite being busy--had no problem taking out a chair for my stroller to be placed at the dinner table. The service was great, the wait staff was friendly, attentive and charming. All that said, I am giving this restaurant 5 stars because of the quality of its food--which is above all, the most important thing to me. I should preface that the night before, I was at a Michelin starred restaurant...and yet, I found Fly Trap to be more deserving. The food was delicious. We ordered the abgoosht (lamb stew), meatballs, short ribs, kashke bademjan and desserts. Every dish was mouth-watering delicious. To add to the experience, the Chef was very personable and inviting--would often come out to engage, which made the restaurant perfectly aligned with Iranian hospitality.
author: Rosa H.

description:
Was just at this place a few weeks ago and I was impressed. Zare @ the Fly Trap felt so welcoming and warm...I loved it! And while homey, it was still rather buji and trendy...in a good way.

Aesthetically, the restaurant is quite busy with the decor. But it works. I find it so adorable that the owner/chef opened his restaurant at this location because it was the first building of the first place he worked when he started his culinary career. How friggin' endearing and sweet is that? So he tried to keep as much of the decor and vibe the same as when he worked there, with some of his own touches. The motifs and vibe is as if you stumbled upon a safari travel trip with royalty. One section your eye is caught on a very Victorian wall lamp, then the next second you see the wilderness camp roman shades that hang from ceiling to floor. Very chill.

Now for the food. We had been looking forward to this dinner date for a while and everyone did their part in reading up on the reviews and checking out the menu. 

We started with drinks. Of the 4 of us I had the Cardamom My Dearest martini...I am a sucker for cardamom anything and so were the rest of the girls at our table. Everyone ended up ordering one for themselves after trying mine. 

A bit after drinks our appetizers made their way out, which consisted of Pistachio Meatballs and Brussels Sprouts. The meatball were definitely full of flavor and accompanied by a honey-pomegranate glaze that was just tangy and sweet enough to highlight the natural flavors of the meat. The sprouts were excellent! 

Then of course, our main courses came out. Around the table there were two lamb shanks and two fillets...both AMAZING! I will say however, that after trying the lamb shank I knew I had to order one for the road to share with the fam when I got home. The lamb shank was by far divine to say the least! It is a MUST TRY when dining here. I don't care if you are a vegetarian...go meat for one day just to experience this meal! It's so worth it! 

We ended the night sharing the Goat Cheese Cheesecake and a Chocolate Delight...both were super delish. But of the two, I've gotta say that the texture and air caught in the cheesecake was magnificent. I could have eaten two on my own...so effin' good!

As for service, our waitress was awesome. She was very helpful, understanding (our orders changed a few times because everything seemed to look so good!), and cheery. Also, the Chef/Owner, Hoss Zare, made frequent trips out of the kitchen to greet people and say hello and thank you for coming to eat there. It was like watching an artist at their gallery opening roaming through the people to see if they loved it or hated it. Good for him...everyone seemed to be more than happy with their food. Also, it was just great to see someone so passionate about the food and the people he is feeding. It also helped that every time we saw him he had a big ass smile on his face.
author: stefany f.

description: Really great service, and incredible food. LOVED the meatballs, and the lamb was incredibly tender.  Really great wine choices, and the dessert, while very experimental (baklava served with espresso sauce & turkish sour cream w/ squid ink), it was seriously good!
author: Anna J.

description: I have a friend in SF who lives only a block from this place, and I was suddenly thinking, wow...isn't she lucky?  I loved it here.  We came in at four pm to make a dinner reservation, and we were lucky enough to get to talk to the owner.  He was so passionate about the history of the place, the art on the walls, the history of the business, and his connection to it.  What a wonderful exchange we had.  The dinner was fantastic.  I will be back every time I visit my friend Alison.
author: Stacya S.

description:
discovered this place by the SF's 38 Essential Restaurants list. 

I wouldn't quite put this on my personal list, but we did enjoy their food quite a lot. (there are just better places for the price or less).

we had:
Pistachio meatballs. - super delicious, please try this.

fig, bacon salad - also great. light and good flavors.

Lamb - it's a huge chunk of lamb.. it was good, but i wasn't necessarily blown away by it.

Scallop - perfectly cooked scallops never serve anyone wrong.. yummy!

baklava - flaky and filled with honey.. just how i like my desserts!
goat cheesecake - definitly one of best cheesecakes i've ever had.. i can't say i know that much, but it was delicious.

crispy brussel sprouts - don't expect something amazing like ones you get from Marlowe's.. not bad, but nothing spectacular.

great service. it was pretty noisy though.. women laughing on the top of their lungs!!
author: Sung C.

description: This review is about the lunch menu. We had lamb wraps for lunch. Most places serve pieces of the lamb. Here the lamb was mixed with vegetable and barely there. The quantity of cilantro to lamb was 1:1 ..  not at all filling from a  lunch perspective. I'm sure their dinner menu  is fairly robust. But from a  lunch standpoint this is really lean and I had to go to a second restaurant to complete my lunch.
author: Vivek C.

description:
I'd rate this place somewhere between a 3 and a 4. I definitely wouldn't bother coming back again though, there are so many other places to try.

The food was pretty good. I got the "yesterday's soup with today's garnish" or whatever it was called... it was a potato leek soup, with creme fraiche and I think sumac and some other spice. The flavor was good, however the soup wasn't pureed enough so I got long stringy things in it.

All the meat we ordered came out way too rare.. There were 3 of us, and we all ordered different types of meat..and all of us got some pretty bloody pieces of meat... yick.. Overall flavors of this restaurant are tasty but the follow through not so great...

The ambiance was nice though..
author: Bon N.

description: Went for dinner with hubby on a Saturday night.  We started with the spiced naan.  It was excellent and very unique.  We ended up getting extra bread because it came with too little for all the dip (we got lavash because they charge extra for naan and I love lavash).  I then had the salad with the feta and heirloom tomato and the eggplant dish as together my main.  The salad was so incredibly fresh and the eggplant was so unique, absolutely delicious.  My hubby had the steak kebab and really liked it.  Great service and ambiance.  Just wish they had more than just one vegetarian entree (which is a spaghetti dish randomly).  Otherwise excellent.
author: Manisha S.

description:
Great food.  Great ambiance (if you are looking for something lively, a little homey, but not too loud).  Service was perfect.

All the dishes we had were excellent and tasty.  The only downside of the entire visit was that they ran out of their nightly special, which was a shame since we wanted to try it.  Nevertheless, what we ordered instead was also delicious.
author: Adam S.

description:
Gorgeous restaurant and wonderful food. Persian influenced cuisine that is truly unique and you can tell the owner has a passion for interesting food that excites the palate. I highly recommend the duck legs dish with barberry and pistachio rice as well as a huckleberry sauce that is to die for. The eggplant appetizer is heavy, but such a great flavor. Not a huge fan of the lavash or sourdough breads, but the olive dip and feta/walnut spread were awesome. Our beet salad was one of the best I've had. 

Such a great date place... will come back!
author: Danielle H.

description:
Another terrific meal last night at Zare at Flytrap. Once again the Pistachio Meatballs, this time even better. For my entree I had the Seabass prepared with a pesto sauce and presented in a bed of orchiette and diced tomatoes. One of the best fish dishes I've had this year.

Parking on the street is a breeze. Service is great. Wine list is fine. Last night the place was about two-thirds full. I don't know why this place isn't packed every night.

4.5 stars
author: Gary C.

description: It just doesn't get much better! Intimate little spot, the food is truly spectacular, the bartender mixes a great Manhattan, the service is professional, yet relaxed and friendly. From the beet salad, the meatball appetizers, to the perfectly cooked wild salmon everything was top quality and packed with flavor, and plated with elegance. The deserts were delightful, and the coffee was magenfreundlich! I will definitely return soon.
author: Geoffrey B.

description: I've now been here three times and have yet to understand what people love about the restaurant.  I like the ambience, the service is good and friendly, the wine selection is good, but the food is really hit or miss.  And if you love foie gras, don't order the foie gras special - only 1/3 of the dish is foie, and even that was cold.
author: Vivian W.

description:
A consistently good meal ... this is our go to place in the neighborhood.  The service is awesome and the food is great!  The salmon was tasty and the lamb was too.  The drinks are also interesting here.. creative.
When we here we spotted Preeti ( Top Chef Contestant ) while having dinner.  
This time it was packed and a little noisy.  But it was still an enjoyable experience.  Keep up the good work.  ;-)
author: Lizete S.

description: Quick review: the appetizers are very good, well deserving of 4 stars.  Cauliflower side is also very good (4 stars).  However, the main course (lamb stew) and desserts are more 3-star level, averaging out to 3.5.  Atmosphere is nice and the service staff is very friendly.
author: Josh Q.

description: I liked this place a lot.  A nice variety of savory appetizers, well prepared meat and veggie entrees, all with good presentation.  Nice atmosphere and helpful staff that will explain the various ethnic dishes if you are not familiar with some of the terms on the menu.
author: Michael S.

description:
I booked a reservation for Zare at Fly Trap, having heard mediocre to great reviews from friends who had eaten there.  I always brushed this establishment off as a restaurant that many visited for business meals, as it is situated between the Financial District and SoMa.  My concerns could not have been more misplaced, as this may be one of the best dining experiences I've had in San Francisco in the past six months.  

There is a cute entryway leading into the busy dining room that gives you the impression that you're entering someone's home - it's cozy and warm.  My friend and I were greeted at the host stand, which is a bit awkwardly placed between the bar and one of the bustling dining rooms.  After being shown to a quieter table in the back dining room, the Maitre D' immediately addressed my notes that I placed in my OpenTable reservation and provided a vegetarian menu without being prompted.  I was instantly impressed.

I ordered a drink, but made a change to the standard preparation.  Not only did it arrive correctly, but I later ordered a second one and it was perfectly prepared without me asking for that same preparation.  Already, I could tell that the bar was on top of their game, in addition to the service.  However, I was interested to learn if the kitchen was in sync.

The menu was not complicated, everything was well priced and the food was fresh and seasonal.  My friend and I both asked our server for recommendations and she adeptly guided us based on our tastes.  Despite the restaurant being packed, our appetizers arrived together five or six minutes after ordering and were hot.  I cannot tell how how many times in recent months I've waited more than a half hour for my appetizer to arrive and it was lukewarm or not prepared correctly.  We both ordered the gnocchi for our entrees (I ordered it without the anchovy) and the server, again, ensured we each had the right plate without asking.  The pillowy gnocchi were made perfectly and did not leave us feeling heavy afterward.  The broccoli rabe in the dish was paired correctly with the seasoning and crunchy roasted garlic garnish.  I'm still dreaming about the flavors dancing in my mouth, as everything worked together so well without being overpowering.

Both my friend and I were blown away by the attentive service throughout the evening.  Our water glasses were always full, plates were promptly removed and both the server and the Maitre D' checked on us on more than one occasion without being intrusive.  The highlight of the evening (beyond the food, that is) was having the head chef visit our table to ensure we enjoyed the meal.  When we raved to him about our experience, he appeared to be genuinely grateful and appreciative that we chose to dine at his restaurant.  A few minutes later, the chef reappeared with a perfectly crisp dessert wine for each of us to pair with our dessert - on the house.  The light dessert wine was the perfect complement to the lime sorbet, toasted coconut, lemon curd and meringue with graham cracker crumbs.  We were beyond ecstatic.

On the way out the door, we were thanked for dining at Zare by each staff member we passed and the chef personally walked us out.  I had missed this on the way in, but he had placed a bowl of sweet Persian lemons by the door for guests to enjoy later as a token of gratitude.  The chef explained that he grew up enjoying these lemons and that they should not be used in a way you would a sour lemon.  The sweetness of these lemons, apparently, should be paired with the right beverage or food item.  My friend and I beamed, holding our sweet lemons, and gleefully recounting some of the highlights of our evening as we left the restaurant.  

It's so rare that I spend the time to write such an extensive review, but Zare at Fly Trap is worth this effort.  The prices are right, the service and food were impeccable and the personal touches made the experience incredibly special.  I've already alerted my husband and several friends that we need to pay Zare at Fly Trap a visit sometime very soon.
author: Rachel P.

description:
I just had dinner here last night. I've heard great things about this place and judging by the menu, description of the food, and even the ambiance as we first walked into the restaurant, it seemed like a solid choice. I'm sad to say that I walked away pretty disappointed.

We ordered the following: 

APPETIZERS
- Smoked Salmon w/ Cucumber Relish 
Four spoons topped with a tiny cut of smoked salmon over a cucumber relish which was really overpowering. We barely ate any of the relish.

- Arincini - Saffron Risotto Balls w/ Spicy Marinara 
The Arincini was super crispy... maybe a little too crispy? I didn't sense any saffron by sight (color) or taste, but that didn't bother me. It wasn't great, but it was good for the price ($5). 

- Pistachio Meatballs w/ Harissa Honey Pomegranite Glaze
The meatballs were good, but the pomegranite glaze was waaay too sweet.  I didn't want to eat the parts of my meatball that had touched the sauce.  It was really that sweet.

SIDE
- Marinated Chickpeas w/ Eggplants, Parsley, Barberries, & Pine Nuts
Simple, but good.  I didn't taste any eggplant, but I do recall some square-shaped black or dark purple specks, so maybe that was the eggplant skin?

ENTREES
- Ghormeh sabzi - Short Ribs over Fresh Herb Stew w/ Basmati Rice and Preserved Lemon
I didn't like this at all and I LOVE short ribs. What they actually serve is a single-bone short rib, so the plural "ribs" on the menu is deceiving.  That being said, the single rib I got was a nice size, so I have no complaints about portion size.  Sadly, the meat wasn't very juicy.  It fell off the bone, but the meat wasn't tender.  I know that sounds contradicting, but it somehow seemed dry.  Maybe it was sitting out awhile or sitting under a heat lamp.  Not good.  The meat was one thing, but the herb stew was was another.  It was really off-putting to me.  There was a single ingredient in there that was extremely overpowering.  It almost tasted like a bitter plant.  I'm not sure what it was... maybe that's what preserved lemon tastes like??  I just had a very hard time with it.

- Lamb Shank Abgusht w/ Black-eyed Beans & Fingerling Potatoes
I think the lamb shank is supposed to be the dish to get here, but it was just okay.  This was not my dish, but I was able to have several good tastes of it.  It seemed to be lacking in flavor, slightly bland.  It wasn't bad, but it didn't wow at all. 

DESSERT
- Fried Milk Torijas
This totally reminded me of the french toast sticks at Jack-in-the-Box.  It came w/ a small side of hot cocoa to dip them in.  It was pretty good, but I can get the same from Jack.

Ultimately, the entire food experience was pretty mediocre. Most of the dishes seemed to have a single overwhelming ingredient or something just seemed missing or off.  

The herb stew is something I would never ever order again... it was not my taste at all.  I can't imagine that I'm the only one who would feel this way about it.  I'm starting to wonder if I just got a very very bad dish or a rotten lemon or something...  

Lastly, the service was pretty good at first, but after our entrees were delivered, our server disappeared on us -- service became nearly non-existant which put another damper on the meal.  Our dessert order was taken by Zare himself when I think he noticed that we were desperately trying to get some attention.

These are just my own personal opinions and it appears many have had difference experiences here.  Maybe we just ended up there on an off night.  Even so, I'm not sure that I'd try it again.
author: J L.

description:
I went to Zaré for my birthday dinner last week. What lured me in was the goat cheese cheesecake I saw on the dessert menu. I don't eat much cheesecake, but goat cheese is the best food on earth. It delivered as promised, but if you're not a whore for goat cheese like I am you'll probably find it pretty ordinary.

Working backwards, for my entree I ordered a seafood stew that I don't see on Zaré's online menu. It wasn't so much a stew as it was a seafood medley with a bit of flavorful tomato broth. My friends ordered black cod with fresh herb stew and filet mignon, which were also good.

My third friend ordered the "spice-roasted bone marrow" appetizer as her main course. I reluctantly tried it and was not very impressed. But I won't blame Zaré's for that since I'm a bone marrow newbie. However, the friend who ordered it said it was not as good as others she had tried in the past.

We also ordered a side of french fries with saffron aioli. The fries were good and the saffron aioli was great. It was a large side dish, so plan on sharing it. 

Zaré also has some interesting cocktails. We tried the "cardamom my dearest" with gin, cardamom and lime, the anar daiquiri with run, acai, pomegranate and pistachio, and a martini that I don't see on the online menu.
author: Adam B.

description: Amazing food and drinks...bone marrow was delicious, fusion drinks are superb, fusion Persian food combined with tasteful presentation...how great it can get!
author: Parmis A.

description:
Do you have a "that" place? You know? That drinking hole, greasy spoon or whathaveyou where you feel like you and only a handful of folks are aware of...Well, Fly Trap is that place for me...

This was the first restaurant that I had dinner by myself in when I first moved to SF a little over a year ago. First, I fell in love with the bartender..and if you're reading this..you know who you are...Second, I fell in love with said 'tenders libations..and Third, the food..oh..and Fourth..the ambiance..and well..You get the 'dearoni..

It's a jewel-box of a restaurant that recently changed it's name..only slightly..Re-vamped the menu. Put a fresh coat of paint on the bar and VOILA~ ZARE at Fly Trap...The menu has a very Med-focus with a California aesthetic and eye to detail. Especially the DESSERTS!!! Holy Dog Mother! I could make babies with her desserts!

Should you ever find yourself here..look toward the bar and if there's a man flayling his hands in a very fey manner..That's probably me and I'm more than likely three drinks in and in need of food..So, saddle up and let's share that Lamb Shank.......oh..and some dessert, too!
author: Roger D.

description: Had the pistachio meatballs (very good) and the trout/cucumber salad (a play on fettuccine alfredo, IMO - cucumber cut like fettuccine, creme freche dill sauce, smoked cold trout pieces) which was awesome.  Great bartender - she made a mean Sazerac.
author: Ryan J.

description:
Fabulous, rich decor with excellent, flavorful food. You can't ask for too much more than that. Oh, well add on great service then too!

Pistachio crusted meatballs, braised italian eggplant, roasted beet salad- mwah!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Ladies and Gentlemen, this is how it is done. Chef Hoss Zaré and team make an already amazing meal and make it feel like an amazing event to which you have been personally invited. The warmth of Chef, himself, is felt throughout the house as he makes his front of house rounds to make sure all are taken care of.

The space is just perfect with being big enough to host an assortment of seating styles (family tables, bar tables, dining tables), to a flowing decor and smooth lighting. The space allows for a lively buzz of excited patrons, but does not drown out your enjoyment or experience. 

But enough of that... let's talk about the food! 

We started with the pistachio meatballs in the honey pomegranate glaze.  At the first bite, I slowed down to savor the following, to let the taste of the grass fed beef combine with an exquisitely complimentary glaze. Happily, Zaré came to the table and let us know that it was perfectly acceptable to dip our bread into the remaining sauce and wipe it up clean. Not wanting to be rude, I immediately obliged. Repeatedly. 

Coming in right after the meatballs, the crispy polenta with a smattering of ratatouille. The delicate outside crispiness of the polenta with a fine and warming center was the perfect stage to dollop a divvy of the fresh-made ratatouille right on top. Om nom nom... they were gone but not forgotten. 

The entreés came in at perfect timing: The grilled moroccan-style wild salmon,  the risotto with pineapple, the fulton valley half chicken, and the lamb shank abgusht.

Where do I start? Let's start with my dish. 

I had the lamb shank. A beautifully prepared slow cooked lamb shank with impeccable flavor and texture, yet delicate enough to come completely off the bone so every last noshy bit could be coddled and savored with a dime's worth of torshi. Without a hit of gameness, and just enough fat to ensure the proper pinnacle of flavoring, my first  thought of DEAR SWEET LOVE OF GOD THIS IS CRAZY AWESOME almost blurted from my mouth, but took on a more primal moan of gratitude as my eyes rolled to the back of my head. Thankfully that moment was not totally vocalized and I continued to savor the reality in front of me. 

My attention then turned to the risotto. I am a huge fan of risotto, and am in awe of anyone that can accomplish risotto that knocks the socks off of you. Zaré's risotto takes everything you expect in such a magnificent dish and then amplifies the beauty of the flavor with an unexpected dousing of pineapple. The deliciousness of the mouthful can only be described as climatic NC-17 moment of sensual pleasure.

Saving room for desert, a yummy delight was the torrijas served with a hot chocolate dip with essence  of rose water.  AMAZINGLY fun and again, an  engaging flavor you want to turn back and go, "I had no idea! I want more!"

But.. for the other dish, we had something I can hardly find the approprate words for. It was the Greek yogurt drizzled with honey and I believe panna cotta. Whatever the official title of this heaven sent dish was, i didn't care, I simply wanted another spoonful. [Update: Greek Yogurt Panna Cotta with Truffle Honey. Yes, it is an addictive substance!] I was reckless, tuning out the whole world and I loved being lost in each bite that melted away like a light dusting of snow flavored with happiness. 

I was having a religious moment at every turn as every taste bud in my mouth was being caressed by all these fantastically prepared flavors exploding in an orgasmic symphony of salivating bliss. 

What the world needs now is that rediscovery of what can bring you  bliss. If it is food we must start with, so be it. One mustn't settle for mediocrity and industry-churned filler, one has to really embrace the vibrancy of the entire cornucopia that is literally at your fingertips.  I can definitely tell you that it is a guarantee that myself, my friends and strangers alike will hear of Zaré at Fly Trap and will find what I found, and there will be happiness, and I, we and they will be back.
author: Dave S.

description: A friend took me here for my birthday dinner last year.  The decor and ambiance are simply impeccable.  Service was genteel, which is exactly what I want from a classy restaurant.  We began with the pistachio meatballs (harissa, ftw!) and soup, then went on to masticate the crispy brussel sprouts and mixed olives.  We decided to stick with small dishes so that we could try more things and hence, eat more.  Overall, just a really eclectic and fantastic place to eat if you've got the dough.
author: Lily E.

description:
I am certainly a lucky person this week; a variety of visiting friends are insisting on taking me out to eat so I will have lots of reports this week...

Monday's adventure was (finally) experiencing Zare's Monday Meatball Madness with the Divine Miss Spieler. We got to experience a variety of tastes before the meatball arrived, including several appetizers;

Smoked trout on cucumber "linguini' with dilled creme fraiche. This was an early favorite, both Miss S and I adoring the coolness of the dressing with the smoked fish and lovely cucumber strips (we are both cucumber fans).

The "pistachio meatball" is a small appetizer but with a huge taste; a harrisa/honey/pomegranate glaze which is just divine in its sticky sweet-spiceness. 

The cinnamon-braised lamb's tongue with apple chutney and chestnuts. God, I love this dish.... Perfectly tender tongue and the flavors of fruit and spice juxtaposes what becomes umami in the chestnuts. Lovely.

Spice-roasted marrow bones served with bergamot preserves, Persian baby pickles, fresh greens and toast. You know, Bix's marrow bones used to be my favorite, but these have surpassed that. The spice is very subtle and the bergamot preserves, which could be sickly sweet is just a great, clean taste that helps cleanse the palate to the Persian pickle which has quite a bite.

One entrée we shared was the Moroccan-spiced Salmon with toasted fregola, seasonal vegetables, and cucumber raita. Again, the brightness of cucumber and dill complemented the ras al hanout compote with some of the best Salmon I've had in ages. I admit to saving a rather large portion of this to have for breakfast the next day and was not disappointed.

Then there was The Meatball. Six- or eight-inches in diameter, ours was stuffed with two small lamb chops. Barely swimming in a light broth, the meatball was surrounded with a few slices of oven-roasted tomatoes and wild mushrooms. The Meatball had pinenuts, spices, and was so tender and flavorful. There was obviously going to be leftovers and the neighboring table advised eating it cold, on a sandwich. They were right.

Two desserts were shared; a goat-cheese cheesecake and ..... wait for it ..... Fried Dough! Hoorah! Sing praises to the heavens.... What are called "fried milk torrijas" these long, rectangle delights might be the second best hunk of fried dough I've found in the city (Piperade's is a nudge higher on my Fried Dough Scale of ecstasy, but not by much).

What a grand night -- and what encouragement for me to get there more often.
author: Carolyn T.

description: This was the first time dining at this restaurant and definitely won't be the last time. The food was completely unique, and completely delicious. We started with the spiced naan and amazing fattoush salad; then a spaghetti squash (special) and salmon for our entrees, a side of French fries with delicious saffron aioli, and finally the tangy faloudeh for the dessert. Everything was seasoned impeccably and just the right portion. They also have a wonderful selection of unique cocktails which we really enjoyed. Finally our waiter was Tim and the service was phenomenal. How had we never heard of this outstanding restaurant?
author: Richard T.

description: Came here with a date and was pleasantly surprised but also a little disappointed. The size and ambience was really nice. Super romantic actually, even though that wasn't my intention haha. The service was superb and never intrusive. The only problem my date had was that all her food seemed to lack seasoning, or rather salt. Nooo salt!  It's like the chef was "afraid of sodium" as she put it. I tasted it and this was in fact true. Overall a good dinner, but 3 stars because she wasn't so happy.
author: Sebastien M.

description: I'll admit that I had only two items and that one of them was quite tasty. The blood orange salad was a gloppy mess. This combination (arugula, fennel, leeks, mint, cilantro, manouri cheese, walnut oil and pomegranate dressing) should be refreshing.  Instead it was a mushy unappetizing mess.  The salad was so disappointing that it overshadowed the eggplant appetizer, which had great flavors. The room was extremely loud. The service was very good.
author: Kirsten N.

description: Yes! Okay, so I came here a couple years ago but never wrote a review. Crazy, because this place is sooo good. I had my first fresh berry muddled cocktail here, with lots-o-berrys...it was really amazing. I will have to go back because I don't remember what I ate for dinner, except that I nearly had an "O" moment from when Harry Met Sally. It was that good. Review update to come soon :)!
author: Shira O.

description: Went here with friends before the cirque show and it was a fantastic meal. Ambiance is dark and swanky And romantic for a date. even with the holiday party that was going on front of house, it was quiet for conversation. Food was delicious, had the salmon with lentils. Not a dish to be missed. The owner brought us some sautéed greens that were flavorful and perfect for sharing. The staff there is very friendly, the drinks are original and very good and I would definitely go back
author: Jennifer O.

description: Nice atmosphere, friendly service and hit or miss food.  The smoked trout and eggplant apps were both just ok.  The lamb was also ok.  The dolmeh was the most interesting part of the meal, but even that dish wasn't particularly outstanding.  The baklava was tasty and lighter than the versions typically encountered.  The wine, a Turkish selection recommended by the sommelier, fell short compared to it's California counterparts.  I don't think I'd come back here for dinner again, but would try the happy hour.
author: melita s.

description: Had a great quick stop at Zare the other day.  As part of my quest to complete the 7x7 list, my wife and I sat at the bar and had a couple drinks and a couple snacks, including the pistachio meatballs.  The meatballs were tender and delicious, and I really liked the pomegranate reduction.  We also had the lamb burger.  The meat of the burger was cooked to a perfect medium rare, and the lambiness was not hidden or covered up by gratuitous spices or anything like that.  I could used a little something more on the burger -- maybe a sauce, or a cheese, or a spread -- but the meat itself was great.  I also really enjoyed my "Minted Memory" cocktail, which was like a cross between a gin mojito and a pimm's cup -- very refreshing.  I can definitely see myself going back there to try a couple more small plates and a couple more cocktails in the future.
author: Pilan C.

description:
OMG , My Husband and I went to Zare the other night for the first time , as soon as we walked in , I was in love with the positive energy and warm hospitality , food was excellent and you dont feel youare actually eating in a restaurant , because food was home made and way too delicious and yummy , plus Hoss ( the Chef ) has a wonderful personality , he hangs out with everyone in his restaurant , I noticed people not only go there for food , but also for him ,  I know I will be going there all the time and I am gonne take all my guests there too , love u guys , u all are awesome 
L.B
author: leila b.

description:
After meaning to go for months, finally went the other night.  I really, really should have gone sooner.

Went with a friend from out of town, and we got the crispy polenta and beef kebab apps, and the roasted duck and lamb burger for mains.  All were outstanding, and the mains very reasonable priced (22 and 14 respectively).

One of the really noteworthy things about the wine menu is that they feature a handful of wines from Middle-East.  We ordered one from Israel -- a Cab/Merlot/Syrah blend -- that was surprisingly good!

Note to (potential) customers: While the back room is cozy and perfect for having a quiet conversation, note that when it's full, it gets really warm in there.

Note to the restaurant: I would consider it a personal favor if you would open on Sundays!
author: Maneesh B.

description: Great food, excellent ambiance and friendly staff!  The food was unbelievably good and the coffee was amazing!  Also had wine that is aged in clay pots under ground...so good and reasonably priced.
author: Heather W.

description:
This is a very old school SF restaurant that has been repurposed as a fine dining Persian / generic Mediterranean establishment.

All I can say is meatball Mondays, it brings new meaning to meatball.  Damn, it's the size of a softball, a shell of lamb and pork with pine nuts, and it has a rack of lamb inside, it's like the new turduckenmeatball.  Plus, seriously tasty.  Memorable.

There is no free bread but they have some kind of pita with dip thing for $4 that is quite good.
author: Gil S.

description: 7x7 seriously??? I hope the pistachio meatballs were at the bottom of your list, because if they weren't, I'm not going to bother trying to get through the rest of it. They were pretty uninteresting, pasty and cold, the smoked trout was barely discernable in a sea of cucumber noodles, and mushroom cake was blaaaaand. Thank goodness the decent atmosphere and good service distract from (or perhaps elevates) some otherwise middlin' food at best.
author: Snuffles B.

description: Zare was an excellent dining experience. The ambiance is vibrant and unique. The food is delicious, locally sourced if possible, and unique also. The wine list is mostly French, Spanish, and Portuguese. I recommend the Tiara from Portugal if you like a heavier chardonnay. The service was great too. The prices are on par with quality and quantity, which many places in the city seem to be having trouble with lately. They also have an excellent cocktail list. Fun, fun place!
author: Julie H.

description:
Talk about a mixed review:

Service: 4 stars
Maitre d' was attentive when I walked in the door, busboy very sweet, and waiter attentive without being in our faces but... (see below)

Food: 3 stars
My friend and I split everything and, although our palettes are very different, we agreed upon the food.

First course:
Beets with goat cheese was pleasant enough but kinda blah. The beets weren't dressed and the salad in the center of the plate was overdressed. Per our waiters recommendation, the fries we had ordered accompanied this... not a good combo as they would of been better with our main.

Second course:
Once again, the eating order was off... 
The liver (foie gras, sheep & chicken combo) would of been better matched with our beets then with our main (our waiters recommendation again on pairing). That said, the foie gras and chicken lovely but sheep a bit gamey. Our salmon main was nicely cooked and the side sauces quite brilliant, but the bulgar (I think that's what it was!) bed was bland; the menu listed this as coming with blue lake green beans but they weren't on our plate.

Third course:
Biscuit with honey, cream cheese and pineapple that was totally mismatched, heavy and overwhelmed by the sweetness of the honey. Two dessert lovers didn't even eat half, which is not a good thing.

Overall, it was a pleasant enough evening but for the price, there are many other places that would be first on my list based upon the food alone.
author: Missy D.

description: A wonderful meal. At the risk of sounding "Top Chef"ee, the menu was filled with delightful surprises. Food that makes you think "I never thought of these items together but my world is being rocked". Perhaps I'm biased... I had the best dessert of my life here. Wonderful!
author: Diane C.

description:
The first moment I stepped inside, I noticed the restaurant's charming vibe. The waiters are friendly and energetic. The decor retains its original charm -- from the original sconces to the original wall paper and the gold-leaved moulding. As the evening wound down, we also saw Zare himself out and about greeting guests. 

I've been a fan of Zare for almost decade; my first Zare dining experience was in his restaurant on Sacramento Street in 2000. Zare ran his restaurant there much as he does this new location at FlyTrap -- with friendliness and flare. I'm glad he still does his bone-in spare rib (my favorite). 

And I'm glad that Zare is back in SF!
author: Patty W.

description: Beginning at the beginning: cocktails as good as any I've had in the city (as good as Alembic on their best night, and better than any I've ever had at Nopa).  The "Cardamom My Dearest" is a kind of perfection, as close as I'm ever going to get to being a British viceroy during the Raj with quite possibly the greatest and most refreshing gin drink I've ever had.  My friend called the "Agave Daisy" the best "margarita-like thing" he'd ever had, and I haven't even talked yet about the "Anar Daiquiri," which would have won best drink of 2008, hands down, were it not for the other aforementioned.  And I haven't even mentiioned the food yet! (This review was a draft from my first visit -- I've been back many times since, and love that this remains bizarrely under the radar for how great a spot it is. Hoss is a perpetrator of constant delight.)
author: daniel n.

description:
ok ok ok ok ..... before i lose the thought train, let's unpack what just happened here......

new year's eve eve and looking for a place to tuck into some "it's almost new year" i don't have to cook goodness. and bless me Fly Trap is just the place for that. made last minute rezzie and got a good table for two then showed up at the appointed hour and felt as is swept into our own little corner of heaven. very cold, very dry martinis were soon followed by scrumptious ravioli (her) and centering comforting squash soup (me). having dined here  many times i know the entire appetizer menu is solid, but these are certainly faves. 

we then made quick detour into couscous and crab salad (one portion divided by two more than enough for an interstitial)  before settling into the "team meat" and "team fish" battling mains: lamb shank vs grilled salmon. confused the server (not the same waiter who took the order but, overall, no service issues today) who landed the lamb in front of me and beached the salmon in front of her. "err, ummm, she's the real carnivore", says i and plates get cheerfully swapped round. and then the true tucking in begins..... ohhhhhhhhhhhhh myyyyyyyy.......................... and that's the reaction to the shank. imposing yet inviting, stunning yet sublime.... and all that happening on the other side of the table. on my end, omega 3 heavy mr salmon lay abject across an understanding array of legume and pasta and when flayed by my fork delivered a flavorful burst of rich excitement and i no longer felt cheated for not ordering the lamb myself.

silence ensued and all was good. very good.

at ceremony's end we did take a flyer and inquire as to our waiter's suggestions for dessert, though neither of us had the room or inclination to actually dive into that particular sin bin. but on the word of our dinner pilot, "the chocolate and the cheesecake"  we had to take courage and order forth though survival was indeed in question. but survive we did and oh so the better for the experience. words cannot describe but the smug arguing after should indicate: she sure she had the best with the chocolate mousse, me convinced she was wrong and nothing could be better than the goat cheese cheesecake.

if you do not do a fly by to the Fly Trap all i can say is you are missing a serious meal. in very welcoming surroundings and convivial atmosphere. we'll miss you.
author: S L.

description: A friend and I made reservations for a Friday night and it was pretty packed which seemed like a good sign (along with all of the reviews on yelp).  We're both vegetarian so our options were limited, and the menu set before us wasn't the one I read online.  But, there were still options for us -  we got the tomato soup (it was chilled and good) and a salad (ok - not too amazing).  We also got the one veggie entree which I thought was okay as well.  While the dishes were all plated great, for the steep cost, I didn't think the food was too mind blowing.  Not sure I'd go again...
author: Rachana S.

description:
I live near this restaurant and am so happy I finally went in for dinner.  The staff is so friendly and kind.  They make you feel right at home.  

The food - wow nice menu and amazing flavors.  I would highly recommend this restaurant to everyone.  A must restaurant!
author: Richard J.

description: We arrive 10 minutes late on a very busy Friday night and were seated promptly. They were so busy and apparently down on waiters, that we waited quite a bit between contacts with the staff. The staff though, is friendly and accomodating once we got their attention. The food is excellent, fresh and well prepared. We had the mushroom cake appetizer and the autumn salad, which were both excellent. The salmon and escolar were also both good, but the bitterness of the side dishes with the escolar were not for our taste. The environment is very energetic. Drinks and wine were also excellent. Will repeat.
author: Ahvie H.

description:
My new favorite restaurant.  Every single one of the dishes we ordered was fantastic, the service was wonderful, and the owner, Hoss, was very outgoing and kind.  He puts everything into his restaurant and the love really comes across when you're eating the food.  The only downer was that I didn't have any room left for dessert!  Everything is very fresh, light, and well presented.  We ordered nearly half of the menu, wine, cocktails and were out for under $150.

Note: They take very good care of vegetarians here and have an entire menu devoted to that diet.  My family is Persian and they eat a lot of meat in that culture so my hat goes off to Hoss for creating a menu that incorporates a vegetarians needs into it!

I will be coming back very soon and bringing my friends this time.
author: Cameron A.

description:
Unacceptable.  

The bartender was the one bright spot.  Personable and knowledgeable.  Sadly, the rest of our experience here did not come close.  

Food quality: Inconsistent at best.   
Starter: crab salad (really, crab morsels over couscous).  Relatively generous portion; flavors could be stronger.  

Entree: "Filet mignon." I asked for mine rare (the server did not ask others at my table how they wanted their steak done).  It was certainly tender, but was also rather bland.  The medjool date they threw on top of the meat was better flavored but felt more like an attempt at a Mediterranean twist than an actual complement to the steak's (lack of) taste.  The scalloped potatoes were a disappointment as well - undercooked and, again, lacking flavor.   

Dessert: horrible. "Not your grandmother's pie."  No grandmother would ever want to take credit for this abomination.  In an attempt to play to recent modern dining trends, Zare has "deconstructed" a pie: the individual whipped cream, meringue and graham cracker crust components were slathered unappealingly onto a plate, along with a miniscule helping of sorbet.  This is unfortunate, because the sorbet was the only thing I ate that night that had any semblance of actually tasting good.  The rest of the 'pie had a slimy consistency.  



Service:  Ridiculous. We were not given enough bread for everyone in our party, and when we asked for more were told that 'bread service was extra.' Fine - few restaurants nickel and dime this way on top of a ~$100 per head bill, but we move on.  It was our interaction with the manager that bordered on the absurd.  Ryan was petulant, defensive, self-contradictory and downright rude when we asked (politely - voices were never raised) why we were charged for an extra meal that was never brought.  His answers ranged from telling us that we "should be grateful because we were hooked up with the back room" (something we never asked for, nor did we really want because it meant breaking our group into two parties), telling us that the "kitchen is closed" (there were still people coming into the restaurant as we were leaving), to accusing us of being drunk (nope).  

We did not let this experience ruin our night, but this is a restaurant to be avoided.
author: Sai-Kit C.

description:
Very friendly service.

I started off with some lavash. For the main course I had the single bone short rib. OMG, melt-in-your-mouth. It was tender, juicy and extremely flavorful.  The Risotto Milanese complemented the meat very well. Nice touch. Paired my meal with a 2002 Lebanon Chateau Musar "Hochar".

Their portions are huge, so I had no space for trying their interesting-sounding desserts.

Definitely going back.
author: Premshree P.

description: The night I ate there I was sure no one else in San Francisco were eating better than I. Try to try everything. Among their cocktails, Persian Breakfast and Minted Memory are a must try as they are phenomenal. The bone marrow dish is out of this world. Make sure you call at least a week in advance.
author: Ramoun M.

description:
My co-workers and I came to Zare at Fly Trap for lunch. The lunch menu must be new since Fly Trap usually only serve dinner. The 3 of us reviewed the menu online before hand and we really like what they offer for lunch. On their simple lunch menu, they have 4 kinds of salad of different protein: grilled salmon, grilled skirt steak or chicken. Each kind of salad comes with some kind of grains like lentils or bulgur. They also have soup and wraps, which also looks very good. The wraps come with the same type of protein choices. For today, we opted to go with the salad so each of us picked our protein of choice. Mine was the grilled salmon. 

When my dish arrived, it was served on a delicate platter with the black pearl lentil with some greens served cold on one side and next to it my grilled fillet of salmon topped with tomatoes, basils and chopped red onions salsa. My salmon was seasoned and grilled perfectly. The lentils were really tender and have a nice hit of citrus flavor. It was really refreshing and a great combo with the rich and fatty salmon. My co-worker grilled skirt steak look so juicy and hers came with the bulgur salad. Our other co-worker had the grilled chicken and she said her chicken was really moist and flavorful. We also ordered a side of French Fries to share and it came with ketchup and homemade saffron aioli for dipping. The light yellowish colored saffron aioli was so pungent with the smell of saffron. At the end of the meal, we shared a Goat Cheese Cheesecake that was so decadent, fluffy, light, creamy and had a great taste of the tanginess from the goat cheese. It was a really unusual cheesecake.  

At first look at our lunch plates, the 3 of us thought the portion was on the smaller side, but as we enjoyed our lunch, we didn't feel that it was lack of food at all. In fact, after the meal, we all agreed that we felt full and satisfied. I think it was because the dishes were packed with so much flavors and the ingredients they use were so fresh and you could taste everything, which leaves us feeling satisfied without feeling stuffed, heavy and kick us into a food coma. 

I feel that the portion of lunch dishes they served at Fly Trap is ideal diet and should be adopted by everyone in the country. If all the people in America eat the portion they serve at Fly Trap for every meal and do more physical activities like 20 minutes of workout every day, walk more instead of driving everywhere, I dare to say our country won't have such a high number of people with obesity and other diseases like diabetes, heart disease, hypertension and such. 

Overall, a job well done to Fly Trap for serving lunch at an affordable price so that I have a new place to go eat during work days. Also a pad on the shoulder for serving healthy, flavorful dishes at the RIGHT portion so that we can indulge without compromising our health and waistline. Yes, I will be back and will recommend to everyone I know.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
I love this place, I had my birthday dinner here, last weekend. The food was great, service was good .Very nicely decorated to give it a comfortable, cozy and elegant atmosphere nice to see the Chef plus owner was walk around taking care of the customers. 
Foie gras was so good which is my favorite. The cocktail pretty strong, and I don't really like the flavor of it, it tasted weird.
author: christy l.

description:
I used to eat at Zaré all the time when it was on Haight.  I ate at Fly Trap once or twice.  I always thought the former was a good value, and the latter was not all that.

Now that the former restaurant is in the latter location . . . I give it the big thumbs up.  They really didn't change the decor at all that I could tell, but the menu is completely new.  The wine list is stellar.  The Menage a Foie was wonderful.  The kobe beef cheek penne were lovely.  The octopus/squid salad was fantastic.  The lamb burger was good.  The chocolate dessert was decent enough.  The service was competent - not amazing, but no complaints.  All that and 4 glasses of wine for $130 - I can't say it's a great value, but it's definitely not over-priced for what it is.  In sum - I'd go back. 

[For those who care - easy parking - good place for a date - full bar]
author: Joe C.

description:
Monday night meatballs!  These things are phenomenal and must be the size of a baby's head.  My boyfriend and I shared a meatball and were both pleasantly full afterward.  You never know what the meatball the be until just before dinner so call ahead if it really matters, ours was ground beef and lamb with a yummy quail center.

And if you don't want the giant dinner meatball you should try the pistachio meatballs w/harissa-honey-pomegranate glaze.  My guy liked these even more than the dinner ball.  Amazing!
author: Shauna R.

description:
Who would figure that a place called The Fly Trap would actually not be some divey bar..have good food AND be in an old historical SF building to boot??? Not us. So we had to try it when we found it on Yelp nearby to a bar we were going to afterwards for a bday party.

Definitely an old-school-style kind of restaurant, all posh and plush and dark wood inside, very historical building...though not sure why the bathrooms are on the 2nd floor as you walk through what feels like an office building connection from the 1970's that has never been remodeled...but I digress.

Food was very good, typical American with a little flair...pianist with a mini-skirted swaying singer, old-fashioned good service. Roses on the table, they will also toss rose petals if you want I guess...we weren't quite that romantic.

Love the old historical black and whites lining the walls and the overall unrushed feel of the dining room. But they don't take forever to serve you which is good because I'm typically starving. We had a few drinks, some pasta and salads. Not bad at all.

Don't let the crazy name put you off, the Fly Trap is worth a visit if you want some old-SF.
author: Mara T.

description:
Great restaurant!  Very nicely decorated to give it a comfortable and elegant atmosphere.  They have some interesting cocktails on the menu, but you can also get some more traditional ones.  

Food was quite tasty.  I had the butter salad - pretty basic, but the mustard vinaigrette livened it up a bit.  The special risotto dish was so good - creamy and perfect.  We also loved the french fries with saffron aioli.  Profiteroles for dessert were outstanding.  Overall a really nice place in SOMA!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Zare at Fly Trap has three great things going for it --- and, for each of which, I award it a well-earned star:  (1) Great drinks: and, with a touch of cardamom no less, probably the best gimlet I've had in over a year; (2) Really perfect ambiance, cool but not overstuffy; and (3) Really, ridiculously good service --- the kind of service so perfectly tailored to the surroundings (attentive but not formal, comfortable but serious) that just ruins you, forever, for places with a more lackluster staff.

The food, however, doesn't blow me away; everything looks other-worldly, and then ends up fairly unsurprising.  In a town full of surprises and deliciousness, I suppose that's fairly damning---but, for all the reasons noted above, I am nevertheless certain to be back, albeit perhaps drinking more and eating less.
author: Ashley A.

description: Great space, and the food was interesting and inventive. If you want to try something new with friendly, helpful staff in a really vibrant environment not to mention delicious food, go for it!
author: Luke P.

description:
The menu was very creative --i had a hard time deciding what to order but was blown away by both dishes I had: smoked trout salad with cucumber "linguine," trout roe and dill creme fraiche; and braised duck legs with basmati rice, almonds, barberries and candied citrus. Amazing.

I had a signature "Fly Trap Martini," which was good but not impressive. We skipped dessert and after-dinner drinks.
author: John Z.

description: Let me start by saying this is a casual restaurant with a high ceiling and no sound absorbers.  So we had a decent meal, the food is pretty good, but with a party of seven, we were asked to be quiet repeatedly!  I want to have a good time and be able to laugh with friends.  They moved us once, which we graciously obliged, and then they asked us to leave "because of the customers."  Honestly, don't ever go here with a group.  Very unfriendly owner and life is too short.  This is not a fine dining experience.  I don't know how they think they are kidding. Mean people don't get my customer support.
author: Taylor T.

description:
Took my Husband to celebrate a promotion.

Great find. Lovely atmosphere and the staff were very friendly and informative.

We told them we were veggie and they quickly came back with a vegetarian menu that had much more options than most places - but could use one more entree.

Food was delicious with good Mediterranean flavors.

The cuisine is all over Mediterranean and does not stick to one region - yet everything worked nicely together.

Great place for a nice romantic dinner.
author: Maya z.

description: The dishes here are not just delicious, they're a piece of art. The chef really puts his heart into it. I had many of the dishes and I was always very satisfied with the quality. The staff are very kind and professional. The service is flawless. The chef himself, Hoss Zare, is a great guy, very friendly and humble. And he always has new yummy surprises for his customers.
author: Haleh H.

description: The food was good here... Service was descent. Pricey though, especially if you order off the menu because of dietary restrictions (vegan; not me)!
author: Scott H.

description:
I don't really remember much about my drinking experience here (translation - that means it was a GREAT NIGHT!) other than they gave me a glass of Pinot and easily, it was equally to 3 glasses.  Score!  I have eaten at the original Flytrap for lunch before, this is another perk of working around the corner from this place.  The food I had was great - I had a burger and it was on a French Roll, very filling and tasty.  Flytrap is actually pretty small.  The bar is even smaller, not much room to move, but it's got a great happy hour vibe and even though we weren't ordering food I DO remember the wait staff asking us if we were okay, if we needed anything, etc.

I did have some sips of other drinks and from what I remember of those, they were quite tasty.  Definitely want to come back here again to sample more of the food.
author: Sonya T.

description:
What a treat.. this restaurant is wonderful..
Came here for valentine's day.. everything was cooked to excellence.. the wine was great with the scallop and short rib.. the restaurant is adorable, the staff are uber-friendly..
plus Hass gave all the ladies a wonderful gift bag with wine and treats..
I look forward to coming to SF so I can have a great meal and wine at Fly trap!
author: Nasim R.

description:
Sexy, sophisticated, modern yet old school charm.  Beautiful blonde (Russian?) hostesses welcome you in, even if you're there 10 minutes before they actually open.
I can only testify to the drinks (cocktails and beer) which are fab, as was the service.  The menu was an interesting and worldly blend of French, Italian, Mediterranean and Californian. 
I will most certainly be back to take advantage of the happy hour specials, if not a full meal.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
It is rare that a dinning experience is perfect on all levels. 

We tried a choice of appetizers and a sea food entree for her and a meat entree for me.

The food was truly amazing. I go out of my way to find unique takes on existing favorites and Zare did not disappoint.

We showed up as 2, but then ran into 4 of our friends and were later joined by 2 friends. The staff did not blink at the change and the service was really excellent. I come from Toronto, and the service in S.F. has always been adequate to good. This is one of the few dinning experiences I've had where the service has been flawless.

I want to go back and try the rest of the menu.
author: A F.

description: Been back about 10 times since I wrote my first post and guess what, it's still ridiculously awesome!  If you go, you'll see the owner/chef cruising the tables, try to nab him and ask him to tell you the story of how he came to own the restaurant, it's an amazing story!
author: Zubin I.

description:
I came here last night for my mom's b-day dinner, and the place is likeable, but not great. Here's a list of what we ordered and how it all tasted:

Pistachio Meatballs - tasty but a bit dry. We thought it would taste more like pistachio, but it tasted like regular meatballs to us

Mushroom kebabs - NASTY! the marinade was too strong and the lettuce salad underneath was extremely bitter.

Salmon with couscous salad - salmon was really juicy, perfectly cooked, and the sour sauce and cucumber raita was a great compliment to the dish. Best dish of the night.

Mussels and Clams in saffron broth - mussels and clams were cooked perfectly, would have liked more broth and more bread to sop it all up.

Menage a foie - good, not great.  tasted like it was supposed to...livery.

Bone marrow appetizer - not much taste, toast was way too crunchy.

Cauliflower & Apple soup - Blah, blah, bland  

beet salad, butter lettuce salad - yummy and fresh!

All sides - cold and bland. I would not recommend any of the sides

Desserts - Fried milk torrijas were yummy and reminded me of burger king french toast sticks. Not your granda's pie was a deconstructed mess. Smurfs on Acid plated this dish. 

If you eat here, prepare for hits and misses.
author: Robin K.

description:
Really good... really really good.... 

Drink - 5 star cocktail, didn't see the wine list, but interesting cocktails are always a good idea for lunch.

Scallops- supa supa scrumptious

Little fried twinky like things with a name I can't remember with hot choco dipping sauce - If I am diagnosed with a terminal illness I will eat these until I am transported from the building by forklift.  mmmm....
author: Yosh K.

description:
Interesting, tasty menu...for starters, we had the pheasant salad and the eggplant - delicious.  For my entree, I had the salmon - which can be pretty boring at most places - but here it was flavorful and nicely spiced.  The one slight disappointment was the lamb shank which is supposed to be their specialty.  My friend found it good, but kinda dry and lacking in flavor.  I would have to agree - I have had better lamb shank, where it just melts off the bone.  

The cocktails are good.  Service is friendly and attentive, but not intrusive.  I appreciated that our server was mindful about not interrupting while my friend and I were catching up.
