The decor is nice - warm and cozy.  It is a bit on the louder side, so be prepared to speak loudly.  Better for a small group then an intimate dinner for two.
author: Eric C.

description:
Everything was amazing! The staff is incredibly thoughtful and knows there stuff.

I made a request for a table that would be easy to hold a business dinner, and the chef sat us to ensure we were pleased with our location.

Note: If you want the vegetarian menu (more extensive veg options than the regular menu) you just need to request it.
author: Kate H.

description:
Service was outstanding. Food was great. waiter told me my public enemy t-shirt was dope (even though I caught a few dirty looks from some of my fellow patrons).

We all had a really good time here, I am glad we came in. Thanks to staff.
author: Brendan R.

description:
Restaurant anniversary menu: peach salad, spring chicken 

Lamb tongue, pistachio meatballs
author: Wynne K.

description:
took mom here for her birthday on a monday night. where do i start? how about cocktails... we hung at the bar before my folks arrived and had the minted memory and cardamom lime gin cocktail...both fantastic...clean and complex. 
We then had dinner...

apps.
-pistachio meatballs lived up to the reviews and beyond. The pommegranate suace was one of the best sauces i've had in recent memory it tasted like it took days to make. 
-The beet salad was simple yet very tasty, i always appreciate when chefs dont try to overdo certain dishes that allow the produce to shine. 
-bone marrow with bergamont jelly and black salt was delicious...
-we also had a traditional iranian dish consisting of yogurt, eggplant, and walnuts...it was fannnnnntastic. this is one of my favorite traditional dishes that was really really cool to see presented in a modern fashion with local ingredients.

entrees.
-braised beef with asparagus and yatimcheh was FANNNNTASTIC. 
-we also had the kufteh tabrizi which is basically a giant meatball with a duck leg in the center with dates and apricot...its broth was fantastic and my mom said it was better than any she'd ever had which is a crazy compliment if you know my mom! The vegitarian kufteh was my favorite it have a spanish/persian flavor to me which was wonduerful..
-the cod was a hit as well. perfectly cooked, moist, flavorful. etc.. etc..!

dessert.
persian tea was done right and the beignets baklava were wonderful. you must try the faloodeh which is a traditional dessert that if there was a world olympics of dessert would probably win gold. 

the service staff was extremely gracious from our bartender at the bar to our server and the bus boy. They were patient very helpful and always filling the water and making sure we were happy. a special thank you to the Chef Zare for coming by and talking with us which as my mom stated was the best part of the evening. 

pretty excited to go back real soon......
author: Mohammad G.

description:
Ate here last week with my wife and really loved it. Great decor and vibe. The chef was out among the tables and was very personable. The service staff was also very friendly.

I had the lamb which was probably the best lamb I've ever had; it was literally falling off the bone. My wife had the cod which was also good. I liked the unique menu and the mix of Mediterranean and French. Truly a restaurant you won't be able to find in most places. I would highly recommend Zare. Might be busy with the after-work crowd, so I'd go a little later. But this was a great mix of super food and super cool environment.
author: Scott G.

description: Had the best time this Saturday at Fly Trap with 17 friends. We received over the top service from helpful and friendly servers, enjoyed great drinks and delicious, well presented food. I especially liked their minted memory mediterranean cocktail, and the kashk bademjan (braised eggplant) appetizer had the most amazing texture. I had the duck fessenjoon and tasted the wild salmon, lamb abgoosht and beef short rib and I liked them all. Finally, the baklava was just the right finishing piece to this amazing experience. I can't wait to go back.
author: peymon k.

description:
+This place is truly a treat. The old print wallpaper is elegant and the staff are wonderful pleasant and attentive.
On this slow night the bartender came out and took our order and had some great recommendations. The Agave drink is supposed to be a precursor to a margarita ... but for my untrained palette it was a margarita.
For starters, we had the crab salad, grilled sardines, and ménage a foie. The salad was delicious and the sardines were grand daddy size when we were expecting little canned size fingerlings. The foie was also a bit of a surprise in that the liver was whole and not macerated into little patties which would have been preferred. If you like liver it will work but if you don't... For finishing the sea bass and a side of saffron risotto was perfect together.
After our meal Hoss, a very big man, happen to come out for another table and we accosted him to thank him for a wonderful meal. 
Great food and atmosphere complemented by wonderful people.
author: Lawrence T.

description:
I gotta admit, there is something about the look of this place that I really love. Not so much because it's well done, which it is, but more so because after experiencing dark wood overload here in the city, it's nice to see a high end place that looks happy. Most restaurants in SF look like they're about to take their life. It's nice to come to a place with some color and personality.

I had the roasted baby eggplant as an app, pretty good, and the sea bass with chick peas for my entree, really good. The service was excellent and the drinks are great. I had the bartender whip me up a little something and while I can't say what it was he made, I can say that you can trust his judgment because the drink was awesome. 

Overall the food is above average, service was great, decor was a breath of fresh air and drinks were yummy. I didn't give this place 5 stars because for me, at the end of the day, it's about the food, and unless I can tell my friends they absolutely have to go here for the food, it's not getting 5 stars. Nonetheless, this place has a lot of strengths and is worth checking out.
author: Shreya C.

description:
Zare at Fly Trap.  In deepest Soma.  A chef of Iranian descent.  Assertive tastes.  And so on.  At least that's what I was expecting.  What I found was a restaurant with very good service and OK food that was not nearly so highly spiced as I had thought.

I started with spicy tomato soup that was nice enough but not particularly spicy.  I suppose that it is not tomato high season as the taste of tomato was ephemeral.  It was there but there wasn't that bright tang of tomato that I was hoping for. 

A salad of smoked trout and julienned cucumber was also OK.  The trout was nicely smoked, firm, tasty.  But the cucumber was ice cold and so not especially tasty.  As I ate and the cucumber warmed the plate livened.  

Finally a huge, falling off the bone lamb shank.  Very nice.  Usually when I get meat, I wish for more meat and fewer vegetables.  Here I wished for more of the black eyed peas and potatoes that came with the lamb.  Nice food but an additional garnish with the meat would have helped.  

I guess I just not so enthusiastic about Zare as most.  A matter of taste.
author: David D.

description:
I've known of Fly Trap but for some reason had never tried it. It was fantastic. Cosy, romantic, LOVE the grand piano, white table clothes, simply a classy little venue. I had the trout (it was a special) which was fantastic and had the perfect combination of vegetables. I LOVED the walnut bread they have... YUM! 

After reading all of the other reviews... I'm dying to go there for HH... who's up for it?
author: Rada I.

description: I'm enjoying a steak wrap and spinach noodle soup as I type this from the new "Grill and Grain" lunch service at Zare. Delicious, and true nourishment -- I can tell these are the best quality ingredients prepared with care. Plus the flavors are authentic. One of my best friends is Persian and the soup especially reminds me of something her mom would lovingly serve. It's a bit pricey for lunch, but well worth the quality. I will be back often and highly recommend anyone who works close by enjoy this new lunch option.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
I ordered the bouillabaisse and the waiter came out 15 mins later and said they were out! I gave him the " WTF,  I'm SO HUNGRY and you waited 15 mins before you told me I had to order something else!!!! " look. ( steam comming outta my ears and face turning purple red)

I almost fell asleep waiting for the appetizers to come out.  seriously, the service was so slow, I could have taken a nap while I waited.
author: Anna T.

description: Let's just keep this one simple. GO! and will GO again and again... Hoss Zare knows how to present hospitality ("I like to say Hosspitality") and his food is unlike anything in the City. He goes out every week to find and create new dishes for his guests and you could be one of the lucky ones.
author: Bill D.

description:
we came in on a wednesday and they were pretty accommodating.  there were 4 of us then there were 6 and they moved us without complaint.  for some reason i had always thought they had sweetbreads etc here.   but one look at the menu and it was clear that this was a mediterranean/persian place.  

i asked the waiter what cocktail was good and without hesitation he said minted memory.  it was good!  not too sweet.

we all shared some apps.  the vegetarian kufteh tabrizi and beet salad.

i had the pan roasted halibut.  mine had some grilled endive that was super bitter.  i didnt eat it.  i usually eat all veggies but i left this one. 

i dont know ... wouldnt particularly rally for coming back ...
author: claudia y.

description:
After much research, a mild panic attack and at least an hour going through my Yelp bookmarks, I took a very discriminating diner who is extremely difficult to please to Zare and was very satisfied my choice.

This is one of those rare restaurants that has a menu where nearly everything looks good. The dishes were all very inventive and didn't remind me of plates I'd seen elsewhere. The one real stand out was the side of butternut squash, which always seems to taste more like dessert than dinner, but this one was definitely the best I'd ever had. I would go back for that alone.

Service was friendly and prices were reasonable. I also noticed that they have take-out, and although I live absolutely nowhere near Zare, I'd consider getting it at some point.
author: Lindsey S.

description: Yum!  The pistachio meatballs are killer. Tried bone marrow for the first time and it was interesting. My husband had the salmon which was delicious. My shredded lamb was fine but nothing special. But the Brussel sprouts. Wow. Never knew I could get excited about Brussel sprouts. They were halved and fried (?) and it was like eating potato chips. With a delicious yogurt sauce on the side. I will dream about these until my next visit.
author: Denise S.

description: Perfect.  Took my family here during the holidays and ordered the off-menu emu egg spaghetti carbonara which was probably one of the most delicious, richest meals I've eaten in SF.  Hoss came out and chatted with us as well, wonderful; on every level.
author: Jesse H.

description:
Dining here was bliss! My bf and I found this place passing by when we had no where 2 eat on Vday, but we were in luck when we decided to take a chance. 
Service was pleasant upon entering and throughout the entire meal all the way to the end, where we were even greeted by the door as we left by the chef, a very nice man. The food was good, I being vegetarian had options, I chose the Putenesca and B (my bf) had the beef short rib, we were both satisfied. B has a high standard for service and food, I was happy to have him not have any complaints.
Plus the icing on the good dining of the night was I was given a single red rose when done & a wonderful little take home bag with a bottle of red wine (Chef's Choice) & season spice with recipe for a make @ home dish. I think they really thought about their Valentine's Day evening dinner serivce & it was appreciated.
author: Samantha R.

description:
Flytrap is a restaurant worth visiting.  

While Flytrap was our third choice of restaurants, after being shut out at Quince and later at  Rubicon (ostensibly for "restaurant renovations"), we could not have accidentally fallen upon a better place for old friends to reunite and enjoy the ambiance, food, and conversational environment that Hoss Zare so masterfully created in his newly established restaurant.  

The prize meal of the night was the Abgusht Lamb Shank Braise that we later learned from Hoss himself came from a family recipe in his home country of Iran, where they would "just add water" to the meat if unexpected guests arrived at their doorstep.  Believe me, no amount of water could dilute the savory experience of this dish.

Considering the organic products, attentive - but not overbearing service, and expert culinary skills in the kitchen, the price was reasonable.

We will no doubt return to this gem of a restaurant.
author: Autumn A.

description: Great restaurant in SOMA.  Hoss is great if you have the pleasure of meeting him while you're there...
author: Dom P.

description:
Went to Zare for a friend's birthday dinner and really enjoyed it. The place was clean, the waiter was very friendly and quite funny. 

For appetizers, we ordered pistachio meatballs and crabcakes, which were full of robust flavors. I ordered the lamb burger cooked medium. It came with lettuce, tomato and onions on the side and amazingly delicious seasoned fries. I had a Spanish Cobbler alcholic beverage, which was a sparkling red wine with chunks of citrus fruits in it. 

The place wasn't too crowded on a Saturday night, although we did have our dinner reservations at 8:30pm. It didn't seem atypical for that place, so if you're looking for a good restaurant with hardly a wait, Zare @ Flytrap is your best bet.
author: D L.

description: The food here is great and the ambiance is an older romantic feel.  The service  was excellent.  I'm gonna ask hubby to take me there for my birthday.
author: Rose R.

description: The service was not bad.  The wine was a little overpriced, but decently tasty.  I had the lamb neck, which was the recommended dish.  It was only fair.
author: Chas J.

description: The staff and ambiance is 5 stars, the place where Zare fell short was the food. Although it was very well prepared with great french technique, the flavor was just not there. I also did not enjoy the dessert at all, I tried the 'not your grandmas pie.' They should have called it a deconstructed lemon meringue pie because I would not have ordered it. Perhaps the menu is what really needs work at Zare.
author: Alisha R.

description:
Since my gf was such a huge fan of Hoss Zare's previous restaurant, she decided to take me here for a date. The place was surprisingly undercrowded for a new restaurant (although it was during Obama's DNC speech, which I was TiVo'ing). We were promptly seated along the side windows, which was perfect given the rare warm SF night. 

I started off with the mushroom soup, which was a little disappointing. It was way oversalted, to the point that the soup broth was unedible. The ingredients in it were good and the poached egg cut the saltiness, but too much is too much. My entree was the pan roasted sea bass and my gf had the half-chicken, both were excellent and made up for the soup misstep. We also had a plate of fries with saffron aioli. For dessert I had the blueberry pie and she had the rocky road, both were seriously good and a nice way to end the meal.

Our server was attentive and knowledgeable about the dishes, but he did have a few lapses here and there, mainly forgetting to give us our leftovers. Chalk it up to new restaurant jitters. Really the best part was the Chef coming out himself to serve us and taking the time after our dinner to chat with us for 5 minutes, knowing that my gf used to go to his previous restaurant. Things like that make you want to go back, despite its imperfections.
author: Cliff C.

description:
Been here only once so will have to try again and hopefully be more impressed.   Food, decor and drinks brought the average down for Zare, as the service was great--welcoming host and servers and even the head chef and namesake, Hoss Zare, himself.  Nice to see the head chef working dinner service. 

Food seemed adventurous in flavor combinations but not always successful and had underwhelming presentation.  Overall not worth relatively high prices.

Martinis were warmish and not made with care. 

Sat down at a table with large sticky spots, though they were cleaned quickly and apologetically, to the server's credit.  

Will go back and hope for better.
author: Matt S.

description:
Delicious. Came here with my parents and we got the following, each of which I would recommend:
- vegetarian 'kufteh tabrizi' (checked the menu for the name of that one)
- wild mushroom cake (better of the two appetizers)
- salmon (you can substitute extra veggies for the fregola if you want)
- pulled lamb dish
- beef short rib (my dish, highly recommend)

Then, when I told our waitress that I couldn't have chocolate so wasn't really interested in any of the desserts, she offered to make a substitution for me! Now I can't find it on the menu, but something that she described as being similar to french toast, but more the shape of a fat mozzarella stick. It was delicious and we got it with caramel sauce instead of chocolate, and mmmm it was so good.

This is definitely a place to go to if you're looking for things you wouldn't make yourself. My mom said she was looking for a 'culinary experience', and yes we found one
author: Caitlin B.

description:
After attempting to find a restaurant somewhere near my work that wasn't incredibly expensive due to its often fogged in bay view I happened on this gem. 

We showed up pretty darn early in order to get to Kooza on time. The place is rather dark with candles throughout and old maps decorating the walls. I read somewhere that it is one of the oldest restaurants in SF, and that wouldnt surprise me. 

The best was when this guy came to our table and asked if we wanted some flower petals... umm, sure, I guess I will take some flower petals. He proceeded to sprinkle rose petals all over our table with great fanfare and precision. It was pretty hilarious when every time someone came to put down/pick up a plate they would re-arrange said flower petals... its ok guys, I am not really a flower petal kinda girl, they can be slightly not perfect...

The menu is rather traditional, but really excellent. There were a handful of delicious sounding dishes for my mostly-veg-but-will-eat-expensive-seafood self.  I had read about their limestone salad, so went ahead and got that one - delicious. I love lemon +oil and this buttery lettuce was great. Had to go with the crab ravioli, which was also delicious. 

The best part was that the bartender knew how to make, and didn't mind making, a awesome old fashioned.
author: amy b.

description: Zare' at Fly Trap is truly great- welcoming, accommodating, friendly, all with great food and nice for the kids.  Having the joy of eating at all of Chef Zare's establishments over the years, this one is at the top and he is at the top of his (or any Chef's) game.  Cannot recommend it enough, particularly "Meatball Monday" with his Kufteh inspired meatballs.
author: Steve R.

description:
Zare at Fly Trap is lovely for many types of occasions;  family get-together, business dinner, romantic date, friends catching up, etc.  My boyfriend and I go there at least once a month and have a great experience every time.  

While all of the food is fantastic at Zare, my personal favorite is the lamb shank - the relish that comes with it is amazing.  The goat cheese cheesecake is light and perfect to wrap up a great meal.  The wait staff is very professional and friendly.  The owner/chef makes his way around the tables, delivering food and making sure the customers are satisfied - also gives some nice background information/history on some of the dishes.
author: Lisa Y.

description: We made a diner of the appetizers, four for two people with a salad which we split.  The food and service were first rate, I'd give Zare 4.5 stars if I could.  The waitress was friendly, funny and knowledgable.  We loved the meatballs and the eggplant though wed order everything we had again.  Will definitely be back.
author: M W.

description:
Yowza... This place makes the most wicked extra dirty vodka martinis. Delicious!

They have homemade potato chips in baskets on the bar, perfect for munching while getting down on a drink. 

It's a little fancier than I enjoy for a happy hour (dives are usually my M.O.) but it's right by my work and I really can't pass it up.
author: C P.

description:
Excellent!  I was very impressed overall.  Food, service, presentation, and ambience were perfect.

We had the lamb cheek ragu in pasta shell dish and the menage a fois gras  to start.  Delicious!

The blueberry pie was heavenly.  You've earned a new fan.

Cheers!
author: Janice Y.

description:
Wonderful! 
Very good food, and not too expensive. The design is awesome, and the service very friendly. 
Good place for a date!
author: Ana R.

description: another of my fav restaurant in SFO, great fresh food! The ambience is wonderful along with their attentive service!
author: Lorac L.

description: Food is fantastic here - the Lamb shank is to die for  - a great mix of Persian cuisine and Mediterranean flare!  Highly recommended!
author: Hessam V.

description:
Loved this place for lunch.  Fast, friendly, and reasonably priced.  Very fresh & light options and not only do you feel full, but healthy and smart for making good food decisions ;-)
I really liked the Mediterranean Grill & Grain menu and had the chicken quinoa salad.  I will be back!
author: amy c.

description:
I love this place! We were very happy with the happy hour. The oysters were fresh, cold, sweet and delicious, and for 1.10 each that is a huge bargain. Yes, I am a cocktail slut and the orange drop was the best I ever drank! The bruschetta left us all burping up way too much garlic and onion, but atleast we all ate it and smelled the same :) It is a small, quaint old school place, packed on a Tuesday night at Happy hour. Get here early, they only serve the oysters at that price in the bar and seating is limited to around 12 stools, no tables.
A great place to unwind from a hectic work day.

UPDATE 5/9/07

The bartender Jay is great. Makes the meanest Orange Drops around!

Wednesday we decided on dinner there, had a guest from out of town and wanted to share this gem with him. Strolled in about 8:50 and were told the kitchen was closing. But they graciously seated us anyway and we ordered drinks waiting for the 4th person to show.  Still no 4th. We order while waiting. My porcini mushroom soup was delicious as well as my friends crab cake.  Finally she arrives and they were nice enough to take her order, though you can plainly see the restaurant is thinning out, tables being readied for tomorrow, etc. Jay is gracious and is our server as well as bartender.  My bf salmon was cooked perfectly, K loved his chicken pasta and my food was delicious but I was a little drunk by then and still can't remember what I had! oh well :)

Thank you Fly Trap for staying open later for us. Jay, you rock!
author: Christine E.

description:
*A quasi-continuation on this train of thought: http://www.yelp.com/biz/maru-ichi-mountain-view#hrid:MFw64xg-InvHt689yS-FVw*

So, I thought about it...that question posed by a friend of mine:  "If there was a pill that eliminated your appetite forever, would you take it?"

Food, would I really miss it?  The daily task of feeding oneself can sometimes be a chore.  Do I eat in or do I want to go out?  If out, where do I want to go?  And then, what kind of cuisine?  And what do I order?

But then, there are aspects of food and eating that I really enjoy.  Hot dogs at a summer barbecue.  The panko-crusted sole at that restaurant around the corner.  Steak frites!  Would I take a pill that erased all this from me?

After last night's meal at Fly Trap, my answer will have to be "no."  Not after the succulent escargot with its fragrant butter & garlic sauce and the bacon wrapped monkfish cooked to perfection, could I possibly answer "yes" to such a question.
author: Yve F.

description: The two stars are for the ambiance. It is nicely appointed, though very noisy in the front room. There is a bit quieter back room. We are relatively new to Persian food. This is only the 2nd place we've gone for it. The place we usually go is in Marin is great beyond all possible measure. Fly Trap's culinary offerings dissapointed both my hubby and myself. His soup seemed heavy with yuky tasting herbs and way too vinegary. My meat ball appetizer (one of the house specials) was nothing I would ever intentionally eat unless I was starving (which I was). They goosed it up in a sweet tart sauce and it was hard to tell whether this was a dessert with a meatball or the other way around. In fairness to them, that was all we ordered. If you like a noisy nice looking place and lots of tartness in your food, this is the place for you. The food is very fusion which I don't mind in and of itself. Someone told me they changed up their menu a couple of months ago. Maybe this is the fallout from the new eats ???
author: Barbara S.

description:
In general I really like Persian/Iranian food, but sometimes it's hard to find vegetarian options on the menu, so when looking for a turkey feast alternative this year I decided to try out Zare based on the vegetarian options available on their website.

Since it was a holiday there was a set menu. I was not expecting this when I made the reservation through Open Table, but the restaurant called me in advance to let me know and I appreciated that. It was a sign of good things to come, as all the wait staff and servers were exceptionally friendly and un-stuffy for a place with such an old school vibe.

By far the best things I tried were the initial courses- there was a delicious parsnip soup that converted me to parsnip fandom, and a saffron & mushroom risotto cake with a really lovely chantrelle sauce. Yay for chantrelles.  These were also the dishes that felt more Californian too me.  The entrees, while plated all fancy-like with a swirl of this and a dash of that, had more of the persian flavors I was expecting but after the appetizers they seemed to fall a bit flat.

The wine list was nice and the cocktail menu looked interesting- I'd definitely come back for a drink and a light snack, and as for a full dinner I'm adding this to my list of "slightly fancy places that it's still OK to take my parents to"
author: saru k.

description:
This review is really for the bar here - but seeing some of the dishes go by, I'd be willing to bet it's just as good for dinner.

So I'm no longer an absinthe virgin thanks to this place.  We came in for a drink at my friend's recommendation while in town for a conference.  The bartender here is exceptionally cool and friendly (and I'm sorry I didn't get her name) and recommended a brand (Lucid).  It was quite good - I'm a fan of anything that even hints of licorice and this was right up my alley.  The side effect I didn't expect (and I wasn't alone in this) was that it gave me the munchies, which was crazy because we just finished putting away a big Italian dinner.  So I better stay away from this stuff in the future or I'll need to buy bigger pants.

The bar is a great place to hang out and talk, the service is good, and the restaurant itself looks fantastic.  I definitely want to come back here and eat one of these days.
author: Nathan C.

description: Enjoyed a well made gin martini. The food was simple and well done.  Excellent service. Nice atmosphere. Will return. I suggest you give it a whirl.
author: Miss B.

description:
went there for dinner last week.

+
valen?, the bartender, friendly, lively, suggestions, amazing.
eating at the bar
food, arancini =  amazing, brussel sprouts, amazing.

-
host: changing the resos here and there was met with total annoyance.
host: had negative energy that affected meal, every time he walked by!
host: didn't seem friendly to other staff.

would have received a 5 star if not for...the host.
author: pete c.

description:
Warning: don't come here if you're allergic to shellfish and your friends are good peer pressurers.  After eating escargot, my friend walked out looking like she was beating up and left with a black eye of sorts.

They have a good happy hour special, and a lot of free appetizers to go with your cheap wine.

The waiters are very knowledgeable and not pushy.  Definite plus in my book.
author: Jenny L.

description: What a disappointment!  The bones of the old Fly Trap are still beautiful, but I'm sorry I chose Zare for my birthday celebration.  I selected it based on the menu on the restaurant's website to make sure all of my guests would enjoy the choices.  When we arrived the menu was different.  I mentioned this to the server.  Someone came to the table later and started explaining that the restaurant's website is changing, the name of the restaurant is changing, etc., which had nothing to do with my dissatisfaction tonight.  She kept talking and I had to ask her to leave.  Two of my guests couldn't detect alcohol in their martinis.  The wine by the glass list is very limited and not California-friendly.  Our server didn't have a command of the specials and the service wasn't very attentive.  The food was good but not extraordinary, and at Zare's prices that's not good enough.
author: Nancy M.

description:
Food overall was pretty darn good & there were many things on the menu that I'd like to try on a future visit.

Goodies we ordered included:
- thinly sliced roasted beets w/Laura Chenel goat cheese & greens including mint (that said, you really aren't getting that much in beets)
- duck legs w/plum sauce over rice (was good, but was sort of too simple, almost like a rice plate in Chinatown)
- pistachio lamb meatballs, great sauce 
- braised eggplant w/crispy onions, I think we mistook 'em for okra which was one of the specials, but the dish was good
- brussel sprouts served with cabbage & pancetta (which was a bit salty alone but a nice combo w/the sprounts)
- short ribs -- to die for, melt in your mouth tender. OMG.

For dessert:
- chocolate mousse cake, prettty good w/something crunchy like rice crispies inside
- deconstructed lemon merengue pie

Again, overall the food was very good. Service was spotty because the entrees took a long time to come after we finished our appetizers, & the wait person didn't come back soon enough for us to report that we were missing a dish. However, they more than made up for the error, so no harm, no foul. Mistakes happen & they did something about it. Tables were a little close together & it was hard to fit our bags/packages under the table.

I recommend this place & look forward to a future visit!
author: D L.

description:
Fly Trap, there's never a bad night there.  I usually come here for happy hour for their $5 house wine that is usually pretty good.

Their Fly Trap martini never lets me down.

Their bone marrow is to die for.

I had the sea bass for dinner last night and was the biggest slab of fish I've ever had at a fancy restaurant.  Every bite if of it was delicious.

Their deconstructed "Not your Grandma's Pie" was divine.  (Only if you like coconut)

This restaurant is one of my faves!
author: Helen C.

description: This was our first time trying Persian food. We really enjoyed it. Service was excellent. Cocktails were average.
author: G. B.

description: Poor service. Manager is absolutely horrible, with bad accusations.
author: Andy G.

description: Moving beyond the traditional Chelokabab Iranian restaurants, I was looking forward to discovering this place that seemed to have interesting twists on Iranian classic dishes. I was not disappointed and even very much surprised. I must admit that the Duck Fessenjoon was amazing and by far beat my mom's fessenjoon. Yes, it did. Very nice acid flavor to it and the meat was simply tender and delicious. Also had the pistachio meatballs that came with a sweat and sour sauce that was finger licking good. Overall, a great meal experience! The wine list was a little on the weird side with a very affordable priced bottle of Portuguese Albarino (quite surprised to find something like this) on the one side and a very expensive bottle of 2003 random Bordeaux on the other. Went for the Albarino and it was good.
author: Reza M.

description:
I've been waiting to review this place since Yelp was down when I first tried.  Full disclosure: I organized the group of 12 that dined there with the other lady.  I agree that the restaurant is a wonderful experience.  It is a small restaurant, to keep in mind if you've got a big group, though they have a section in the back for big groups.  The food is fabulous, flavors subtle yet intense.  The chef is amazing, and actually well-trained (for foodies) and it shows.  He brings his experience and his Persian culture to bring a wonderful fusion.

I had a great little martini with some sort of complex mint rosewater cucumber reduction.  Sounds complicated but really yummy and artful.  They had a wonderful little dish with a poached duck egg that I had with chickpeas.  And great appetizers.  And panna cotta was great though one said the beer caramel syrup could stand to be lost.

And very reasonably priced, a big plus when you're eating in Soma-- compared with Ame and its peers this place is a bargain.  Yet elegant.  The only thing that drove costs up was several orders of olives and bread as appetizers as we had a big group and I figured can't go wrong.  Some restaurants have these complementary but I don't blame Zare for charging for quality. (You can skip these and order real appetizers.)

And it is definitely grown-up dining.  Vegetarian-friendly but my opinion is the vegan options aren't so memorable.
author: June G.

description: went in on  a date last night for drinks. great atmosphere super friendly staff.   told the bartender i like surprises and she quickly mixed up a fabulous cocktail and served it with a smile
author: Cory B.

description: I came here with a bunch of friends not knowing what to expect. We were greeted by a very friendly host who shook hands with us.  We had a very lovely waitress (Meghan) that was super friendly and down to earth.    We ordered a few dishes to share: shirazi salad, meat balls, steak bites, lamb chank.  The lamb was amazing and probably the best I've ever had. We met the chef briefly and he asked how the food was.  I highly recommend this place and can't wait to go back.
author: Salim T.

description:
I've only had drinks and dessert at the Fly Trap, but both were solidly good. Decent wine list and effing incredible desserts. The staff was friendly and helpful, going out of their way to find my friend and I a seat during a pretty busy evening. 

I doubt I'd ever end up here for dinner, but it's my first choice for drinks when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Alison B.

description:
This is really a 2/3 star place but I'm edging on the lower side since I feel the critical needs to be represented here amidst the 4/5 star reviews.

First, the decor is amazing.  Moldings on the ceilings were a nice touch and complimented the rich woods and reds nicely.  Felt as if I was walking into a turn of the century library of a wealthy patron or what not.  Seems like a great place to grab a drink and some appetizers for a zip back in time.

Food was not as desirable  Fois gras dish (menage a fois or something like that) contained 3 types of liver, none which were "true" fois gras.  Meat balls were good, but not great.  The duck was over cooked and dry (really should check this on the line before serving).  Lamburger was good.  The sauces didn't have much flavor to them.  However, the iced tea infused w/ pomegranate was great tho.

It might just be my palette and I'm just not really into the middle eastern "essence" - i.e. gamey tastes coupled with tart / sugars.  Perhaps it's an acquired taste over time.

Net, I would come back here for a drink and apps with maybe a lamburger, but would not do fine dining here again.
author: J L.

description:
I was very eager to try this place because I read about their new vegetarian menu. Yay!

Loooovely ambience and walkable location. The cocktails were tasty and creative, but not all that strong.

We were really pleased with our food, but it was a little heavy. Our appetizer and my entree had breaded/fried items which is probably why. I'll have to go back and try something different.

The huz had the biggest slab of beef I've ever seen with risotto on the side. Whoa.
author: Tamara M.

description:
I had high expectations for this place from all the reviews here.

The place is definitely adorable. Even the entry way into the restaurant is unique and makes it feel sort of tucked away. I like the art deco-ish furnishing. The place settings really beautiful. The live pianist is a nice touch that adds an air of elegance. It has a classy ambiance and can be a nice romantic spot. 

Then I got to the food. My companion and I shared the prosciutto with cantaloupe and figs, which was short of fresh and the pairing with the fruits seemed uninspired. We also shared the crab cake over a bed of arugula salad. I heard a lot about the crab cake, but didn't realize it was TINY. And for some reason, the arugula was sprinkled with so much salt I almost gagged. I know salt's making a comeback in SF restaurants, but there was no reason why simple arugula had to be so salty.

My companion had the crab ravioli which were huge and very tasty. Could definitely tell it was made fresh. I got the chicken jerusalem since it's been raved about here. But I was disappointed; the chicken itself was nice and tender, but it was bathed in so much cream it was like the dish was cream with some chicken in it. Every bite I took I was thinking, "boy, this sure is going straight to my thighs." This is my preference, if you're a cream kind of person then this is heaven for you.

The biggest reason I gave 3 stars was the service was so overzealous. Every other minute either our server or the buser would come ask how's everything/are you finished? The restaurant was full, but it wasn't like there's a line out the door. We were seated in the back room that was kind of partitioned off from the main dining room so it was more private. Maybe the server didn't want us to feel like we were overlooked so was extra attentive. But it was TOO attentive.

Maybe I'd come back to try other things on the menu, but not any time soon.
author: Linda L.

description: Some really inventive tasty dishes.  Everything we had (it was a group of about 15) was delicious and the cocktails were well made.  The service was attentive and yes the pistachio meatballs are good as was the trip of foie gras
author: Ali B.

description:
This place gets 2* for the ambiance/setting, but overall I was disappointed given that YELP gave this place 4*.  I went on a Monday with a 730 reservation...showed up on time and was told by the hostess (who clearly thought she should be modeling in NYC) that it would be another 5 - 7 minutes. Well, it was another 25 minutes before we were seated -- no apology, no "have a drink on us." Fine, they want to play New York, let the food be damn good. But it wasn't, even the butter for the bread wasn't good (and I consider myself an amateur connoisseur of fine butters from around the world. ya.) I order the limestone salad -- bland.  The porcini stuffed ravioli with truffle oil - bland.  I didn't even bother with desert because I knew that too would have no taste.

I am a pain, I know, but even my dining companions weren't thrilled.  What was the worst part of the meal? I had to pay for it instead of the person who did the inviting.
author: Eugene W.

description:
The hostess was strange - I have to start with this as my opener because it really didn't make an impact on the dining experience at all, but I have never had this happen to me before, and quite frankly - it was more than a little fuckin' awkward.

So, we walk in, it's cute, petite, old-school looking with a touch of romance and a nice spot of class.  I'm going with intimate on this one.

The hostess walks us to our table, like any other hostess would.  Now, here's the weird part.  There are napkins folded like triangles or some other origami-esque shape directly in front of us.  She puts one menu in front of my boyfriend and then just stand there and looks at me.

I sit here and look at her, elbow on the table and arm ready to grab that menu.

We wait, she stairs at me for a longer period, still - no words.  This shit is Mystery Diagnosis status - I'm thinking, "wtf?"  Do I have something on me, on my face.  Wow, is she a lesbian and is it love at first sight for her.

She continues to just stand at an awkward angle in front of me staring at my head, or maybe my left ear - I can't differentiate now.

I take off my coat - solution, bitch? No.  The blank stair continues.

Now I'm calling for back-up.  I give my boyfriend the 'what the hell is going on' look and he starts moving shit around on the table.

Wait - why the fuck does he have a menu and it's been five awkward-ass minutes and I still haven't ordered a cocktail - this isn't like me.  Things start to blur.

Finally!  I realize my bf has put his origami napkin in his lap - ahhh ha!  I grab that triangled piece of starched fabric and look at the hostess like a five year old that discovered toe-jam.

She gives me my menu and walks away.

Really?

Now, on with the food.

It was good, not great and it's really close to where I live and I still haven't gone back.  I felt like I was overcharged.  The prices are too high for the taste.

From my meal there I would recommend:

 * The shrimp w/red sauce appetizer.
 * The special they had was a wonderful salmon creme ravioli - really great, but I don't know if it's still on the menu.
 * The duck confit pasta - also very good, but much musky and heavier on the belly.

I think I'll try to go back when they have a piano performer there and see if I like it more
author: Lauren G.

description:
I would give this place 5 stars simply because its worth every penny.

Great little place downtown, parking is usually not too bad and its small and intimate. 

Food is 5 star. Typical American/French. I've had the Foie Gras, awesome, the onion soup also awesome. Veal... of course I like forcefed little baby calves on my plate breaded and fried. 

Service is great as well. 5

Price. 5 you get what you pay for

Atmosphere 5 - intimate, but not small enough to have a party. piano player/singer sometimes they got live music.
author: Steven C.

description:
The Fly Trap is off the beaten path, and that's just fine by me.  It wouldn't have the intimate, romantic setting if there were huge crowds in it all the time.  Its' unassuming facade on Folsom can be missed, however, parking isn't too much of an issue to tell you the truth.  

I eat here once very so often for special occasions, and it never disappoints.  The sundried tomato tortellini in particular, upon arrival, looks kind of small.  However, it's so rich it's beyond deceptive and I find myself oredering it every time.  They make their own pasta here daily, and it shows.  

Piano players during dinner aren't all that distracting, and the jazz vocalists can set the mood.  The staff is courteous and the service is really great, plus, they put rose petals on your table for decoration when you're seated at your table.  It's really nice.  

The food can get pricey, but whatever.  It's better than a touristy seafood restaurant by the Wharf anyday.  The bottom line?  This isn't a place to grab a snack, for sure... this is somewhere you go when you have 2.5 hours to eat a meal with dear friends, family, or a significant other.
author: G B.

description:
We went for the giant meatball on Meatball Monday. Atmosphere is beautiful, service is great.

Cocktails are excellent - I'm a fan of interesting cocktails made from fresh ingredients, and Fly Trap has plenty to offer. Broken into Barbary Coast cocktails and Mediterranean cocktails, you should find something you like on this list. Very creative and yummy.

Wine list is interesting - Chris Blanchard is one of the few master sommeliers around, and he has cultivated a list that includes unique US finds, European, Mediterranean Islands, and Middle Eastern selections. 

The menu - I didn't love the menage a foie, but my boy thought it was pretty good. The roasted eggplant wasn't what I expected - the sauce was a bit heavy handed, but it was pretty good. The meatball was excellent. The bread and lavash was great - served with some of the best spreads. Very yummy.

None of the food was overwhelmingly fantastic, but it was all pretty good, and everything else just came together. If you don't build up your tab with cocktails, the meal is actually pretty reasonably priced, too.

I look forward to going back and trying more from the regular menu.
author: Monika M.

description: Service here is excellent!!!!! Greg, the bartender is awesome, as is the nice gentleman host.    Greg makes delicious drinks.  I love love love love LOVE the Persian breakfast cocktail (vodka, bergamot, honey).
author: Wakako U.

description:
this is in my hood..mi barrio...so i been meaning to try it for some time now...so today...i had a friend visiting, so took her here...we started out with a half bottle of rutherford...fairly priced at $22....a fly trap salad...blue cheese and pears with leafy spinach...room temperature...it was okay...maybe 2 star worthy....and crab cake...yummy....it was nice and toasty brown on the outside..soft and moist inside....really great crab cakes....5 star worthy....

for the main course....she went with the skirt steak..i went with the angus steak....i really wanted her to try the sole fish....so i could get a taste...but no luck...she and i were both carnivores....both steaks were saucy...blackened peppers and maybe it was capers...but it was delicious...if you like the saucy type of steaks....it's 4 star worthy i thought...

interior is "classy"....it was a fullhouse at 7pm on a monday evening....mostly older crowd....not a "hip" place to dine for the metro 20's and 30's....food is solid....i don't think you can really go wrong here....dinner for two with salad, appetizer, entree and wine...$128 after tax and tip...not bad...
author: Hen A.

description:
PERSIAN PERFECTION! 
The service was impeccable and the food top notch. Blended ingredients from the Middle East. Meatball Monday is terrific, The softball size meatball opens up to reveal treasure. This week it was a whole chicken breast. The ground beef/veal mixture slips into your mouth and the spices roll of your tongue like a satin sheet. the chicken was moist and tender. It can feed two easily with an appetizer. Best fries I ever ate.. They stayed crisp and good even after they were cold. Top shelf cocktails ($10). Ask for the back room where it is quieter.
author: Lois M.

description:
Overall, we enjoyed our experience at Zare, but there were definitely both pluses and minuses.
The pluses: delicious Persian breakfast cocktail.  The egg white on top was like sabayon or the top of a hot toddy.  My scallops & tagliatelle were nicely done, as was my husband's salmon with couscous. Our friend really liked the combination of the chicken with prosciutto and cheese.  And the unconstructed pie and goat cheesecake were delicious.
The minuses: super hot inside.  We might have stayed for an after-dinner drink and coffee, but we just couldn't manage the heat any longer.  We told our waitress, who seemed to smile knowingly, as if that wasn't the first time she'd heard the complaint.  And our appetizers, which sounded so good based on other reviews, were disappointing.  My meatballs were dry and the pomegranate sauce was a congealed mess.  There wasn't enough marrow to even enjoy on the dish my husband ordered, and there was nothing memorable about the lamb sausage.
I'd go again, but I suggest skipping these appetizers.  Oh. And wear something light.
author: Ann B.

description:
Im gonna go ahead and agree with "Dr Jones" here and give this place two thumbs down.

This highly overrated restaurant gets to keep a star for their "good" calamari cous cous which left me anticipating the future entrees. But the main dishes left me unfullfilled. The chicken was blah-honestly best word for it. The Seabass was bland and covered in some olivey tapade. The fish tasted like it came from Costco. And the risotto-yeah I wouldnt have minded it if I didnt foresee the consumption of it later on showing up on my rear end.

And lets not forget the grand finale: the dessert the "Chocolate Suprise". Basically a piece of flavorless cocoa cake with some salty caramel and a side of cracker jacks. Not a good suprise.

Im glad my date disliked this as well so now I can vent openly about my true feelings of this place!
author: Heather S.

description:
3.5 stars

Note: I have eaten at both the original Flytrap and now at Zare at Flytrap - I have to say, I enjoyed the original Flytrap's menu more. The original restaurant is definitely missed.

Fiance and I shared the following:
Menage a Foie: Of the three offerings, we only enjoyed the foie gras w/huckleberries. The chicken liver was just ok and the sheep's liver was tough and not-very-tasty.

Baby octopus and calamari salad: This was one of my favorites of the night. The beans were probably not necessary - but then again, I'm not the hugest fan of beans - but the octopus and calamari were to die for. The lemon on top was the perfect touch.

Lamb burger: It was good, not great. 

Saffron risotto: Second favorite of the night. It tasted like a macaroni and cheese dish, but just a tad lighter. Very flavorful.

Chocolate surprise dessert: Totally not a fan - I was not "surprised" at all. Bland, boring, not very exciting. The only thing that saved it were the housemade "cracker jacks."

They also just changed their Tempranillo, which I personally felt was not a good change...I came for HH a few months ago, and thought that Tempranillo was much better.

Overall - good service, ok food, a little pricey for what you get.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
This is one of my favorite lunch spots...its like an old friend...you always know what you're gonna get:  good food, good service, a heart-aching bill (it's not cheap).  

Order the dungeness crab salad (the FULL order!  Not the small size!  Get real!  If you're gonna pay...then pay!) or any of the risottos they have on the daily special menu.  TRUST ME!  You may not know me, but I take my food very seriously.  Both dishes make my belly happy and make the rest of the afternoon at work bearable.

Sit at the bar.  The guys are great.  Especially during lunch.

Enjoy!
author: Susan L.

description:
The food was good...but not GREAT. The prices were incredibly high considering how simple and small the servings were.  The setting was romantic, but definitely not a 5 star restaurant and the prices they charged was way  too expensive for food that was bland and burnt.

Didn't get to try the dessert but heard great reviews from it.
author: Melissa N.

description: Excellent experience all around.  Were warmly greeted by the staff and the service was helpful and timely all evening.  Went with the chef's specialties: Pistachio Meatballs, Bone Marrow, Lamb, and Salmon.  All were delicious with complex flavors in the accompanying sauces.  The chermoula on the Salmon was especially tangy, and, I hate to admit, was a little better than the one I prepare at home.  Had the unconstructed pie and the chocolate mousse for dessert.  Both good, especially the pie.  Street parking fairly easy.  A comforting, satisfying dinner.
author: John K.

description: The food was delicious, although the service was a little slow. I love the decor and atmosphere, and they have a great selection of cocktails that looked delicious. They have a special "vegetarian menu" available upon request, and although I applaud this attention to non-meat options, I wish it were just part of the regular menu -- I was there for a business dinner and hate calling attention to my food choices by requesting a special menu. ("You don't drink AND you don't eat meat?? You're going to have to help us out here!" me: *eyeroll*) I was part of a party of 5 and everyone raved about their food choices. I had the gnocchi, which melted in my mouth, yum! Don't miss the chocolate mousse cake for dessert.
author: Gaelen X.

description:
I loved the old Fly Trap and was a bit worried when it came under new management but it has remained true to its roots while offering an amazing new menu; meatballs with pomegranate? Delicious. There's quite a lot to like.

The staff are always pleasant and accommodating and the atmosphere is relaxed and refined.
author: vinay d.

description:
I loved this place before and have been meaning to write a review for a long time. 

Looking forward to going back to try the new menu and making this rating complete.

 If you put the Exotic Bomb back on the dessert menu I'll give you 5 right now! It's the best dessert I've had- EVER!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Took my girlfriend here for a little holiday Christmas dinner. It was a bit loud in there for an intimate dinner but the place is nice. Our waitress was awesome. Really pleasant and attentive. It's all about the food but great service can also make the experience that much better. So everything I read talked about the meatballs, so we ordered the meatballs for an appetizer and I have to say it was a pretty tasty meatball. I mean it's just a meatball but probably one of the  better meatballs I've had. 

So lets talk about the food. I ordered the lamb. Fall off the bone tender. It was pretty good. Debbie had some white fish which was pretty good. 

I'd give it 3.5 stars but can't do half stars so I rounded up. It was GOOD but didn't blow me away. The service was fantastic and the food good.

This was my second visit, The first time was before it changed ownership and the menu is different but the food has improved.
author: Hyung L.

description: We went for the third time tonight.   Zare has been great every time - unique tastes and super delicious.
author: More B.

description:
This weekend, I made my third trip to this establishment in as many years, and I am consistently impressed with the overall quality. 

It's a quieter, almost date-place atmosphere on weekends, which is helped along by the live piano and singer in the corner. I appreciate the live music and it isn't so loud or obtrusive to interrupt conversation. 

The hand-made pastas here are quite good, with special emphasis on the sun-dried tomato and veal selections. The portions aren't huge, but certainly tasty. 

My most recent dinner included the pork chop, a generous cut of meat that was perfectly cooked. It came with mashed potatoes and spinach and a superb brown sauce. The cut was lean too, which meant that everything but the bone was to be eaten and enjoyed. 

Additionally, there is a decent wine list and full bar available. Some of the house cocktails are quite good, albeit a bit on the "chick drink" side of coin. 

After numerous visits, I have yet to be disappointed, and the food has been great. You add in the ease of surrounding parking, the ambiance, and the quality of the waitstaff and you have a winner place. 

This would be a good place for a 6+ month relationship dinner or for someone you really want to impress.
author: Peter C.

description:
I really enjoyed having dinner here. The food was delicious and reasonably priced. Considering the current economy, I feel guilty splurging on fine dining if I can just cook, but I didn't feel like I was going overboard here at all.

For appetizers, we split the beet salad, lamb tongue and pistachio meatballs with pomegranate glaze (YUMMM) and for an entree, I ordered the lamb burger (which was only $14). My friend got the crab linguini, which actually was a bit too citrusy for my taste, and someone else got the seared scallops. All three were great, but I thought the lamb burger was the best!

One of our guests had to leave early, and we asked our waiter if it was possible to bring his food out earlier than the rest of us. He was very understanding and they brought his entree out (also the lamb burger) with the appetizers.

Also, the fries that come w/ the lamb burger are deeeeelicious. Overall: 100% recommended!!!
author: ting b.

description: Had an amazing dinner here with a group of friends recently. We decided to order a bunch of appetizer plates to share so we could experience a variety of dishes. All were excellent. The waitress was knowledgeable about the wine list and made suggestions to best compliment the variety of dishes we were having which were excellent choices. Many restaurants tend to "recommend" the more expensive wines but she recommended wines of various price points for us to choose from. Chef Hoss came by the table to check on us which was a nice touch as well. A new favorite place to dine in SF.
author: Ken H.

description:
We were looking for nice place to eat on new year's eve. We ended up going to this place as it had good reviews and we got reservations for that evening. We were running late. So we called them up and they were nice enough to move our reservation ahead by half an hour. Since it was new year's eve, the price was exorbitant (~120 a person after taxes) for the four course meal they offered on that day.
I must say even though it was super expensive the food was excellente :).
We started out with a glass of  Champagne and Asparagus Soup. Next in line for the veggies was appetizer Wild Mushroom Cake which had a very unique taste. This was followed by persimmon fall salad with a delicious some kind of vinaigrette. Next was entrée Stuffed Delicata Squash. Tough this was good, I think this was the least delicious of all. The last was the dessert. My choice was Ranginak (date cake).  Surprisingly it had pretty strong flavor of paprika.  It was interesting dessert. We also tried the other 2 desserts, not your grandma's pie and chocolate mousse cake. 
The food was excellent. I hope to go there during normal non-event days and try out their other food.
author: Vatsa S.

description: My friend took me here for a celebratory lunch recently. We got there a tad early but they let us order some wine and even gave us some bread to munch on while we waited. It was worth the wait. I had a crab, couscous salad and she had the beet salad and they were both wonderful. Then we split the "Menage a Foie" which was exceptional!!!! I can't wait to go back for dinner!
author: lisa v.

description:
we consider this place to be our neighborhood bar, and fortunately for us it has some pretty amazing food too.  i can't remember if i've ever actually had an entree there, but i've tried almost all the appetizers and a couple desserts and they've all been excellent - standouts are the shoestring fries with saffron aioli (side) and the yogurt marinated flank steak (appetizer).  they also have some pretty cool specialty cocktails.

the ambience is perfect for drinks, dates or just an intimate dinner, and the chef (zare) spends a fair amount of time out in the dining area saying hi to everyone, which i think always makes people feel special.  overall i love going here - and you really have to try the fries...
author: KT R.

description: So yummy!  Went with coworkers for Meatball Monday and the meatball was HUGE and the veal fell right off the bone.  It's a very nice restaurant, the wait staff is very friendly, and the chef/owner came to our table a few times which I have to admit was very nice to see a humble owner that truly appreciates business.  Overall, a great experience.  Would recommend this restaurant to everyone.
author: Kathleen O.

description: The food here was really very good. Fresh ingredients combined in novel ways to produce delightful dishes that sound familiar but turn out to be quite different from anything you've had before. We began by sharing the braised eggplant appetizer and a Dungeness crab salad. I had the lamb 'abgoosht koobideh' - a melt-in-your mouth concoction of pulled lamb in broth with fresh peas. The crispy brussels spouts with yogurt-based tartar sauce were extraordinary. Both the food and the service were great. The only significant downside is that the place is extremely noisy - as in 'you have to practically shout to be heard' noisy.
author: David K.

description: We've been here a few times with a friend who knows the City like the back of his hand, and we've enjoyed our meals and drinks immensely every time.  Perhaps it's all in the company that you keep -- but Fly Trap appears to consistently offer excellent fish, oysters, and pasta in an elegant, warm atmosphere.  Just walk in and sit at the classy bar; the bartender will take great care of you even if you choose to have your dinner there.
author: Sherri C.

description: Fly Trap is my favorite neighborhood happy hour spot. My roommates and I venture out to Fly Trap frequently to catch the 1/2 price drinks specials after work. I love Fly Trap for it's super cozy and friendly atmosphere. It isn't too crowded and the bartender J makes me smile.
author: Debbie C.

description: Very cool place for quick eats or drinks. Amazing wine list and BTG selections and very wine knowledgable wait staff which is nice for a change. Modern spin on traditional Lebanese dishes is great, this is not your standard Mezze.
author: Tim B.

description: Right under my office - what could be better? Amazing food, I especially love the meatball appetizer and the cheese platter. The drinks are strong, and the staff are super friendly. It's great for happy hour, or dinner. love it!
author: Tati M.

description:
Pleasantly surprised.  The atmosphere was cozy and un-hurried.  Would seem like a place that you could sit and lounge around in for a while, despite the fact that it is a restaurant.

Originally didn't really like the name - but now having been the place - I believe it does carry a certain charm.

Foodwise, I enjoyed every item ordered, from appetizer to desert.  Also had an interesting - through unremarkable - selection of mixed drinks.
author: Jerry C.

description:
When I want to eat at a place that is a little more posh then my usual hole in wall family owned restaurants this one is at the top of my list.

The staff is always friendly. Nice atmosphere and great place to take someone special. But most of all the food is always great. The menu changes nightly so what you had before might not be on the menu that night. From appetizers to entree's everything is cooked in such a way that you know the people that are making it are putting lots of care in the preparation so that once it hits your plate is not only is cooked right but is presented right as well. if you can manage to fit in desert they have the best banana splits!

I've been going here for years and will continue for years to come.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Hey, where did the gnocchi go?

Oh well, this whole remodeling thing did not cause too much damage to this place (other than the disappearance of couple of popular menu items). Still, small and intimate space that gets a bit loud on busy nights. The bartenders mix STRONG drinks at the bar (first I thought the bartender was flirting with me but then my husband got a very stiff drink as well.)

The menu is solid-- between the 4 of us, nobody was disappointed. We all went for seafood: from salmon and sea bass, to scallops and tuna salad. Great stuff. The desserts are fantastic as well -- do order the yogurt and honey. It sounds odd but that Greek-style yogurt is closer to ricotta cheese than a grocery store yogurt and comes in a little cut. Very good. 

As a final touch, everybody gets a little chocolate with an imprint of a fly placed on a sheet resembling fly paper. Super cute :-)
author: Gina M.

description:
The meatball dishes are unique and very tasty.  I had the rack of lamb meatball special (not a typo).

The wine list is affordable and also very unique.  The Spanish and Italian wines that our waitress recommended we phenomenal.
author: Jeff S.

description:
my new favorite restaurant!
great food, better service!!
quiet, chill, love it
author: Deka M.

description: Cozy place for a quiet dinner date, rather pricey $21 for a glass of wine and mussels appetizers 3.5 stars
author: Chris A.

description: A great SOMA restaurant.  As an individual who loves Mediterranean food, this place is a winner.  I have been here with groups both small and big, and this restaurant always accommodates.  I love the Risotta Balls and Ricotta Cheesecake.  Although the Ricotta Cheesecake sounds questionable, when I went with a few friends this dessert was ravaged within seconds.
author: Sonia M.

description: Went here last week with a girlfriend who I had been trying to get here, so she could experience some great vegetarian fare. The bar was hopping on a Friday night...and I still loving the atmosphere of this cozy place. Also, the wait staff has always been very welcoming and accomodating. The loss of one star from my last review, came about only because I was somewhat disappointed with the menu selection....gone were so many of the yummy dishes I had raved about. I suppose the chef changes things up for seasonal ingredients, but the desserts, and most of the entrees weren't as appealing as on my previous visits. My friend ordered an herb bread platter for starters, basically pita and french bread served with two herb spreads, very tasty, but boring. She also had an eggplant dish which she said was very good, presentation was nice. I ordered a carmelized onion soup with cardamon and other spices. Served piping hot (hit the spot after walking around the city in cold, rainy weather), the first few spoonfuls were delightful, full of flavor, but as it cooled, became very acidic, and made it hard for me to finish. I also ordered a side of crispy sprouts, fried brussel sprouts served with a kind of yougurt raita sauce. Again, very good whilst hot, not so much as they cooled. We skipped cocktails and dessert as we were short on time, but there wasnt too much there that interested us. I would def come back to Zare, its a wonderful place, just may be they are scaling back a bit, so selections are limited.
author: Nina B.

description:
This is a place of old-school, relatively understated elegance. The food is delicious and not terribly expensive ($20ish entrees), the staff is friendly and helpful, and the bartender makes astonishingly good Manhattans. 

My group of four waited at the bar for a few minutes while our table was being prepared. When we arrived at our table, I knew the staff was in top form -- it was already set with two white and two black napkins, as two of us were wearing dark pants and they wouldn't have wanted us leaving looking linty.

EDIT, 1/7/07: Went back. The classy music is gone, replaced with Om Lounge 4 or whatever. I had the steak, which was edible and cooked to temp but not very flavorful.
author: Joe G.

description:
It's very difficult for any restaurant to get a 5-star rating from me, but this restaurant is truly the best. I've been here well over 8 times and the food is consistently excellent (and I've had quite a few different things from the menu). The service is wonderful--from the occasional music to having rose petals sprinkled on the table. The restaurant itself is lovely inside with dark wood and mirror panels. 
Everything on the menu that I or my bf ordered has been excellent. Their fresh pasta is to die for, so if you are going there for the first time don't hesitate to order anything under that part of the menu. Of course the meats are excellent as well. It is a bit pricier than your average dinner, but I have never left this restaurant feeling hungry or dissatisfied, and I would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone looking for a delicious and romantic dining experience.
author: Irina D.

description:
A very romantic old-style SF restaurant that'll make you wanna rush your date home for a great post-dinner romp. Food is delicious and the waiters are very kind and attentive (though ours had a sneaky grin...).

A lovely little back-room feels a bit secluded (and quiet, especially if everyone else dining at Fly Trap that night is on the older side) but quite nice if you're in the mood to stare into your date's eyes and slyly feed each other oysters and bites of chocolate souffle surprise. The meal was a bit pricey, but if you're in the market for this kind of evening, do check it out.
author: Brittany L.

description:
Great place to have a relaxing gin + tonic (which usually turns into several rambunctious gin + tonics).  The two bar tenders  (Jay, and umm, the blonde guy who likes d209 over sapphire) I've dealt with are fabulous - great intuition as to when to leave the collective you be, and when to join in the conversation with an always humorous anecdote.
The food I've had here is great, but umm, that would consist of happy-hour-oysters, olives and slices of lime.  Oh - I've had chips too!  They kind of look orange - so much so that when we first saw them, we thought they were crappy cheddar-storeboughts and wondered where the crappy cheese-powder-taste was when we bit into them. Turns out they peel their own sweet potatoes everyday and start passing out the warm basketfuls at 4p.  bravo fly trap.
author: Meg W.

description:
So let's start w/ the fact that we didn't have dinner, nor any food really.  Well save for the Skookum oysters at $14 for a dozen - such a deal.  And potatoe (that's the VP spelling) chips.  And delicious bread, both french and parisian (hazelnut and raisin filled).

Happy hour ends at 6:30, supposedly.  But thanks to Fernando, it keeps on keeping on.  The white wine special ($4) was an Italian Chard and the bubbly was of the Gloria variety :) for only $5.50.  

The crowd was a bit old for my liking and the ambiance quite classic.  But they did have a variety of alcohols - including a scrumptious calvaldos.  How I love thee.

Let's see what happens when they change management in a week or two.  Hope they don't get rid of the staff...
author: Charla W.

description: My favorite restaurant in SOMA. It's somewhat fancy and expensive - but the food and service definitely lives up to the prices.
author: Nicholas M.

description: We shared a lamb dish that was excellent. Definitely recommend trying this place.
author: Joshua S.

description: I had dinner at the Fly Trap last night for the second time in the last year. I first stumbled up on this place when I move to SOMA and loved it. I haven't had a chance to make it back there,well until last night. I wondered if the memories of the amazing food were exaggerated in my mind. Well, I'm happy to say they were not. The food was excellent. We had the flank steak appetizer, the lamb shank entre and a side of baba ganoush.  All were VERY good.  I'm looking forward to going back.....and this time I wont be waiting a year!
author: Nicole A.

description: Loved this place. Posh interior, beautiful young professionals, and a great vegetarian selection. My favorite dish was the vegetarian kufteh - fried balls filled with spiced rice and beans and a hundred other ingredients I couldn't identify. The seven spice emulsion was sweet and tangy, and the mediterranean avocado salsa was creamy and delicious.
author: Amber K.

description: I've only been there for happy hour in the modern era; I think it may be too expensive on the food side for me.  Bottom line: it's an okay place to go for drinks when it's not too crowded.  They have IPA and something darker on tap; it's nice when you can get seated at the bar, and the bartenders are cool.  However, once bar space runs out, all the table seating is reserved for dinner-eaters, which makes going there for happy hour a sorta hit-and-miss experience.  Your call.
author: moosedog i.

description:
4.5 stars.

I can see why the bar at the Fly Trap is so popular at 6:30 pm on a weeknight.  The happy hour margaritas were luscious.  However, it's a small place with few stools.  

We were there for dinner, waiting for our large party which was a bit late due to street parking (or lack of).  But once we all came in, we were promptly seated.

I started with the Limestone Lettuce Salad, and progressed to the Black Angus Steak Au Poivre.  In truth, I didn't care for the dressing on the salad, and it seemed rather plain.  The steak was perfect.

Other entrees for our group included:  The Rack of Lamb (pronounced "wonderful!"), and the Bouillabaise (very popular, and they all loved it).  Two members of our party did not like how their steak was cooked, however.

Terrific service, very attentive.
author: Linda B.

description:
A friend of my recommended Zaré @ Fly Trap and having a Gluten Allergy, I have to go through more lengths to get a meal.  I called ahead, spoke to the manager and they said, that they are very used to accommodating Gluten Allergies.  As I came in I said I was the one who called and they Manager said "we have 2 other gluten folks in the house right now - just tell your server".  The server worked with me and the even ran to the back to check with the chef on a few items.  They made me a wonderful meal and the service was wonderful.  The chef came out and explained my dish to me.

A wonderful dining experience!
author: Jamie J.

description: Came here for dinner on a girls night out. Fun vibe, atmosphere in a packed restaurant on a Sat night. Loved the fries and brussel sprouts. Portions for dinner was much larger than expected and none of us could finish our dishes. I personally wasn't a fan of the entrees but I generally don't like game-y food to begin with.
author: Kim P.

description:
I stumbled upon this gem while wandering around with some friends, post 111 Minna and we instantly fell in love. I've been back several times since, and I always have a great time. Maybe it's the fabulous ambiance, the low lighting, the killer old school bar or the foxy servers. I can't be sure. But the food is spectacular, you can always get a table and it's really easy to pretend you're in a Woody Allen movie. 
Order the coq au vin. 
Minus one star for the chanteuse not knowing all the words to "Bewitched, Bothered and Bewildered" which would have made my night perfect...
author: Beth S.

description:
Fly CRAP is more like it!!!

If you're looking for a people friendly staff, don't bother coming here.  The waiters are big pricks with giant sticks up their arses.  I always try to make excuses for these a-holes, like they had a long night or their significant others just dumped them via text message.  Today, I didn't really give a flying f**k!  

We came in for dessert and coffee, nothing big.  Our server looked down his nose at us from the start. We were all dressed in our Casual Friday attire (i.e. jeans), but judging from his response you'd think we decided to forgo hygiene for the day!

When we weren't ready to order, he made some obnoxiously rude remark pertaining to our loud chatter.  

The desserts (we each tried a different one) were delicious.  However, I was disappointed with our waiter's obvious disinterest in making us feel welcome.

If it weren't for the yummy desserts and decor, I'd give this place zero stars.

Not going back!
author: Daniela L.

description:
Fly Trap Happy Hour!!

Black Dog on tap!!

Chips with... ripples on them to eat at the bar so that I am thirsty for more beer!!

I always leave The Fly Trap the same way: a little tipsy but feeling soooo good.

Oh, and it's right next door to my work
author: Chris C.

description:
I've had a better raw oyster experience and the service was a bit slow. 

Half-a-dozen raw oyster, missing horseradish and tobasco
Arugula salad - a nice tasting dish
Calf liver steak - cooked nicely 
Crab ravioli - too heavy on the sauce but the ravioli itself was good 

The dim lighting made the atmosphere a little romantic and the pianist and singer did their duet for a a few minutes which was lovely but towards the end of our meal, we weren't thrilled to stay much longer.

*Happy hour - 3 oysters for $3.50
author: Oanh N.

description:
I had dinner here on a Friday night.

Ambiance was nice.  Dim lighting is a plus.  Also there was live music.  Piano & a lady singing.  I didn't pay much attention to it, but it was nice "background noise."

Food was just okay.  We shared the prawn appetizer - I thought the tomato sauce and chorizo overpowered the shrimp.  It was still good, but not great.  BF got the liver....the bacon that came with it was super yummy.  I prefer chicken liver so I won't comment on this since it was beef liver.  I ordered the Jerusalem chicken.  It was tasty, but reminded me of something I could get at the cheesecake factory.  Apple crisp dessert I could have done without....I didn't even finish it...and I love dessert :(  Cocktails were just okay....not sure if maybe it was an execution problem on the bartender's part. 

I will say that the portions here are huge!  So if you want a place with good (not GREAT) food, pleasant ambiance, and some bang for your buck....this is a good place to visit.

Service was really good....that's what kinda makes me feel bad only giving this place 3 stars, but oh well.
author: Neety P.

description:
To be fair, I don't think I really like Mediterranean food all that much - so I'm going to try to stay away from criticizing the dishes too much, as I'm pretty sure the flavors just happen not to be my preference. For example, I realized after ordering the chicken (sounded really good - included artichokes and mushrooms in a cream sauce) that I probably don't like tarragon - which is the spice it was seasoned with. That's my bad. However, my soup starter (somewhat unappealing referred to as "yesterday's soup" - irony not appreciated in this case) was a lobster bisque topped with crab, and that was pretty universally tasty.

The restaurant boasts a really nice bar and actually shares the space with an Indian joint you can walk through to next door. Service was fine, and the wine list is okay, if a bit pricey (maybe it's just that the waiter recommended the only $13 glass of red on the menu).

So...if you like Mediterranean food, give it a try - it's my understanding that's what the faire here is now, and that's a change from the original establishment. If you don't, it probably won't really be your thing. Perhaps come here for a drink instead if you work nearby, as it may be a nice change of pace.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
I went with a vegetarian friend and split a bunch of small vegetarian plates, all of which were delicious. We were in the mood for fries; the fries themselves were very tasty, but we were not digging the overly fragrant saffron aioli. That said, we had plenty to keep us going. Their veggie meatballs are mindblowing. MINDBLOWING. The crispy brussel sprouts with the yogurt sauce were also amazing. And no, it doesn't matter if you actually like brussel sprouts.
