No one fit the part of one that would be working in a restaurant that was supposed to be excellent!!  This is too bad because I think Fly Trap has so much potential.

I will watch out for the future of the Chefs, but I will never bother choosing Fly Trap again....and trust me, we were not the only ones who felt this way that evening. The table next to us waited over 20 minutes for their order to be taken, I even offered them some of our bread and food!!

To the Manegement: Hire people who enjoy being hospitable and who enjoy being in the industry. Good luck. No pun intended...the industry is just not for everyone.
author: Isabel L.

description: This is my 2nd time eating here. The 1st was earlier this year with a food group honoring noted cookbook author, Marlena Spieler. On that occasion, a special menu was prepared for us which was excellent & the nice thing was I didn't have to try to figure what to order. I decided to go back with my family & my sister & her family for our Easter dinner...This time we had to order on our own...No matter...everything we ordered was DELICIOUS!  Of the 9 of us, 4 had the Lamb Shank Abgusht, which was the best we had ever eaten...the meat was juicy, tender, flavorful & fell off the bone (like it's suppose to!)...2 people had the Oxtail Tagliatelle & that was GOOD, too! 1 had the Ghormeh Sabzi, which is a fresh herb stew with short ribs & I got to sample some of that, which was GOOD, GOOD, GOOD! My husband had his usual pork chops & the brussel sprouts accompanying it was very tasty...and someone had the filet mignon which I guess was also good (I didn't get to taste any of it because that person wouldn't share since he liked it so much!). I also have to mention the appetizers because they were the best: pistachio meatballs, grilled lamb sausage, a side of french fries (we didn't order enough!) & my favorite, spice-roasted bone marrow (I could've eaten more of this, too!)...The desserts were quite memorable as well: goat cheese cheesecake (with medjool dates & toasted walnuts), not your grandma's pie (lemon curd,coconut meringue, coconut sorbet with saffron-mint syrup...yum, yum, yum), and fried milk torrijas (served with rose water hot chocolate)!!!!! We were all quite full (as the portions are generous), happy & satisfied!
author: Karen Y.

description:
This restaurant it definitely makes honor to its name, and yes it makes you want to fly away from that trap, the Happy Hour trap! What a experience for a happy hour with appetizers, okay so it's a cheaper option but that doesn't mean screw up the food and have attitude towards your customers. I don't know what was worse, the food or the service. My husband and I had high expectations about this place, I happen to work nearby so from outside it always looks nice, good location and even inside it have quite a charm and good vibe but I guess it's just that...  The service is a huge problem two words: arrogant and pretentious. Then the food comes as a problem, first they were out of salmon even though we were the first ones to arrive at 4pm when nobody else was in there. So after the first deception we start ordering couple of plates like the French fries with saffron aioli sauce, which I don't have any complaint at all but truly who can messed up a simple dish like that. Then the risotto saffron balls with marinara sauce came and I thought: "okay this doesn't look very tasty but let's give a try", big mistake! I think they have those little balls in the freezer for decades and because of that they were mushy and flavorless, the sauce even worse. Finally a bigger ball combination of beans, mushrooms and herbs arrived and once more a boring plate, lack of essence and personality I mean nothing memorable to neither remember nor recommend. So I guess we felt on the trap, too bad.
I almost forgot the beverages, I guess because its also nothing special.
author: Pepperchik p.

description: I had a fabulous meal here the other night for my boyfriend's birthday dinner.  We had a nice table in the back room, and enjoyed the beet salad, sourdough & lavash, bone marrow, Morrocan salmon, and oxtail penne.  Everything was spot-on, servings were generous but not too big, and our waitress took excellent care of us.  Zare himself brought our meals to us and was very friendly.  Definitely the perfect spot for a sophisticated Mediterranean meal in a charming setting.
author: Anna S.

description: This is a good interview lunch kind of place - rather staid, classic food, fancy decor.  On my most recent visit I had a caprese salad for starters.  The dish was saved by its phenomenal balsamic vinegar - sweet and intense.  Otherwise, the tomatoes were under-ripe and the dish was soaked in too much olive oil.  The Jerusalem Chicken was rather boring.  It's main flavor came from an abundance of heavy cream.  I would classify service as slow but friendly.  Might also be a good place for dinner with older family members.
author: Katina M.

description:
Preface:  I wrote this review about a year ago when my coworkers and I were "comparing notes" on our experience(s) at The Fly Trap.

If you work or live in SOMA, chances are you've eaten at The Fly Trap Restaurant.  If you've eaten at The Fly Trap Restaurant, chances are you liked it.  The Fly Trap Restaurant has served up delicious dishes in San Francisco since 1906 - first at 73 Sutter, then at 515 Golden Gate, and now at 606 Folsom. Even though it's been in business for 100 years, it never tried to be "popular".  People know about this restaurant not by glitzy advertisements or a brand name chef but rather by word of mouth.  That is probably the best advertisement for a business - clientele endorsement.  

I've eaten at The Fly Trap three or four times and every time I came out full and satisfied.  The menu offers classic Californian cuisine that you can count on. Portion sizes are just enough to fill your appetite without stuffing you to the rim.  I can't remember everything I've eaten there thus far, but there are three that I will always remember.  For lunch one time I had the Chicken Coq Au Vin.  It's a demi-glazed piece of white and dark meat chicken served with mushrooms, bacon, roasted potatoes, red wine, thyme, and pearl onions.  The meat was juicy and the flavor of all the ingredients complimented each other perfectly.  For dessert on another occasion I had the Crme Brule.  I loved the consistency and the right-on-the-money sweetness.  I don't like desserts that are too sweet and this one was just right for me.  Still yet on another occasion when I went for happy hour drinks at the bar, I ordered a Bruchetta to go with my beer.  If you love garlic and basil as much as I do, then you'll love this dish.  If you don't, then stay far far away.  The garlic flavor stayed with me the entire night and I loved it.  This was the best Bruchetta I've eaten ever.  I should also mention that their bar has a very good selection of beer.

Although the atmosphere tends to lean towards business casual, I never really felt the "business" part of it.  I've always felt calm and relaxed. Another impression I have of this restaurant is that there is absolutely no pretense, neither from the staff nor from the other clientele.   Everyone there is about food and food only.  This is often lost at other restaurants in the area.  As far as service goes, it's what you would expect from a restaurant.  The right amounts of efficiency and courteousness.

The Fly Trap is a restaurant I would go back over and over again.  It's so close to me that I can go frequently.  The only thing that stops me from going too frequently is its prices.  At about $20-$30 per entre for dinner and $15-$25 per entre for lunch, it's not steep enough to break the bank in one shot but definitely not an everyday affair for the average worker bee like me.  Finally, The Fly Trap is a restaurant I feel comfortable and confident recommending to people.
author: Irene T.

description: Great food, expensive but worth it! This is a nice place for a special occasion. Yes, they do have a limited menu but they manage to pull it off. The ambience is quite laid back...
author: Praveen K.

description: Classy restaurant with an excellent bar.  I've eaten lunch here three times since my office is across the street and never had a bad meal. The Jerusalem chicken and coq-au-vin were excellent.  You can tell this is an old-school restaurant (The Fly Trap celebrates its 100th birthday in 2007) that still serves calves brains and sweet bread.  The oysters are supposed to be excellent.
author: Eric G.

description:
Musta' fallen on hard times, changed managers or something.  I stopped there recently, dressed in a t-shirt and shorts.  The bartender was too busy talking on the phone, then waiting to listen as one of the waitresses talked on the phone, to take my order.

With barely a glance at me, he took my order for a greyhound with Grey Goose.  Minutes later he returns to say they weere out of grapefruit juice.  I asked for a wine list, he took another few minutes to get me one, and then....never returned.  I waited five minutes, and left.

This used to be a highly rated restaurant.  The food may still be really good.  I, for one, shall never know.
author: Tony F.

description: I have only been twice for drinks but both times I had a really nice time. Bartender was very friendly and gave a few suggestions on things to do in the neighborhood. I really enjoy how it's a small cozy place and I love the piano player. I still need to have dinner and when I do I will revise my review.
author: Lisa A.

description:
classic French offerings mixed with new American -- really enjoyed the company that evening :)  very cozy and quiet on a weekday evening.  dimmer lighting as the evening rolled on.
sampled and shared Fresh Oysters (good), Oysters Rockefeller (good), Oven Roasted Escargot (ok), Pan Roasted Mussels (so so), Chicken Coq Au Vin (good, right amount of bacon), and Steak Au Poivre (they were out of the Bouillabaisse) -- steak sauce was off
author: Rob C.

description: My dog loved my left over rib bone!!! and I forgot about anything else I ate there but I recall it was um good, I think.
author: Royce L.

description: The restaurant does have a good atmosphere- dim and cozy (although the two elderlies at the table were holding candles up to their menu for extra light). The oysters were okay and the mussels were the same. My entree was what caught me off guard- an expensive non-note-worthy fillet mignon with mashed potatoes that tasted like they were flavored with a pound of salt. Three people at the table ordered the rack of lamb and all three complained that it was gamy. Definitely would not go back--- well, maybe for a cocktail at the bar.
author: C A.

description: A lunchtime favorite amongst busy business people in SOMA... live piano, good salads (they skimp on the greens sometimes), a nice variety of choices.  It's a little on the high end, so I don't recommend jeans and tees here even though they do serve burgers ($12 ish).  If you're watching your figure but want dessert, try the tropical sorbet in a chocolate shell (!!!).  Friendly and attentive staff, reservations recommended.
author: Jessica M.

description:
don't let the name fool you or turn you off.  it is an olde san francisco restaurant which i enjoyed.  the menu items are from yesteryear and for example celery victor sounds like the most unflavourable and thought provoking dish.  i don't know the last time i ate celery.  this is just a starter.  there are anchovies in it--and you know what it was delicious!  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: This place is really classy. The cuisine is light. At dinner, plates run $18-$25. I had the bouillabaisse, which was nicely done with scallops, shrimp, mahi mahi, and cracked crab. The ambiance is nice, dimly lit. Piano can be a little deafening, though.
author: Kevin L.

description: Decent food.  Not as good as the original in my mind but definitely not bad.  Its actually decently priced here so give it a try if in the mood for mediterranean inspired cuisine
author: Charles C.

description: Fly Trap is the place! First and foremost, the food- everything has incredible combinations of flavors/textures, some you may not have known existed.  You'll be rolling your eyes back in your head and moaning about how good it is. The staff is very friendly, nice, helpful, accomodating. Our server made a very good recommendation for wine, and did not steer me to the most expensive on the list.The decor is beautiful and warm. Hard to imagine a better dining experience than Zare at Fly Trap. It isn't cheap, but it is worth every penny. GO!
author: JOHN S.

description: Maybe the reviews I read got me a little too excited but I found myself walking out of this place going "eh, it's ok." I have definitely had better food but the service was friendly.
author: Audrey Jean T.

description: Had a reservation, but the table wasn't ready when we got there.  The manager was attentive enough to bring out two rounds of small appetizers to hold us over.  Started with the pistachio meatballs - wasn't a huge fan of it.  A friend started with the "Ménage a foie" - this is my recommendation.  The Abgusht lamb shank braise is worth trying (meat was really tender).  Great service and ambiance.  All in all, a pleasant dining experience.
author: Mark K.

description: Cozy atmosphere, old school charm, and great food will make me come back the Fly Trap.  Get there a bit early and enjoy the music to a drink at the bar.  Their Kauai Prawns are big enough for two people to share and their salmon has an outstanding sauce that almost made me lick the plate.
author: Angela D.

description: Not a very large restaurant, but quite comfy and cozy.  The piano player and jazz singer were good, albeit loud (we were right next to the entertainers).  But, the food was excellent.  The 2 drawbacks are 1) slow service 2) horrid bathrooms.  I would definitely go back, just be sure I have 3 hours to kill and not be very thirsty.
author: Christopher C.

description: Went here for lunch and was impressed most by the food, second by the ambiance and third by the service. The crab raviolis were so good, my dining companion and I reminesce about them still, two months later. The ambiance is very nice and classy. I thought the service was a bit stuffy, but it could've been my own lack of familiarity with fancy napkins and tablewear meant to be used more than once that made me uncomfortable.
author: Kate R.

description: Pretty decent place for a quick business meeting over drinks.  Perhaps a good place for a farewell happy hour too.  The food is pretty good but a little pricey.   The waitress is pretty nice and friendly.
author: Jeff H.

description: Despite a very attentive waiter and a good appetizer I was disappointed. My main course was too salty, as if an entire cellar of salt had been dumped on the unsuspecting butter lettuce to make up for its inherent lack of flavor. The crispy prosciutto, to which I had been looking forward, was a lump of salt. I've never liked dressings on salads for this precise reason: that because of those who are afraid of green meals, restaurants have made a practice of disguising lettuce and its relatives like a blemish or poor relation. I say free the natural flavor of greens. The ultimate goal of a chef should be to enhance a flavor, not sweep it under the rug. As a side note, overhearing a none-too-private tongue lashing of a waiter by the owner didn't earn this place any points either. They are your staff, not your help.
author: Christine P.

description: Great flavors and very interesting menu.  The drink menu is also great.  Very well prepared and flavorful food.  The duck legs and lamb tongue are spectacular.  Interesting deserts.  Easy on-street parking
author: Jeffrey P.

description: We accidentally went around first Zare's anniversary. The interior is very nice and warm. The service was very attentive and caring. Zare stopped by our table to check on the food and make some suggestions - very nice gesture. And food is just excellent - we started with drinks (I prefer sour cocktails and enjoyed Cardamom my dearest- quite interesting). Ate and highly recommend -pistachio meatnballs, smoked trout, soup and braised duck legs
author: P I.

description:
tried it out because of the great reviews (on sites besides yelp) and wasn't disappointed.  the atmosphere is hip and relaxed....which i prefer to places like Local Kitchen (which tries too hard to be something that it isn't).  the service was excellent and the female waitress made some great recommendations.

one of the salads:  good, but not worth $10.
meatball appetizer:  very good, but you should eat it with something else (such as a salad)
lamb shank:  awesome!  it was the waitress' rec and it was perfect....fall off the bone lamb in an incredible light sauce.  seasoned well.
fried bread thing:  amazing amazing amazing.

cost:  cheaper than expected....cuz it has $$$ on yelp.  it's between a $$ and $$$
author: Jay M.

description: A hidden gem in the SOMA district but everything was so good about this place!  Yes, the items were somewhat pricey but the food was cooked with the utmost highest standards.  I had the grilled white bass on warm mashed potatoes on a bed of cabbage couli.  Basically sauteed red cabbage slightly sweet!  The fish was cooked perfectly , that just melted in my mouth.  There was a pianist during the lunch hour on weekdays.  Very fancy for a lunchtime getaway from the office!
author: Carmen M.

description:
Opening day with almost all of the fantastic wait and bar staff from the last version of the flytrap. Today also included a very pleasant addition behind the bar to compliment Jay by the name of Bridget.
I reviewed the most interesting new menu and selected the beet carpaccio to start followed by the lamb shank.
I loved the beet dish served on a cold plate with sprinkles of feta over the yellow and red beets. This was a great taste sensation.
The lamb shank followed and by far was the best shank I have ever tasted. Lamb fell off of the bone and the light gravey with mixed veggies were wonderfull.
I was 100% satisfied from the welcomes back from Chris, Meg, Jay, Ricki from the ole staff and pleasant service from Bridget who served me. This was a great overall food, drink and service experience.
 I will certainly be returning here and referring friends and also hope to see Fernandos return behind the bar as well. Next time I will sample some of the great looking wine selections by the bottle as my glass of Sryah was very good for 9.00 per glass
author: Dave O.

description: Perhaps from the over-hype, it was underwhelming each time I've been. Ambiance was great for the neighborhood. Upscale, Mission-esque, with a Mediterranean flavor. It's a welcome addition to the neighborhood, shown by its popularity. If only the menu, food and execution lived up to the hype. But it's been rated so well, I'll give it a few more tries before passing a final verdict.
author: Dan S.

description: I used to eat at the Zare on Sacramento....the food there was great...the new place frankly was a major disappointment. My fish was dry and overcooked. The chicken dish was just awful. The deconstructed pie was simply retarded. The chocolate surprise was gimmicky and uninteresting.
author: Rob P.

description: I've been to the old Fly Trap many times and have always enjoyed the food there, which is why I was excited to finally try Zare. The menu is a bit daunting and made it hard for us to decide what to get. We finally just ordered the meatballs and a salad with fruit. Both dishes were quite good, but didn't wow either of us. The service was great and out server had some great suggestions on the wine list. I would go back for happy hour since it's around the corner from my office, but I don't think it'll be a dinner destination spot for me.
author: JS K.

description: The meal was excellent. I'm only giving this iteration of Zare 4 stars because it isn't as good as the prior one. The old place, Zare, on Sacramento was one of my favorite restaurants ever. I was sad when it closed. The menu here seems a bit smaller and not quite as european. Don't get me wrong, we had a great meal and it could be that nostalgia is playing a role in my 1 star deduction. I just wasn't as blown away as I was by the old place. My disappointment could also have been rooted in the fact that they were out of the lamb burger that I so craved.
author: Christopher K.

description: Just ate there with some friends. Food isn't as good as the pictures show. The meatballs had a very sweet sauce that didn't quite go with the taste of the meat. Lamb shank was very average.
author: blue s.

description: Went here for the first time for lunch yesterday and was very impressed. Lot's of cool food choices, we had the carpaccio, crab salad, crab stuffed pasta and apple fritters, all of which, maybe not divine, was all certainly very good. The wine list is decent, had a nice Malbec, the waiter was cool, and after lunch we saddled over to the bar and had a couple couvioussiers and oysters during happy hour. So, what ostensibly was supposed to be mellow afternoon lunch turned into an entire day at the Fly Trap, which turned out to be a great day. I would definitely recommend the Fly Trap!
author: Steve l.

description: While I don't eat red meat or poultry, I do have to give myself the guilty pleasure of liver and onions about once a year (yes, i am weird - i love liver and onions). Since i can't and won't cook it, and the only way i can get it the way i like it is to visit mom on the east coast and have her stink up her kitchen to make it for me, you can see that it is not always easy to get. Enter Flytrap. My hubby, who is not a fan of liver and onions, heard from a friend that they have it there. In an iron deficient moment of mine, boo suggested we go to flytrap and get my liver on. Flytrap rocked it! The liver was amazing, and the portion was huge! My tummy and my anemia thanks Flytrap!
author: Danielle S.

description: Last night was my third time at Zare at Flytrap, and I loved every minute of it... We ordered a bunch of different appetizers, an entree, and dessert. Each dish was beautiful to look at and even better to taste. My favorites: braised eggplant, menage a fois, beet salad, cod with saffron sauce and mussels, and the goat cheesecake was unbelievable. Light, almost savory. Service was excellent... mellow atmosphere. Phenomenal experience in every aspect. Go there!
author: Angela T.

description: The food was good but the service and atmosphere is lacking. First, the temperature in the restaurant was so warm it was uncomfortable (normal SF evening temperatures outside so the intense heat seemed bizarre). What really surprised me was the service from our waiter. We repeatedly inquired about his favorites and recommendations to help guide our choices but he seemed very put off by us asking questions and the whole process. The service improved throughout the meal but it was definitely a rough start.
author: Shannon R.

description: I have opted all invitations to go to this place for how many years it has been there ...name does not really impress me especially the story behind it..but tonight I am so impressed to have  tried to just go wherever I was invited to.  From my interview with the chef, they were just newly opened under his ownership but the name has been carried on  for 100 years..and told me so why is it fly trap because in the old days, there were so many horses in the area and so they would hang fly traps in front to catch the flies!! exactly why didn't want to go there because of the name..), But to my surprise, the place and food  is superb.. I love the exoticness blends of the sauces and the creativity for each dish! My fav. is the delicate lamb tongue as the appetizer and wild salmon as a main dish and finished with their chocolate dessert with a great red wine all the way, syrah 2003 which made my experience as enchanting just how the wine is labeled!!  The only thing here which is not my fav. is that the bread was not complimentary1
author: cecille p.

description: Nice place for a date.  Opens pretty late. Really liked the Butter Lettuce salad. And really good ribs that melt off the bone.
author: Janny J.

description:
this place is classy, yummy, and the menu is a wonderful mixture of classic old school favorites and modern experimentation. the service is great, the bar is excellent, and the decor is pleasant and interesting. 
if you're a fan of calves liver, bacon, and onions, they do it super well here. of course there are many other less 'classic' items on the menu :)
author: dj pie b.

description: My dad is one of those fellows who's smooth words and chivalrous moves has gotten him far in this world of women in restaurants.  The Fly Trap is a key ingredient.  With a singer who sounds like she was transported from a hot underground speakeasy, hot crusty bread and butter and exotic old school items like celery salad and sweatbreads.  Personally these things don't get me so riled up, mostly I enjoyed the quiet dark interior, scrumptious veal tortellini and the flicker of the attentive waiters eyes.  Go here, and take your parents.
author: Lindsey M.

description:
As long time regular patrons of the Fly Trap we were concerned that a new owner and remodel would not appeal to us.  Fortunately, the only noticeable decor changes were a change in accent paint colors and an addition of a community dining table.  There are new faces behind the bar and they have a new cocktail menu.  But the big difference was in the food.  We always loved the old Fly Trap but the food was just "OK by SF standards".  Now, the food is really very good.  I had the trout appetizer and the lamb shank entree.  Both were delicious.  They also upped their game on the wine list.  We are happy to see that the changes to the decor didn't affect the love we have for the Fly Trap and the new chef/owner should be proud.  

~ To the previous reviewer, I can understand your frustration.  When you tried to make your rezo in March, the old ownership had short-timers affliction.  I encourage you to try again with the new owners.
author: Bradley T.

description: We ate here Saturday night to celebrate my birthday.  The food was exquisite -- the pistachio meatballs, the baba ganoush and the lamb dishes were all amazing.  But the service definitely didn't live up to the food.  We had to wait for drinks until the appetizers were cold, the plates never got cleared, our entrees were served even though we had no utensils to eat with, and so on.
author: Juliet D.

description: This place has quickly catapulted itself to the top of my San Francisco short list. The food is delicious, my favorite being the various soups I've had there. I'm a vegetarian, so I haven't tried any of the meat dishes but all the friends I've eaten with there have loved them. The deserts (deconstructed apple pie, the beignets, and the porfiteroles) were all fantastic.  The service is warm, friendly and attentive. I organized a group of 13 last Saturday and the staff worked with us before dinner to make sure everything was taken care of. The bar also makes great cocktails and good conversation. Highly recommend this place to anybody who wants a great evening.
author: Aditya B.

description:
Spent Thanksgiving dinner at the Fly Trap. My college roommate and I had reservations for 8, but we showed up early and sat down at the bar. 

Fernando was excellent. He helped us pick out a wine and patiently waited while I told him how to make my favorite cocktail...which he nailed. We were having such a fun time that we stayed at the bar for the remainder of our meal--it was fabulous. 

The Fly Trap has a beautiful interior and I can't wait to come back when there is live piano music.
Thanks for a great night!
author: Charity A.

description: Normally I'd save this for after trying out the luncheon menu people seem to be thrilled about, but I couldn't help myself. My dad talked me into trying out this joint after a Cubs/Giants game and I think we could have done better at the Chophouse(not saying much). There is no excuse to have: a) overcooked sea bass, and b) a creme brulee that was two completely different temperatures. The service was decent and our bread/water was refilled often, perfect for a dehydrated Giants fan. Two stars pending review.
author: Christopher V.

description: I have been a fan of Chef Hoss Zare for a long time but this time he just blew me away with his worldly new menu.  The food is just crazy.  The service is very friendly and the atmosphere rocks!  I love the outdoor seating area with the flowers.  I think I have found my new hang-out place.   You can find me by the bar most likely.  Cheers!
author: Tom K.

description:
I went to this place last night based on the reviews but I was really disappointed.  I agree.  The restaurant is nice.  The lighting is a little too bright to call "nice ambiance" but it's cute.  And the service was really nice.  We had a nice waiter.

But the food was ok at best.  We had the stake, Soup of Yesterday, and grazed eggplants.  They were all ok.  We couldn't finish them because everything lacked the subtlety and sophistication that we looked for.  We moved from NY recently and are still looking for good restaurant in SF and we were hoping yelp was a source we could trust... maybe we are too picky..
author: mice o.

description:
I had a wonderful experience with this restaurant.  The service was really great and my duck legs were fantastic.  All the dishes are saucy, and I'm all about the sauce.  My duck was tender, salty, sweet, tart all at once and even worked with the veggies that I substituted for the basmati rice.

Everything on the menu looks good and when checking out other dishes on tables, they all looked really good as well.

It's not a "hip" place, it seems a little more old school style but I liked that.
author: anderson g.

description: I had lunch here yesterday.  I was just walking around looking for a place to have lunch before a meeting at US EPA.  When I looked at the menu on the outside, I knew that this was the right place.  I was a little early (11:30) but I was surprised that it wasn't more crowded.  I had a hard time picking just one dish - they all sounded so good.  I had the lentil salmon salad - it was great!  The lentil salad had little tiny chopped pieces of endive, fennel, red pepper ub it and a deliciuos salsa tied the salmon and salad together.  So flavorful!  It was just the right amont for lunch - not too much, not too little.  The price of $10.00 was perfect too.  After that, I blew my south beach diet plan and had the goat cheesecake - it was amazing.  This place should be packed, given the incredible (and healthy) food and such a decent price for lunch.  If you City people don't appreciate this place for lunch, maybe we can lure them to Sacramento!
author: Kathryn T.

description: Beautiful decor, gracious, charming service (thanks so much to the pretty female server who brought us the sparkling dessert wine at the end of the meal)...outstanding salmon, and I will be back very soon to see about the lamb shank...
author: Tonya M.

description: Phenomenal food, great decor and ambiance. I especially loved the smoked trout, salmon, and the vegetarian meatball. I will definitely be back.
author: Gigi H.

description: i just tried the Fly Trap out last night and was very impressed. i'm a huge fan of piano players so i couldn't have been happier. the atmosphere was intimate and cozy-- perfect for a date. the food, although pricey, was fabulous! i'm so glad i live close by, this is definitely somewhere i'll come back. even if just for a drink at the bar.
author: Michelle I.

description: I ordered the special entrée of the day, it was basically lamb pasta. The meat was sooo tender and delicious, only downside was some of the pasta was hard (probably due to being precooked and sitting under heat waiting to be made). The delight of the night was surprisingly the french fries with a saffron dipping sauce side order and the goat cheese cheesecake. Yummm! The cheesecake was so smooth and light. The service was great too. We had some miscommunication with our hotel car picking us up and left us.  We left the restaurant, and was waiting outside for the car to come but some how the driver did not see us and we did not see him. The driver was suppose to call my cell to tell us he was there but instead he went into the restaurant to check where we were. The host told him we left already. Even though the restaurant was not responsible they still came out and apologized for sending our hotel car away.  I was very impressed considering the hotel car didn't even apologize for not calling.
author: Jess H.

description: Im rating a 1 for the service I received when trying to book a party at work.  I was organizing an event for my coworkers and happened upon  the Fly Trap.   I had checked online and the place looked great and I was in charge of providing options for a lunch meeting for my job.  I had called to find out the pricing, availability, etc.  I called the first time and someone picked up and hung up on me.   I thought this odd since the placed looked so nice on the internet.  I waited about an hour later and called back.  The woman that answered the phone just said "hello".  I was not sure if she was a customer or employee.  I then asked if this is the Fly Trap and she responded with "yeah".  There was no mention of " how can I help you" or anything professional.  I mentioned that I wanted to discuss having a lunch party at the trap.  She said "hold on".  I was on hold for about 15 minutes before I finally gave up.  I will hold when I think the place is really busy but fifteen minutes is a crazy long time to wait when I am trying to get them to take my company meeting. I attempted a third time to contact them and left a message for someone to call me back to discuss schedules and pricing.  Never got a call back from anyone at the Fly Trap.  I think 3 attempts is plenty and if they are not professional enough to handle customers in a better way, i would take my business elsewhere.  This was back in March and so we just decided to go to Buca De Peppo in a last minute crunch while waiting for call back from the Fly Trap.  They actually returned calls and were willing to assist us which was more than the fly trap offered.  Judging by the reviews from the other Yelpers, they all had better experiences than I did so maybe the Fly Trap works better when you just have smaller parties.
author: Adam B.

description: My wife and I loved Hoss' intimate place on Sacramento. But he left SF for Napa. We thought we might never see him and his lovely Cal-Med cuisine again. Then looking around Yelp for a place to eat last Saturday, I find Zare at Fly Trap. Now the Fly Trap (pre-Zare) was a neat place. The space reminded me of something from another era. The menu was certainly from another era - Shrimp Louis, Clams Casino, other classic yet stale American fare. So this combination seemed like a match made in heaven - a cool space with a hot chef. My wife had the buratta app, while I started with the butter lettuce salad. We shared a plate of the fries with saffron aioli. The food was very good. My wife had a half bottle of a white burgundy off the small, but thorough wine list. For our main courses, wifey had the salmon served with roasted fregola (couscous on steroids) and veggies. I had the lamb shank, which was outrageously tender and beautifully spiced. We finished with a goat cheese cheesecake. I was especially excited about this. At his prior place, the kitchen was so small desserts were somewhat of an after-thought and I thought they never quite held up. But this cheesecake was outstanding. It was less tangy than I expected, but the texture was unbelievable. It was so soft and smooth, rich without being too sweet. Overall, it was a great experience. The prices were reasonable. The service friendly and attentive. Hoss, It was so good to see you again.
author: Alex C.

description:
A friend and I made reservations for a special prix- fixe dinner offered at $80.00 per person with wine pairing for an additional $30.00 per person celebrating the Iranian/Persian New Year Navrooz..
The dinner was a failure in my opinion. I am very familiar with Persian food. This menu was totally "sour" by too much lemon or too much vinegar not sure. The brown sauce which accompanied the frenched chicken legs tasted of absolutely of nothing, no taste at all. Most items which were not pickled lacked salt.
We were promised leg of lamb on the menu instead we were served small portion of lamb shank in a tasteless broth.
Wine paring consisted of some unknown white and red wines whichever you chose at unlimited pouring, that is it.! We could not bear it any longer, we left before the desert course.
The setting with all celebratory decorations was very nice. But food!??? We will not repeat the same mistake.
author: Yasmine S.

description: five stars for the old fly trap, 1 freaking star for crappy zare's cuz it's just not cool to create fake yelp profiles and harass people that don't like your food.
author: Jennifer G.

description: This place deserves their reputation for tasty, creative cocktails.  Their vegetarian menu is also very well crafted - give the eggplant a try.
author: Rhea H.

description: The service was very good.  The setting is very well done.  I was disapointed with the actual food.  Have only been 1x and will update the review if anything changes after next visit
author: Marty C.

description: My stomach thanked me after dinner last night at the Fly Trap...no, I mean it actually reached out and shook my hand and said "you have never satisfied me like that before, and I thank you for it." Haha, I had my first oyster experience here last night and they are interesting...they were good though, kinda slimy and soft but they seemed really fresh and I liked the cocktail sauce. My sexy, sexy date suggested that I get the salmon, and it was so good I felt like I shoulda jumped under the table and gotten busy with him right then and there. Sriusly tho the salmon melts in your mouth like butta and it comes with mashed taters. We split the Arugula salad with pears, candied walnuts and goat cheese...i think the description speaks for itself about how good it was. He got the crab ravioli, which I'm pretty sure was made with angel baby tears, and was sooo good it almost made me cry. The service was excellent, the atmosphere superb, and it put me in that romantico feeling that carried all the way home....
author: Amanda S.

description: Fantastic, everything you want in a restaurant. The space itself is the perfect size composed of an intimate bar, sleek communal tables  perfect for a casual drink/appetizer, and comfortable banquets. The warm lighting and cozy ambiance invite you to linger over your meal. The staff is impecable, each element; chef, pastry chef, sommelier, bar manager are extremely cool, friendly and knowledgeable. Everything on the menu has an ecclectic Mediterranean twist using fresh ingredients to achieve a clean and flavorful taste in your mouth. The pistachio lamb meatballs, lamb tongue with white asparagus, grilled whole sardines with heirloom tomatoes and cucumber, and smoked trout with creme fraiche, cucumber strands and salmon roe were spectaculer. We were very lucky to have each of these courses masterfully paired with the perfect wine, they have a vast selection! Although we were too full for dessert we managed to fit it in and I am glad we did. The goat cheese cheesecake with marinated figs and a shortbread crust was the best cheesecake I have ever had, so light and airy. Also not to be missed was the Rocky Road re-creation; mini chocolate cakes topped with homemade ice-cream, tahitian vanilla marshmallows, candied peanuts  and chocolate sauce. Until next time.....
author: Laura Gardner S.

description: Very good crab cake. I hope the remodeling wasnt an euphenism for change in management, because this place IS GOOD. This is probably one of the few restaurants that have severed my fish entree with the proper temperature INSIDE the fish. I didnt even realize they could have warm insides for fish since I imagined that would have naturally burnt the exterior. Great food. The waitress was friendly too. I love the bread.
author: eric h.

description: Really good stuff. Creative food, creative wine list with a reasonable markup. Service was mediocre, but it was more than made up for with innovative creations from the first course to the goat cheese cheesecake (think low-carbon footprint with delicious unmistakable tang). We had the grilled sardines and trio o' livers for starters - both dishes were outstanding. Followed that up with the market fish and a hunk o' meat w/ a luscious marrow bone. Did I already say, outstanding? And the dessert... you got it, outstanding. Wine list is cool with some unique stuff including the half bottles and wine by the glass. And some interesting cocktails, and I mean that in an interesting = good way.  I said it once, I'll say it again - outstanding!
author: Matt B.

description: An expensive lunch with decent-sized portions? Blink, blink.  We went here to celebrate a coworker and really enjoyed our meal. I loved the brown walnut bread with unchilled butter served just as it should be. My swordfish special was delicious, and big enough to parcel out tastes without sacrificing my own portion. We split two fairly boring desserts that regardless hit the sweet spot. I'm not sure I'd come here on my own, but I'll be the first one in the door if we came for another work lunch.
author: Jessica D.

description: the service here i remember was a bit awkward, but they tried pretty hard. the dishes here are sort of on the expensive side, but the portions of the dishes were pretty good. i was REALLY happy with my salmon - it came with mixed veggies and a great cream sauce. ur supposed to mix everything together and eat it, and it tasted good. i also tried my friend's risotto, just the right amount of creamy-cheesy goodness. the best part i think was dessert  -  i had this friend-donut type thing, where you dip it into hot chocolate - great stuff. the food here is pretty good overall, but maybe not good enough for their prices.
author: Angie K.

description: An average of four stars?  As Seth Myers would say, "Really?"  This place was SO average and SO bland that it should be instantly forgettable.  Except it's not.  The blandness and the mediocrity persist in memory.  The meatballs people are raving about have no zip, no personality.  The sea bass on pasta with heirloom tomatoes was overcooked and bland.  (At least the diced tomatoes had some flavor.  Two of my party of four had the lamb shank -- both HATED it.  Couldn't finish.  Made them ill.  The fried mozarella appetizer wasn't even worthy of a sports bar, though I will say the french fries with saffron aioli were tasty.
author: Tom B.

description: I really liked this place.  Meditarranean food of good quality.  Over great time at this place. Good mixture of food and drinks.
author: Brian S.

description: The restaurant space is lovely, as are the people that work at the restaurant. It is a gem of the space. The food however is uneven. The beet salad was out of this world with the mint and the dips for the bread delicious, but the calamari/octopus salad was flavorless with no zing and the beef kabob really overcooked with a funny salad that was twice the portion of the meat. Good wine list."
author: B.M. B.

description: This place used to be yummy . . not sure if it's the 'Zare' part bringing it down.  I ordered the sea bass and it was . . well not so good.  The flavors didn't work together at all and I'm pretty sure the side of chick peas and eggplant wasn't fully cooked.  My co-lunchers complained of their orders of beef rib being dry.  All in all - very disappointing and now VERY overpriced for the quality of food.  Two stars for good attentive service.
author: Sadie W.

description: The "new" flytrap is delish! the food is so good! the app's are great the main dishes that we shared were really good and the deserts we shared were fab! There was a big group of us so we tried almost everything on the menu.... the meatballs were really good as was the lamb and everything else.
author: mary r.

description: we went for a birthday dinner last night. Most of us had been to zare's on sac or the haight back in the day. this was the best effort yet. we ended up sharing a whole bunch of apps and sides and desserts. everything was great. the squash, the eggplant, the bread and dips, the fried mozarrella salad, the squid, the deconstructed [apparently the latest term for foodies these days] lemon curd pie. very, very good. looking forward to 1) trying the lamb dishes and 2) taking a friend to swoon over the yogurt and honey dessert.
author: Rachelskid L.
